=======ANYTHING ELSE=======
Game focuses on the period from the Hundred Years' War to the Victorian era. When starting in 1444, Jeanne d'Arc had only passed away about a decade prior. However, recalling the Jeanne d'Arc campaign in Age of Empires II, with a depiction of medieval knights, longswords, and crossbowmen, it suddenly feels quite fantastical. But we all know that France had cannons towards the end of the War.

Personally, I believe EU4 is the easiest entry in Paradox Four (excluding Stellaris). Learning EU4 is actually quite simple. Choose any major European country, press the spacebar to release the pause, watch time pass by and deal with events as they come. After waiting for 200 years of history, you naturally learn the game and then want to start over. Continuously simulating the course of history is perhaps the most enjoyable aspect of Paradox games.

Although EU4 appears to have a multitude of adjustable and controllable parameters and variables, many things do not need to be meticulously detailed. They can be effectively resolved through the game's event handler.

That I said, when someone accidentally fractures a skull and you see that large newly colored area, the sense of achievement is overwhelming.

My favorite video game ever and quite possibly the greatest game ever made. There's a specific comfort that I can get only by playing eu4 which is why for the past ~8ish years i keep coming back to this game. I don't think this game will ever get old and I can't even imagine eu5 will come anywhere close to being this good. It's simply impossible. Theres a big learning curve for beginners, especially those who never played these types of complex grand strategy games (which was my experience) but it is well worth overcoming that curve because the game is so great. If you're trying to learn the mechanics of the game I recommend watching youtubers like The Red Hawk play guides of whatever nation while you play along. 

Long story short: This game is the GOAT. Paradox and their team deserve all the praise for this incredible game

This game is incredibly exciting to play, offering a depth of complexity that surpasses titles like Civilization V. Although I'm relatively new to Europa Universalis IV (EU4), I've been familiar with the game for some time. Having recently acquired it, I eagerly dove in. Initially, the learning curve felt steep, almost overwhelming. However, with each game, I've gained valuable insights from both triumphs and setbacks, navigating through success and near financial ruin.

As a history enthusiast, I can attest to the game's immersive historical elements. Whether you share this passion or not, EU4 provides endless entertainment. Multiplayer mode is particularly outstanding; playing with friends can easily lead to marathon sessions that stretch on for hours.

EU4 has firmly secured its place as one of my favorite strategy games, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking a rich and rewarding gaming experience.

Before talking about this game, let me explain why my review matters. I have almost a thousand hours on this game, on steam, I have seen it inside and outside, vanilla and modded. While I did have about 50 hours of fun on this game, the other 914.2 hours were insufferable and disheartening.

You can have fun with this game, you really can, but it isn't worth it. This is because:
It is a bad game. It just wastes your time coloring an ugly map(which only gets uglier) with one of many disgusting colors like pure puke green, It is built to be addicting and hurtful. This game is the definition of cocaine, so I have wasted 2 years + on this game, do NOT buy it. Do NOT be tempted by it or any of its siblings. The entire paradox grand-strategy genre is a waste of time & money. The game design is wonderful, the music exhilarating, this is a well designed game, but you should not play it, as it is designed to be good, but in practice, it is one of the worst experiences you can have with a game.  

Please do yourself a favor and avoid games like this. If you REALLY want to play a strategy game, play civilization 6.

Great game and I think this could be a revolutionary educational tool, here is some of my feedback on how I would improve the game.

Natives and Colonization: natives are too op to be fair or historical, there should be some sort of event about the spread of smallpox that destroys your manpower reserves/stability as natives because that's what happened historically and could balance the game.

Pacific Island nations- i dont think the game should have these both for mechanical reasons as well as historical reasons, just have regular uncolonized. Now on or two sure, but nearly every island: NO.

Coalitions: I beat the same worldwide coalition 5 times in a row, utterly, like destroyed them and took basically no losses, and yet time and time again they will join back and fight me only to die. How is this realistic or a good game mechanic, who would willingly continue to join a coalition and march their entire economy, military, and nations to their death time and time again.All im saying is that it would fix a lot of these issues and make the game more realistic if there was maybe a option in the peace menue during coalition wars that was something along the lines of "cant join a coalition for the next 20 years".

Expanding Christianity: there needs to be some sort of mechanism to send missionaries to African and Asian nations, as was done historically and led to large scale christian movements in China,Japan,Africa, etc.

Genuinely the most in depth paradox game to date, and still getting support after 11 years is insane. Say what you will about their DLC policy, but I think it gives the game more life as time goes on. If this game had 2-4 DLC for $20 each instead, it would've been dropped in 2017 or earlier. I have no problem with the DLC as you can just buy it on sale, or not buy it at all and acquire it through other means. That being said it has thousands of hours of replayability and takes plenty of time to adapt to the games mechanics and systems of each nation offers a unique gameplay experience whether you want to form Japan during the Edo period or conquer the HRE and confederate all of Germany into one nation.

Europa Universalis 4 is what I'd describe as the most feature-rich Paradox game out there. It retains many aspects of board games from its "mana/power" systems and includes hundreds of playable (and fun) nations. If you are not at least somewhat inclined to min-max, interested in history, or care about numbers, then this game may seem boring for you. This game kickstarted my love of history, and the countless hours that I put into it makes buying all of the DLC worthwhile. (Albeit on sale.)

It is incredibly replayable, if not due to the sheer number of nations, due to the dynamic historical events and RNG that is a part of the game. The game spans almost 400 years, a span that can even be lengthened to THOUSANDS with mods. 

The modding community is enormous for this game, which recently passed 10 years of age. I've dabbled in modding even myself, which is quite easy for someone that doesn't know how to code in Paradox's scripting language.

It takes about 30 hours of playtime to learn the game, but almost 1-2k hours to master it and figure out all of the inner workings and secrets of the game. I just learned at 2.5k hours that the "improve relations modifier" helps reduce aggressive expansion. I wish I knew that earlier! But learning these new strategies and secrets are what keep me coming back to the game.

Multiplayer is pretty fun, but my personal favorite play style is role playing in single player, taking into account my ruler's traits and my nation's immediate goals.

I'd be lying if I just said that I don't recommend EU4. 
Painting the map under your desired nation, whilst learning some history along the way too; that is a great combination. The game is quite deep too - you'd need atleast 2 hours or so minimun to get a grip of the interface alone. But I'd say it's well worth the trouble: who wouldn't want to change the course of history with your self insert ruler restoring the Roman Empire in year 1600 as Albania? Even if the history stuff doesn't appeal to you, it's still a very much stimulating game in it's own - managing the economy, diplomacy, armies, trade and steadily improving your nation - in hundreds of different countries. You kind of forget about the history stuff (not like the ai nations try being historical anyway). There's also mods - if you want to go through the successive or predecessive timelines that the game didn't offer you, or just alternate history scenarios. Awesome.

But I can't recommend EU4 however.
Because of:

1. The DLC (unsurprisingly).
Ultimate bundle is about eight times the cost of the game itself. It doesn't help either that... well, the dlc is just kind content yoinked from the game. I'm not exaggerating; vassal interactions, for example, is a dlc only feature. It exists in the game without dlc for some reason, but with a message overlaying that "subject interactions is not available now". Well what was the point of that, then??

You might think that 10 years worth of dlc packs makes a game with the already much gameplay variety even more overwhelming. And well, you're not wrong, but some dlc features should really have been essential from the beginning. For example, you cannot release vassals from lands you conquer; making world conquests about a hundred times slower and coalitions last forever. Most mods also expect you to have all the dlcs, so it's not like you can pick one either way.

2. The loading times. Unreasonably long, and once you start the game, you might aswell just go outside, meet a girl and start a family, because it's gotta be one of the worst loading times in any game. Ten minutes is the average for me, and if you have a chad thundercock space sex pc 42069 flex, then good for you I guess. You still have to wait though, and that applies if you go back to the menu while ingame. Europa Universalis 3 and Victoria 2 had some, about a minute of loading before coming to the menu. After that, there's essantially no loading screens at all. Unlike in this game, where the damned loading screen is resurrected for every time you want to go back to the menu. It's like you should be grateful for only having to wait 5 minutes less than before; because you clicked "back" in the countries' selection screen, to return to the menu. It's really frustrating. 

The only way to make the game run faster is by disabling, like, all graphics. The ocean goes black, hills become flat and armies invisible - only for a ducat worth of better performance. Yeah, I'm talking about performance now. Did I mention how the game runs like ass? No I didn't, but it takes 10(100) times longer to pass a year in eu4 when compared to eu3 - especially in the later stages of the game.

You come back to it in the same mindset of a tf2 player; finding yourself hitting your head on your desk over all the negatives that you decided to forgive in favor of the entertainment that was just sitting and waiting. Again, I'd be lying if I said that I don't recommend EU4, but it's flaws are pretty obvious. You could always play it the poor man's way, without the dlc, and endure the loading times. If you can keep that up for 835 hours, then props to you, sir, the game is yours. You owe me 300 euros though. Think over it before buying.

coming from a fairly casual strategy game player (Really all my experience is Hoi4, civ, AOE,) this game is pretty fun but complex.

The reason why I'm not recommending this game though isn't because I'm a casual or because the game is too complex, the issue is that the devs hide very important QOL changes behind very expensive DLC. Changes that you'd hope that the devs would just add to the main game, they push to DLC to help push sales. I played this game for around 8 hours without the DLC and the experience with the DLC as compared to without it is just night and day. 

If you buy this game, buy it when its **very cheap** and look up info on which DLC is important and pick those up too. Some are pretty shitty but there are a few that are basically mandatory.  Otherwise you'll probably get stuck paying $5/m for the DLC, which actually isn't bad, but the fact that this game is significantly worse without the dlc its much less of a choice than a demand.


edit: 6/20/21 I've dumped almost 1000 hours into the game on 1.30 and 1.31 added a bunch of cool new features through DLC. Don't buy EU4 anymore. This game is horribly unoptimized. They added too much stuff to the game and the performance suffers greatly because of it. The game just becomes unplayable after 1600 because the framerate even on lower speeds just gets wayyyy too choppy. 

It's time for EU5. I don't even really think this game is that worth it to play on older patches simply because of the lack of QOL that has been added throughout the years.

edit 2: 1/19/24. Quite a few years since my last update to this. It runs better than it did the last time I updated my review, quite a bit better in fact. Also the DLC they have added since has been pretty spectacular and added an insane amount of enjoyment to once boring nations.  DLC is VERY expensive though, so that almost makes me want to turn it back to no, but I believe paradox has helped the stability of this game a lot while also adding hundreds of hours in gameplay from basically every dlc they add, so that bumps it up  to yes for me :)

The mind boggles at how much thought and effort went into this game.  This is the grand daddy of strategy games.  They thought of pretty much everything.  And the replayability factor is off the scale.  Playing every nation just once would probably take you around 10,000 hours of gameplay.  If you like history and have the patience to learn how to play it - as it will take many hours just to understand what you should be doing.  Then this is an excellent game.  Not for the casual audience.  My only real grip with the game is that sometimes its a bit too historical.  Im not really sure why some nations should get bonuses.  Its more fun seeing what random situations can develop IMO.  And they really ought to add something into the end game so that it spices it up a bit.  As many nations you play as are kind of boring after a certain amount of time.  But yeah - great game, highly recommend.

Play this now while you can, this game was clearly made in a different time, back when we thought Mackelmore was going to have a career and not merely be a shill for not having children in pointless relationships.

Honestly, it's very complicated game they just keep shoving new programming on top and it somehow still works.  It's the one of the few PDX games where you can play anyone in the world if they were around in 1444.  Also because of when it came out, while the PC police were bad they hadn't ruined all of entertainment yet so you can actually colonize the new world, engage in slavery, battle in wars of religion, basically all things you literally cannot even discuss on PDX own forums (eat shit assholes).

Obviously they will be bought off by BlackRock and the DEI crowd so just like Vic 3 expect this to be the last faithful representation of the Renaissance and Enlightenment although you can tell even with their later DLCs they are already caving a little but they can't go full toxic SJW without breaking the game.

Game wise if you play CK or Imperator Rome it's basically just my stack beats your stack.  It's more about the enjoyment of not having to hang your head in shame about some of the most impressive feats of human history especially for Europeans and the Ottomans that definitely led to the modern world.   The game also certainly makes you realize why so many things that are now deemed "bad" occurred because well various nations refused to by wiped out by the other and as such everyone else in the way had to pick a side whether they wanted to or not. 

But at least it was actual progress and people actually benefited from it as a whole whereas now all you get is a new iphone that tracks you better and magically begins to have lots of bugs by the time you pay it off.  Don't buy the DLC either, just buy the base, rent the DLC and drop it like a rock when you're done.

This game is in the same framework as Crusader Kings II, and it SHOWS. I wanted to like this game, but I'm sorry, its time to send this puppy to live out her golden years on Grampa and Gramma's farm in the country because it is so aged and decrepit. The entire execution of the concept is racist as shit and, AND: it's only really playable at all as one of the major European powers. I'm sorry, but that's not what I came here to play, I came to build a nation of Amazons in the amazon, but, yeah, that isn't particularly possible since most of the Amazon is "Wasteland", impassible, and uncolonizable which is unconscionable. 

Oh, and to add insult to injury; IMPERIAL CHINA, the last of the surviving O.G. civilizations, even then, cant build anything except forts because they lack the tech for it... 

WHAT?!?!? 

China was orderly, organized, self-sufficient, and playing with gunpowder as a TOY when the people of Northern Europe were still running around with stone knives and bear-skins. The only reason China was overcome by Europe in the end was they got COMPLACENT, not that Europe was superior in ANY way, shape, or form at _this_ period in history. (That would ultimately change, but not until the time-period of the NEXT game in the course of a "Grand-Campaign"...)

Oh, and don't get me STARTED on the inheritance mechanics, or rather, the LACK of the same! You can have ONE heir, take them or leave them, and weather you can even GET a consort is... Random...? The _hell_ guys? Were you, like, asleep at the keyboard when you programmed that...?

No offense, but this game is so far behind the modern benchmarks you've set with CKIII and Victoria 3 that it's just unplayable, and needs a total from-the-ground rebuild similar to what CKII got a few years ago with the creation of CKIII: and Victoria II got more recently with Vic3. Until that happens? This is only good for "Grand-Campaign" playthroughs and maybe nostalgia: DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY!

EU4 is one of my all-time favorite games, and has my highest hour count on Steam. There's nothing like stackwiping half of the Russian or Ottoman armies within a year of going to war with them. There's nothing like the advanced trade and colonial establishments. And there's nothing like the satisfaction of raising whichever country you choose to ultimate glory (and the top of the ledger).

While this game is a great recreation of early modern history, it certainly has its drawbacks. It is quite a lackluster game without any of the DLC. And even with all of the DLC, there are plenty of mods to be used that make the game even better. I don't even play this game without mods AT ALL because the map itself is so bad. You don't even need "border gore" to strain your eyes while looking at the map because the provinces look like chicken nuggets with aids. There's nothing historical about the provinces' designs, which is why you should check out my mod, Realistic Europa: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2624910016
Aside from that, there are few games I have had as much with as I have EU4. It's especially fun with friends. And given that this game is over 10 years old, my friends and I, surprisingly, rarely have connection issues, even while using a dozen mods.

What I wanted to out of Crusader Kings! Great Game!

OK, the year is 1860 and playing as Portugal had to find an ally to fight Delhi in northern India who got enormous by that time.

Looking at the allies - Austria doesn't have a border and too far away from Delhi to be useful in that war and China is to weak to hold up the fort.

OK, looking at the map we can see Poland the size of Delhi in terms of land and troops AND bordering Delhi ! Perfect ! BUT, they happened to declare us as a rival and went hostile, pirating, spying etc etc. Damn, what do we do ?

Declare on Poland with the help of Austria and make them to drop rivalry ! Ally ? NO, damn :)

Wait 10 years for the war debuffs to wear out, sell them an ex Swedish province they want so badly and I just happened to get my hands on in the early game (Yes, Poland conquered all Sweden and Russia all the way East to the Urals). Give them money and voila ! They agreed to the alliance !

Now to India ! :) Thank you Paradox !

This game's tutorial does not give justice to just how many mechanics there are. There's a reason that the community jokes about how the tutorial ends on hitting the 1000 hour mark.

Don't let that scare you away, tough! It's the most stream-lined grand strategy game from Paradox. Probably why it has the highest player count. It's not like HOI4 where you can literally pick individual parts of every individual warship to customize it. Mechanics are pretty simple, there's just a lot of interaction between them that you need to learn.

You have 400 years of human history to guide a random nation through. This being a sandbox game, you set your own goals to reach through a campaign. A good starting point are either easier achievements or trying to unite the home region of your starting nation.

That being said... the base game without the DLCs feels restrictive and limited. If you get hooked into this game, I recommend only getting the most important DLC centered around the nations you like to play as or plan to play as. 

On the other hand, Europa Universalis would probably be even more newb-unfriendly with all the additional mechanics from the DLCs. Think of the base game as a "extensive demo".

In conclusion, best glorified map-staring competition. Would bring the mighty empire of Ulm back to its former glory again.

EU4 is a great game that's hard to recommend. Between the insane learning curve, and all of the DLC which many are essential for the up to date version of the game to be playable its a tough sell. That being said its the deepest grand strategy game I've played by far.  

First, what could the game improve upon? The mana system (monarch points) is by far its weakest aspect and unfortunately tied to many aspects, such as development, technology, and many other aspects. You will need to learn it in order to master the game and learn to use it efficiently. I feel like imperator rome's  / victoria series population system would fit much better in this as it encourages a tall gameplay style. While playing tall has been improved upon, playing wide is almost always a better option, hence why many call EU4 a map painter game.

Second, the trade system should be dynamic. The fact that the trade mapmode is static and trade flows don't change during the entire game sessions is silly and is not realistic at all. I do like how trade works, if it changed back and forth given demand I feel like it would be perfect but what we have is honestly pretty good minus it not changing over time. 

Now for the good, diplomacy is amazing. I've never played a game where the diplomacy works this well. The wars you sometimes end up fighting due all of the diplomatic ties that everyone has can make the game very interesting and honestly drives a lot of what you end up doing. Allies, rivals and their interactions are fantastic. The sheer amount of options you have when interacting with another country is insane and no other game matches this complexity and interactivity. 

Warfare is also quite fun as the game is in real-time. This gives the timing of where armies go much more importance and micro-ing said armies to do quick hit and runs off of your enemies smaller stacks. Taking down forts, fortifying your own provinces and fighting through them are quite enjoyable.  The actual tactics once the armies clash leaves something to be desired as its all pre-determined before the fight starts and oftentimes can end up being whomever has the biggest army wins (though not always). Peace deals are also done the better than all of the other paradox games with a warscore system that go up and down based on your performance in the war along with what the actual stated wargoal is. My only wish was that there could be a plus and minus to the peace (as in I give you a province, but I'll take this province) etc. Otherwise its done very well. Aggressive expansion is a great mechanic that slows down the player mainly, I wish AI would sometimes risk it and have high AE as well. I have never been able to be in a coalition against an AI, ever. 

Multiplayer is also a great aspect that cannot be understated. You can even have friends join in your singleplayer sessions (assuming they aren't ironman) play as a nation for a bit and then keep playing afterwards. This is amazing and I wish more games did this. Ironman is fun, but the removal of the multiplayer aspect definitely steers me away from this mode which is unfortunate as its what you'll need to play to get achievements. 

There's much much more that I haven't covered but in all I can recommend EU4 but be warned of the DLC high pricetag, get the DLC on sale and absolutely buy the base game on sale.  If you have friends that play, only the host needs the DLC, which is something to keep in mind.

I really love EU4, it's one of my favorite games of all time, I even listen to its soundtrack while lifting weights. But the monetization model, followed by the lack of necessary changes to unfun game mechanics forces me to not recommend it. If you want to play a Paradox game, I recommend Hearts of Iron IV or Stellaris.

EU4's DLC policy is just a joke. This is a $40 interactive map made almost 11 years ago. Why is this still $40? Not only this, but the vanilla, no DLC experience of EU4 is laughable and shallow. Extremely important features, such as focusing monarch points, and transferring occupation to / from a vassal are completely locked behind updates with $5-$15 price walls. I understand the market for these kinds of games is small, but this honestly should be illegal, or not allowed on Steam. The purpose of a DLC is to expand the base experience, adding more to an already fun and completed product.

You simply cannot experience whether or not the game is for you or not if you have the DLC. Everything from flavor, mechanics, scripts, events, and playstyles depends entirely on owning the appropriate DLC. Which DLC do you need for X feature? Who knows! So, Paradox adds a seemingly good "deal" by allowing you to spend $5 a month via subscription to unlock all "DLC." This is a good deal in theory, but the fact that I am spending $5 on a game I spent $40 for is absurd, and should be illegal in an ideal World and market.

Let's talk changes. EU4 has changed so much, it's basically EU5. EU4 is nothing like it was 10-11 years ago, and a lot of that is definitely for the best. However, a lot of very annoying, tedious, unfun, and blatantly unfair mechanics have gone virtually untouched.

In terms of battles, mechanically, EU4 is pretty simple. Click your soldiers, move them to tile. So, of course there have to be mechanics to add difficulty, to avoid a braindead map color changer. This is not done so in any fair metric, however, as countries such as the Ottomans and Korea are so senselessly and unfairly broken just be hidden stat modifers, that you're essentially losing battle after battle to a braindead computer robot army, that has absolutely zero strategy or intelligence to it. The AI in EU4 is terrible, and instead of working on a good AI, Paradox just adds unfair modifiers and country-specific scripts to make the game artificially harder. This is not fun to play against.

Warscore makes zero sense. If you're an Asian country and you're having a war with European colonies, except a long, boring war of nothingness. Have full naval dominance, and your wargoal locked down? +3 warscore. Have the entirety of France occupied, and Paris burnt to the grown? +44 warscore. Have literally the entire Siberian frontier occupied? +12 warscore. [b]Battles do not win nearly enough warscore.[/b] There ARE mods that fix this, but they are not Ironman compatible. 

There is no real aspect of "campaigning" against the AI during war. For instance, if you and your neighbor go to war, the AI is much more likely to attempt and "snake" its armies around yours, just "backdooring" your provinces, wasting your time and playing a very annoying game of cat and mouse, instead of two colossal armies battling for glory. This is extremely obnoxious if you play as China, Russia, or any country with a lot of provinces. 

Colonization is extremely dull and boring. The AI has absolutely no idea how to guard its colonies, and the process is way too slow. Spain from 1492 to the mid 1500s had virtually all of Mesoamerica under its crown. Spain in game will maybe have the Caribbean and maybe half of Mexico.

Missions are annoying and overly scripted and just become overpowered. Playing a country with not missions is so sluggish and rugged compared to ones with them, creating a very clear game of favorite with Paradox. 

The game punishes you for doing well via Coalitions, which are completely untouched from their original conception 11 years ago. The Napoleonic Wars were literally coalition wars, where Napoleon divided and conquered each coalition member specifically. This is mechanically impossible in EU4, as you are unable to make separate peaces with coalition members. Coalitions force the player to sit idly, wasting finite time the game has to offer as the end date is 1821, with a braindead "coalition" that has virtually zero options to negotiate with or appease via diplomacy, other than just "improving relations." Boring boring boring.

RNG. Decisive, era-defining battles are often just decided by a literal die-roll. Yes, really. There's even a little picture of a game dice to symbolize this. RNG RNG RNG, RNG Emperor dies, RNG lose stability, RNG go into debt, RNG, lose umpteen thousand manpower, RNG regency council, forcing years of boring idleness. This does not simulate the turbulent, difficult nature of ruling a nation, but an annoying computer mechanic that feels more like a headache than a challenge.

All in all, EU4 is a great strategy game, but after about a thousand hours in it, I can't really recommend it. It's a terrible timesink that has extremely unfair and random-generated mechanics, followed by a seriously criminal DLC policy.

After roughly 3500 total hours in Paradox map games, I'm ready to say, this is the hardest one. By comparison to Vic II, III, HOI4, CK3, and Imperator, this one requires the steepest learning curve and largest buy in. Despite this however, this game is without any doubt one of the most dynamic and interesting of the main timeline Paradox map games. The sheer scale of innovation that takes place throughout a playthrough in this game is truly unlike any other paradox game I have played. The transition from feudal nations to the discovery of the new world makes for in my opinion great worldbuilding, leaving this to be a hugely replayable game! Overall, if you enjoy paradox games and have the time and money, this is definitely a must have, otherwise it might not be a good idea.

This is a great game, I certainly can't deny that. As many other reviewers have noted, however, the DLC is completely out of control. I'm not even going to complain about the price, because it's entirely possible to get most of it for 50 or even 75 percent off on sale. What deeply irritates me about the DLC is that the game is never complete. If I want to play the full, final, definitive version of a game like Civilization V, I only have to buy two DLCs. If I want to play the full, final, definitive version of Battlefield 1, I have to buy four DLCs, which is a little more expensive, but still doable. With this game, though, there will apparently never be an "ultimate" version of the game, since there is no end in sight for DLC releases. Playing a game that completely changes every 6 months is deeply frustrating, since I don't have unlimited time to learn every feature of every new release. I'm glad I own the game, but I can't recommend buying it for that reason.

Steam tells me I've played an additional 500 hours, so here's an update. The DLC situation has not improved. All the packs after Rights of Man have been either a) minor tweaks to countries that were already fully fleshed out, or b) absurd power fantasies that take the game even further away from an alternate history simulator. There were also a couple of catastrophically buggy releases, although at least those seem to have been fixed at this point. I can't seem to stop playing it, but you shouldn't start.

Meh, it's fun sometimes but I never feel like anything I did was challenging or worthwhile. It takes a while to know what all the mechanics do, but it's all just an clever abstraction to make you feel like you're leading this empire, but really it's just map painting with some extra steps. The game could probably eliminate several mechanics and you'd be doing the same exact thing but with less clicking. Also, once you know what you're doing, there's very little chance you will struggle, except for maybe the first 10-30 years. After that, there's hardly any doubt that you'll win, it's only about how fast you want to win.

Not really my thing, but if you're into map painters, then you'll probably like it.

Update: 12/2023

It's still an awesome game, the publisher kind of addressed the DLC-issue but I still can't recommend in good faith that you buy this game.

First: DO NOT BUY THE BASE GAME alone. Except if it's for MP purposes to play in lobbys where somebody else has multiple or all expansions. The base game alone is NOT PLAYABLE in SP.

Second: I gave the starter pack a look. Sorry! Not worth the money. You essentially pay full price to get the game as it was multiple years ago.

Ultimate pack: 300 bucks for a game and it doesn't even include the last DLC. LOL.
You can buy and get so much more and better for 300 bucks.

The prestige pack. Well... I'm with this game since more then 10 years. I've spent hundreds of Euro's on this game over those years. If they don't feel that they can't just give me some unit sprites or some more music with the expansions I payed for, I won't buy them separately. And yes, as a good and reliable customer I'm VERY miffed about what feels like their try to nickel and dime me. My goodwill as a customer with this company is as good as gone. 

From experience I can say: the best way to start with EUIV are humblebundles. Wait for one of those. 

And... be well aware that this game is on its way out. EUV isn't announced, yet. But that's just a matter of time. Spending 300 bucks, or 80 bucks, or even 50 bucks on a game with a successor well on the horizon seems... unwise to me.
But you do you of course.

All in all: good to great game, but not worth the asking price... by a long shot. So NOT recommend.

A kind of fun game. The game is a time-suck, so divide hours played by 10 to see the equivalent hours for a FPS or RPG game. A sequel is long overdue, and the DLC onslaught encourages life on the high seas. There are a lot of bugs which are fixed every year, only for more bugs to be created/revealed a few years later. The gameplay can be fairly satisfying when you see yourself grow more and more powerful over the decades/centuries and looking back where you came from is very inspirational, but this eventually goes too far and you fall into the hegemony status of being unable to lose, and then the game loses it's challenge and thus fun. I look forward to Europa Universalis V.

I just want to comment on the spectacular amount of DLCs.

The base game is going to give you a pretty good idea what the full DLC experience is, and if it is on sale, you can very cheaply try it out. There are some key Quality of Life improvements that are in DLC's, but they are not really needed at the beginning of the game - and games are very long, and I quite often restart.

The subscription is the best way to get an overview of what they offer (which I have). I might drop the subscription and cut back to a few core DLCs, most of which are in the Steam beginner bundle. If the bundle is on sale (and they have sales every couple months), the base game and those core DLCs are pretty cheap. A lot of the DLCs are adding content for "non-core" countries, and so are somewhat optional if you do not want to play them.

I was very sceptical at first: tiny letters in an overcomplicated UI… when scaled to a 2K monitor, everything became horribly blurry…  and yet I was attracted to the complexity of the game and the historically detailed map the game offers.
Luckily, there are graphical mods to fix the UI and then the ride begins. I then spent dozens of hours playing the game, restarting my campaign several times because of one dumb mistake after another... but hey, every time I play, my campaign takes longer and my nation is stronger. Right now it’s my seventh-or-so game and I am half-way through the campaign (in the mid 1600s). It feels like I am going to finish that 400-year span after all!
It's a very niche genre, probably not for casual gamers, but if you liked Civilization and preferred world maps to randomly generated worlds, if you like spreadsheets, if you like history and political geography… this game is definitely for you.

And this is the first game in which I had to launch a youtube tutorial just to finish the in-game tutorial.


+ historically accurate, conquerable map
+ you learn more about history than you did in your school classes
+ infinite replayability: even if you start in the same year with the same nation, the countries around you develop differently every time

- the game does not officially support bigger monitors than HD
- too Europe-centric (and I am saying this as a European)
- 40+ DLCs to buy is a travesty

"Europa Universalis IV" is a grand strategy game that stands out as a shining example of its genre, and my experience has been significantly enhanced by the addition of its major DLCs. Each expansion not only adds to the depth and complexity of the game but also enriches the overall gameplay experience in unique and meaningful ways.

The core game itself is a marvel of strategic depth, offering an unparalleled canvas for historical simulation. You can lead any nation from the late Middle Ages through the early modern period, shaping their political, diplomatic, and military course through centuries. The level of detail in nation-building, diplomacy, and warfare is astounding, providing a deeply immersive and intellectually stimulating experience.

What truly elevates the game, however, are the major DLCs. Each one brings new layers of strategy and historical detail. For instance, 'Art of War' greatly expands on the military aspect, allowing for more nuanced war strategies and peace negotiations. 'Common Sense' enhances the internal development of your nation, giving more control over subjects and provinces. 'Rights of Man' adds greater depth to the personalities of rulers and leaders, making the political landscape more dynamic.

The expansions also add a wealth of new content, from new nations and cultures to unique events and mechanics, making each playthrough feel fresh and exciting. The historical authenticity in each DLC is impressive, showing a dedication to not only entertaining but also educating players about different periods and aspects of world history.

Graphically, the game is clean and functional, with a user interface that, while complex, becomes intuitive over time. The in-game map is a work of art, and watching your nation grow and evolve over centuries is a visual treat.

In summary, "Europa Universalis IV" with its major DLCs is a must-play for anyone interested in history and strategy. The depth and breadth of content available make it a game that can be revisited time and time again, each playthrough offering a new and exciting journey through the annals of history. As a strategy game enthusiast, I can confidently say that it represents the pinnacle of the genre.

While Europa Universalis IV may offer a rich and immersive gameplay experience, criticism arises from the fact that Paradox locks crucial mechanics behind paid DLCs. This decision restricts access to essential features, creating frustration and limiting the overall enjoyment for players who cannot afford or choose not to invest in additional content, detracting from the game's potential.
This business model of locking essential mechanics behind paid DLCs has been a point of contention within the gaming community, as it can create a perceived imbalance between players who have purchased the DLCs and those who haven't. Some argue that these mechanics should be included in the base game or made available through free updates to ensure a fair and cohesive gameplay experience for all players. Nonetheless, Europa Universalis IV continues to be a beloved game for many, despite the frustration caused by this monetization strategy.

At best, these games are a real, strategic challenge where every victory feels earned. At worst, they're infinite optimisation modellers and progress bar tinkerers - equally boring as they are mysteriously addictive.

There's a lot to play with here, plenty to learn and all kinds of different civilisations with their unique difficulties and missions to try. One could get away with arguing that the push and pull of diplomacy here is yet to be bested.

But at some point, you'll notice the dry rawness of your eyes, find it's 3am on a workday and struggle to conclude whether you're engaged in the challenge or the eking out of 5% higher monthly income. Engage with caution and note the prevalence of 2000+ hour playtimes with the full cosmic terror they deserve.

Cautiously recommended - big plus for all the history and geography you can't help but learn. Buy on sale + get the subscription.

One of my favorite strategy games of all time. It combines economic management, military tactics, diplomacy, and politics alongside pretty good opportunities to role-play for a strategy game. Now these mechanics are not as deep as compared to a game that specializes in it, but the combination always gives you something to tweak and look forward to.

The long term support is a double edged sword. This game has lasted over a decade, and has spawned many incredible mods like Extended Timeline, Anbennar, MEIOU and Taxes etc, but the DLC situation is confusing. Some DLC has core features (some of which has been integrated into the vanilla game), and the total cost of it is daunting.

The UI feels dated but is proficient at displaying what you need to see fairly easily, and the game provides tons of information if you know where to look. The mechanics are satisfying to learn. The unique situations many countries face are fun to play.

Overall, it's fun to play and to learn some novel history from the missions and events the game provides.

Great game. As with all other paradox games, it has a steep learning curve. Great game overall. 

EDIT: 650 hours after I first wrote this, it has become my most played paradox game. Genuinely a great game.

I now have over 1,000 hours in this game, so yeah I recommend it. Taken like two years for me to buy a majority of the DLC, I just pick them up for 50% off on sales when I have the money/want one, because there are so many. 

For new players looking to get DLC I'd suggest Art of War (ability to transfer occupied provinces in war to allies), Common Sense (to develop provinces, very much needed outside of Europe with institutions), Rights of Man (For consorts, great powers etc) and Mandate of Heaven (for age bonuses and leader traits). I'm starting to pick up the ones I don't care for too, like Mare Nostrum and the Cossacks when I have the money so I can eventually get the achievements for those DLC too. 

Speaking of achievements... I need to get on that.

EDIT 4/21/2020: You can transfer occupied provinces and develop provinces in the base game now.

Edit 11/25/2023: Haven't played in a while but editing my review for the steam awards badge. I have 1990 hours in EU4.

So, I finally feel like I have enough experience to write a review for EUIV. As someone leaving the beginner ranks and reaching the average player status I can tell you that this game is a must for grand strategy players.



My lack of playtime - *clears throat* - is a result of the bad side of EUIV. Currently, Paradox has a - to put in lighter terms - bad DLC policy. Old DLCs rarely get cheaper and at their launch, the game gets free updates which alter the game slightly. But in the end, you get a beast of horrendous formation which leaves a sour aftertaste. Truly, it's great that Paradox offers the free updates and most DLC are rich in content, and are what makes this 2013 game to still get so much love. So, what I mean is, most DLCs are a must, and starting the game without them means a very poor experience compared to what it should have been.


But the good side of the game is that it gives you so much fun. Be it just roleplaying as any nation in 1444 or creating an ahistorical catholic Ottoman Empire or a Chinese speaking New World. There is so much fun to be had by the little things. Each DLC, usually, brings so much flavor to a specific culture/region that you end up interested in playing Lithuania for the 10th time so you get everything right (you know, beat the Russians, remove the Turks from Europe and dismantle the Holy Roman Empire).



If you are in doubt, don't download the demo. It doesn't give you any useful insight. Go to YouTube and watch someone play. You probably like the game better doing it anyway.


2020-05-11 Update: This game will receive a huge DLC + free update within this year. It will be the biggest one yet and it seems it will be a very good one. However, if you have yet to buy the game, the amount of DLCs will scare you. Previously, I suggested a different set of DLCs, but recently, Paradox has merged some content into other DLCs and I feel like I should update what you should buy with the base game.

Art of War: Some time ago, Paradox merged transfer of control to base game (thankfully), making this DLC a little less valuable. However, it is still essential. It adds a lot of war related mechanics that makes your life easier and wars more enjoyable, and should I tell you, wars are where you will spend most of your time. It also makes the game a bit more dynamic with the league wars and spicing up the revolution.

Either Conquest of Paradise or El Dorado: There will be a time you will be playing a subject nation or maybe wanting to screw up your rival and help their subject on a quest for their independence (you know, divide and conquer) but the damned button for support of independence won't be there because you didn't buy one of these DLCs.


If you are not satisfied spending on the DLCs above or wanna buy more DLCs after playing for a while:

Common Sense: Before, it had the most valuable mechanic hidden behind this play wall, but thankfully Paradox merged Province Development into the base game, so it isn't as much of an important DLC as it once was. But, it still has a lot of good improvements and makes handling vassals such a breeze that you will start to use vassals to expand because it’s better then taking that Berber province yourself. Seriously.

Dharma: There is a caveat. It focuses on India. If you are interested in playing there, it will be great. It also adds a very cool system for government reforms. So enjoy it.

Cradle of Civilization: It adds some cool features such as army professionalism and trade policies while improving the Middle East. Cool stuff.



That's it. Don't rush DLCs. Buy after playing for a while and enjoy what you can. Eventually, if you, like me, play enough to not be a joke amongst the community by putting a few hours on the game, you will, for sure, buy them all. However, I feel obligated to remember you to only buy old stuff on sale. This game is old and Paradox expects you to pay more than GTA V at full price. Recently launched DLCs buy at your discretion, though.

In the past I have begrudgingly given the game a negative review not so much for its content, which was always in-depth and engaging, but for the DLC policy the company pursued, where to get the full experience of the game, a newcomer would have to invest non-insignificant amount of money or wait for sales/price decreases. This put newcomer into an awkward position, to either shell out the whole sum at once, risking it all, hoping that you will like the game (which requires much more to lear than the 2 hours of game time the refund policy would allow), or buy just the base game and try to measure your interest based on an incomplete experience.

Now however, with the introduction of the subscription option (as contentious as the idea of games as a service may be), there is a third path that may be much more palatable of newcomers,  where for the price of 1/51 of that of all mechanic-related DLCs (subject to regional pricing, this particular calculation was made in rubles) the player can get to experience the full game for a month. This gives a much simpler entry point to the game and leave those who did not like the game less disappointed, and those who did like it with a choice, to either continue paying the subscription, or start buying the DLCs. And while from consumer’s point of view, I would have much preferred old DLCs to be slowly, but fully merged into the base game, from the business standpoint I perfectly understand the rationale and the compromise made. 

All in all, the game is in better state than it has been in a while, the content keeps coming and now there are actual paths for new players to enter the game and try it out without bankrupting themselves in the process.

This is a huge game. Take control of any nation in the world that existed in 1444 and try to survive until 1821. It may be tough to learn exactly how to play the game, but keep trying until you win.
The best and worst part of this game is the scale and details. The good part is that the game feels epic and realistic, and that it gives you full control. The downside is that it is hard to learn how to play and it takes a long time to complete a playthrough.
One important thing to note is that the game has a whole bunch of DLCs, and the more you have the better the game experience. However, a new player may want to check out the subscription that unlocks all DLCs for a monthly fee that can be cancelled at eny time. This gives you access to all DLCs, and if you are only going to play for a few months it saves a lot of money.

One of my all-time most played games, and yet compared to many others, I am but a beginner - it's depth can a little intimidating at first, but well worth it.

You play as a country, and lead it to glory or defeat. But some nations start as far more powerful than others, and so while you can go on large conquering sprees with some nations, as others you need clever leadership and diplomacy just to survive.

It can be very satisfying bringing your nation to greatness, and some of the achievements present very interesting challenges. It can get a little annoying with some mechanics locked behind DLCs, and one problem I often find is later in the game, you often can get to a point where there is little challenge left.
It's a great game, but I really need to get outside more often.

EU4 is considered a grand strategy game and obviously is the 4th in the Europa Universalis series. Gameplay consists of you leading one of many different nations through 300+ years of history or 300+ years of alternate history.  The game is played in real time and can be paused, speed up, etc. You have a wealth of choices to manage your nation from they type of religion, your economy, buildings, what type of national idea groups you want to choose for your nation, government reforms, some nations have extensive mission trees depending on the DLC you have, and much much more. There is also a ton of events to keep you busy in between all the fighting and killing.

As of right now I have all the DLC with the exception of just a couple. I have played this game over 2000+ hours and plan on playing it even more as I like to go for different achievements and I like to play many different nations. I know many people do not like Paradox's current DLC policy/pricing is nonsensical, but most of the DLC do add a lot to the game. After buying the first few DLC full price, I have decided to just wait until there is a sale either on steam, greenman, or humble for the DLC. The way I approach the DLC from Paradox is that no matter what they bring out, it is guaranteed to be 50% or more then whatever they are asking. That is how I approach it and that satisfies me pretty well. It does not take long at all after release of their DLC when it goes on sale, especially from the sites I had mentioned earlier. 

If you love grand strategy games then this game is probably for you. If you are new to the game I would wait until there is a big mega sale to grab the base game and as many of the DLCs to get the biggest bang for your buck and watch plenty of youtube regarding the game before you decide to spend money on the game. The last and greatest thing about this game is the wealth of mods that the community has put out, some being complete overhauls, others smaller in scope. The mods alone can net you even more fun out of an already great game. This game is a highly recommend after all these years.

The best strategies for all time

Rewriting and experiencing an alternate history has always been a fun concept to me.
With EU IV you can relive the rise of your nation or, depending on your preferences, create your own legacy by forming a customized nation. 

Of course said rewriting needs its own strategy, which will require you to nail it down to the ground, otherwise you might run into Mother Russia or the Kebab hailing from the Bosporus who both will happily take care of you. That said, once you know your ways around certain (historically accurate) events you will eventually reign superior to any AI, but that's a long and possibly expensive way.

You might ask yourself why it should be expensive to train your skills in EU IV as you could just study a strategy by watching some informative clips on Youtube. I urge you to have a look at the long list of DLCs to this game. If you are no stranger to other Paradox Interactive games, i.e. Crusader Kings or Hearts of Iron, it won't surprise you that there are a bunch of core features or useful content only available via paying extra. 

Still, as you certainly noticed, I recommend this game, that's because the experience this game creates for you is fulfilling, imagine yourself as the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire as Austria with Bohemia and Hungary as your loyal subjects. Fighting your way up is the goal as it will always be. The game's challenge lies in mastering its many mechanics wanting to prevent you from ultimate success. At least some of the most painful ones only trigger if you've actively paid for them.

With that I wish you a pleasant journey aboard the sandbox that contains Europe and the Rest of the World.

As so many people have mentioned before, it is a shame that there is no middle ground when recommending the game. I've played 2774 hours, and finished many campaign as the top world power, which clearly states that I have had a good time in this game...but, there is always a 'but'

I hate to say it, but I am thoroughly done with it; I cannot put myself to playing another campaign.

The Whack-a-mole chasing after enemy armies, the besieging of forts (I take down one while the enemy takes down 4 in the same time), how useless allies are (Vassals work fine) and how fast nations like Portugal and Spain colonise have ruined it for me. The game has become unbelievably frustrating for me to play. 
I find it wrong that Castles prevent movement, which it doesn't do well anyway because enemies can siege down forts within 'weeks' and pour into your hinterlands anyway......In my opinion Castles should prevent occupation.

Despite the massive amount of hours I have invested in the game, I cannot say I am a 'pro'; never touched Iron Man, to much RNG going on (yes, I feel forced to savescum a lot), and I just about managed to play the game on 'Normal' (which oddly enough is easier than 'Easy')

This may be the best entry-level game in the grand strategy genre. It is extraordinarily replayable, engrossing, and vast.

The problem I have with EU4 is that many decisions that should be synergistic or complimentary are mutually exclusive or harmful to each other. This abstraction of resources make EU4 play more so like a board game than like a simulation or an accurate model.

Yet all this being said, it does bear repeating that EU4 is extraordinary. It's a wonderful strategy game and I recommend it highly.

This is a great game, and as the hours played shows that I've spent an unhealthy amount of time playing it. But I simply can't recommend buying it besides during a 75% sale. 

Because while it is a nice game, it is also the best example of Paradox's disgusting policy of turning elements that really should be in the original game into expensive dlc's that are released soon after the main game.

The game itself isn't worth its price, but including the DLC elements that really should be ingame (at the very least Art of War, Rights of Man, Common Sense and El Dorado) it would be. 

So, if possible get it at a 75% sale with the DLCs more relevant to your prefered play style (economic, sea-focused, administrative/diplomacy, etc). Otherwise, not worth the price.

Europa Universalis is a grand strategy game from the developers, who pretty much have a monopoly on the genre at this point. You can change the course of history and lead your country into prosperity or decay within the limits of the game's mechanics. You can be a dominant military power, a colonial empire, a prosperous trading giant, and so on. There's a wide selection of countries with unique bonuses and missions that make each playthrough feel unique. It's important to use your imagination, however, to visualize the abstract elements of the game, such as battles that are played out in numbers with different modifiers and dice rolls.

Used to love this game but now I can't stand it anymore. It's me against the AI and it doesn't follow the same rules as I do

- The AI cheats constantly (No FOW, lucky nations, rolls better than you, no naval attrition, infinite monarch points / ducats)
- Allies don't do anything
- The economy was nerfed at some point, can't even build to my force limit anymore.
- Endless negative events spawn rebels, lower stability, force loans, take mana, etc.
- Endless DLC and updates to wreck your save files
- Everyone bordering me has a great power ally (even OPMs) but if I was that nation they would all be hostile to me
- AI merc spams and will triple the size of their army
- AI will go out of its way to fuck with you ( Countries breaking alliances to rival you, refusing call to arms, ending wars the second you declare on them so they can focus on you)
- You can't take anything in peace deals but the AI can take your entire nation regardless of warscore, even if you reject the peace deal
- Coalitions are a player only mechanic. The AI will never form a coalition against an AI nation
- If the AI declares on you it's an instant game over since they cheat in wars and will declare on you again when the truce expires

As an avid strategy gamer, Europa Universalis IV (EU4) has undoubtedly become my go-to title for an immersive and intellectually stimulating gaming experience. Paradox Development Studio has crafted a masterpiece that stands as a testament to the grandeur of historical strategy gaming.

From the moment you delve into the rich tapestry of the 15th century, you are transported into a world where every decision has far-reaching consequences. The depth of gameplay is staggering, offering a level of complexity that allows for endless replayability. Whether you're leading a European powerhouse, a budding Asian dynasty, or a New World colonizer, the possibilities are as vast as the historical era itself.

The diplomatic system is a shining jewel in EU4's crown, providing a nuanced approach to alliances, rivalries, and negotiations. The intricate web of political relationships adds layers of complexity, making each game feel like a unique story unfolding before your eyes. The dynamic nature of the world keeps you on your toes, adapting to unforeseen challenges and opportunities.

The attention to detail in recreating historical events and the sheer accuracy of the map are commendable. The game's commitment to historical realism, coupled with the freedom it affords players to shape their own destinies, creates a perfect harmony between structured narrative and player agency.

The visual and auditory elements of EU4 are nothing short of exceptional. The map is beautifully rendered, and the attention to historical accuracy in unit design and cultural representation is evident. The soundtrack complements the gameplay seamlessly, enhancing the immersion and transporting players to different corners of the globe.

The extensive modding community adds an extra layer of longevity to the game. From total conversion mods to small tweaks, the modding community's creativity knows no bounds. This not only extends the game's lifespan but also ensures that each session can offer a new and exciting experience.

In conclusion, Europa Universalis IV is more than just a game; it's a journey through the annals of history, a canvas upon which players can paint their stories. Its combination of strategic depth, historical authenticity, and limitless possibilities make it a must-play for any fan of grand strategy games. EU4 stands as a true gem in the world of gaming, a testament to the genre's potential for both entertainment and enlightenment.

Europa Universalis IV is nothing short of a gaming masterpiece. While it may have a steep learning curve that demands dozens of hours to master, don't let that discourage you. Once you dive into this historical grand strategy gem, you'll find it impossible to tear yourself away.

The initial moments of the game, whether you're leading the mighty Ottoman Empire or the modest Candar, set the stage for an addictive experience. It's not about constant frustration or getting your butt kicked every playthrough; it's more about the thrill of "I made it X years, what went wrong, and how can I do better next time?" And then, before you know it, ten hours have vanished, and you realize you should probably eat, call your parents, or let people know you're still alive.

Each victory and defeat becomes a part of your unique story, showcasing the sheer magnitude of this game's possibilities. Whether you're dealing with Leonardo Da Vinci or plotting total world domination from a remote island, the choices are endless. You can even trash-talk the world's strongest powers to their faces and somehow make their enemies love you and their allies adore you.

Europa Universalis IV's commitment to staying relevant with active DLCs over the years is commendable, even if the DLC policy could use some improvements. Despite any flaws, the game continues to evolve with a dedicated and passionate player base.

Playing this game will make you feel incredibly patriotic about some obscure, long-forgotten one-city nation that ceased to exist in 1445. You'll become a citizen of that nation in spirit, diving into Wikipedia rabbit holes to learn more about its history, all while loving every second of it.

If you enjoy dissecting complex systems, indulging in grand strategy, immersing yourself in history, flexing your problem-solving skills, and creating your own historical epics, then Europa Universalis IV is a must-play. It's worth every penny, and you'll find yourself lost in its immersive world for countless hours. Get ready to embark on a grand journey through history and craft your unique tales of conquest and diplomacy.

EU4 has the same issues as HOI4 and some more.

Firstly the developers are bad at game design great at graphics.
How dare I say this? Well let's see.

Achievements only in Ironman. Its a game, do not see how neckbearing is so cool. Get a life.

Ironman as a feature with a terrible UX.
Yes the game is excel with graphics, except this excel forgets to tell you fundamental relationships and you need ot know where to find the developer interface, because it has the only way to enable basic functions.
Initially you may be thinking you are the one making the mistake, but eventually it turns out there is only 1-2 ways out of the pickle you are put in (HOI4 - France; EU4 - Sweden). Given you are put into a backwards situation, with a clearly ineffective initial setup, you will lose... and lose... and then win wars but not be allowed to claim any lands so you lose. So you have to restart... Oh wait... but there is no restart button. So you quit to menu pick same nation load back in, do the same 1st turn setup for 20th time, because it clearly is the best option... and then you get shafted by a random number generator... and so on.

So basically you have to save scum the game with intersting nations but save scumming is made longer, because the devs are bad at their jobs. Yes ironman needs a restart button, if you think quit restart is a good solution you probably love the Rings of Power as well. I.e. you are worng.

Favorite counter argument to the above "but its realistic game bruv". No it isnt, I never got beheaded IRL for rising against Denmark so it clearly has nothing to do with reality. It is a game, and a game should have a UX that serves the user experience instead of wasting their time.

EU4 was a very nice game that has suffered from continuous DLC development that changes the base game. The breaking point for me was when developing your provinces, an integral part of base gameplay, was reworked and put behind a paywall wih the DLC "Common Sense."  With the AI retaining the ability to develop its provinces normally, only the player's country remains a medieval backwater, unless you pay for the privilege. 

After hundreds of hours already in the game, it left a sour feeling to be asked to pay money to retain features that had already been present. The level of chrome and updates the game has received since release are alright if you own the DLC, but largely to the detriment of players who own only the base game.

Edit: More than five years and hundreds of hours of game time later, it is no longer fair to keep the review at negative as the development problem with Common Sense was specifically removed, and the subscription system makes the (enormous amount of) DLC more accessible for someone who has only the base game. The base game itself remaining empty by comparison is probably still true, but at least you are no longer as actively penalized for not buying key DLC.

I am still enjoying this game after playing with the latest expansions, many years after I first bought it. I didn't play it much after release as like all Paradox games they are a bit boring for the first few years, they don't come into their own until they have been filled out with several years of dlc.

The gameplay does vary quite a bit depending on what country you pick, it's size, and cultural type etc. There is a lot of replayability. Yes the mechencics remain roughly the same but the missions and events will change from faction to faction. The main enjoyment comes from playing the different countries and cultures, and a lot of the depth comes from all the dlc. They flavour the game with music, units, missions, events and the like. It is an interesting semi-historical game, probably the best game Paradox have ever made. This game you get will last you years, providing endless historical strategy gameplay that is deep and fulfilling. 

The game revolves around developing your country and culture around the time of the Renaissance and usually expanding. Like all the Paradox games the fun comes from the interplay of factors. If you capture a new province for example you will get rebels rising. Because you have been in a war you might have no money to support an army, and your people might be displeased and your neighbours worried by your aggressive expansion. This will mean you have to take steps to placate the rebels, stabilise your country, whilst building up your money reserves, whilst also being aware you maybe weak to enemy attack. There are also religious factions to consider, not to mention estates in your country to keep balanced, diplomatic relations, navy and army, trade, province development and many many other elements to consider. It can take a long time to figure out the complexity of the game mechanics. 

The only thing you cannot really do with these Paradox games is play them without any dlc, because then they are very bland. If you are not prepared to outlay a lot of money for the dlc one way or another do not even consider getting this game. Unfortunately the dlc is expensive and numerous, because the game covers several centuries of world wide historical development.

You may be able to restrict your dlc purchasing to one culture or country type, for example a major like France, or an Arab nation etc. That would make a lot of sense. Buying the dlc gradually in sales will still be expensive costing £100s for the whole lot. Or use the subscription for a few months.

You might want to also look at Imperator Rome, Crusader Kings, Victoria and Hearts of Iron which all cover other parts of mankind's history. They all roughly follow the same principles but they also all vary slightly in the exact mechanics of gameplay. Some of those may appeal more or less than The Renaissance featured here. Although I think this game is the pinnacle of Paradox I do not think they will ever do a better game than this one. CK features more intrigue, HoI features combat far more heavily, IR features more families, whilst Vic concentrates on industry and population. This game concentrates most on making an empire. So look carefully at each to see which will appeal.

Addictive gameplay that has you clamoring for another run. DLC model could be tweaked to a more user friendly state, but the $5 subscription pass is good to have until you can catch dlc on sale. Never truly boring when you can switch up regions and cultures. 8/10 would recommend

Now that I've put some hours into this game, I must say that I like this game a little.

I'll start by saying that this game is good, I wouldn't have wasted 400+ hours on it otherwise, however at that same time, this game isn't good, yes that is oxymoronic, but hear me it.

EU4 is great, I love playing the game and I love painting the map my colour, but all of this is ruined by what the dev team considers "balancing", such as the unfair buffing of superpowers and the horrible AI mechanics.

To be more in depth about what I mean, the dev team have placed a system in EU4 called "lucky nations", which are given to giant superpowers like France, The Ottomans, Austria etc. This gives these nations unfair buffs to fighting in battles, their siege abilities and their siege defence, among other things.
This is supposedly implemented to maintain a balance of power in the game, but I think that's a ridiculous notion. It results in often all EU4 games ending up the same, with the same superpowers often triumphing over everyone else.
It forces players to play some form of meta so they can progress. some people are complicit with this saying it's necessary for there to be consistent superpowers, but even without lucky nations these same superpowers would still hold a considerable amount of power.
This isn't helped with the coupling of horrible AI mechanics which I feel are designed to target the player and generally make their experience unfun.

It feels like every game that AI superpowers are specifically going out of their way to hinder me for no realistic reason other than to make the game more difficult. Often will I see large superpowers allying with minor nations that are a part of my mission tree and therefore stunting my growth.
Allies will often make horrible decisions in wars for no particular reason, this has often been game ending, allies will also make horrible decisions outside of wars, choosing to ally nations that they know you have claims on.
Finally I often can't count on my superpower allies as for some reason, EU4 AI is completely incapable of handling their economies, I haven't seen a game where France isn't somehow 1000 ducats in debt or where The Ottomans isn't some grossly more ludicrous amount in debt.

If the price tag attached to this game isn't convincing enough that you probably don't want to get into this game, then this should be. Paradox manage to consistently create good games that fall short as a result of easily fixable issues.

I love this game, and I want to recommend it but like many others the problem is the DLC. I like the DLCs and if there were 2 or 3 that would be fine, but every month or two they make you shell out ~$20 for stuff they should give for free. The only thing in DLC I could think of that should stay DLC is the random new world mechanic. I would recommend this game if they changed the way DLC worked, maybe half the price, or keep the price and release less often, because right now they give you half a patch and make you pay 1/3 of the original game to get the other half.

1/30/20 - Years later, same problems with DLC. Paradox has said they are working on a fix for massive DLC costs though. Still a good game nonetheless and a wonderful time sink as you can see. My 2300 hours in this game were all enjoyable.

10/25/23 - A few years later still and finally the community's voice has been heard. The move to a subscription model is beneficial to new players and to Paradox surely. Is it a perfect solution? No, but I'm glad that I can finally recommend the game to friends without also recommending they take out a personal loan. My only wish now is that they would make a new game with an updated engine that is more optimized, allow more graphical options, and allow quitting to menu without restarting the game, better fullscreen windowed. All these gripes are minimal in comparison though. I'm glad to say that I can finally recommend EUIV.

Horrible company that largely releases "flavor packs" for $20, adding to the game what modders do for free. Half of their recent DLC's are to add missions and events to various nations, you know, stuff that should be in the base game, but instead they sell it for $20. Modders do this for free, and often do it years before paradox even thinks of doing it themselves. You want a good "flavor pack" that does everything paradox flavor pack dlc's do? Go use missions expanded, great mod. Paradox business model is to release an unfinished product, and then over time release over-priced DLCs to slowly finish the product, forcing people to pay exorbitant amounts of money to get the finished game which they were owed when they originally purchased the game. Paradox has some of the scummies business practices out there, horrid company.

This game has consumed my life help. Now in all seriousness this is probably my favorite game ever. There is a reason its my most played game. It's endlessly repayable, fun as hell, and satisfying to take some OPM to the greatest power in the world. But I would not call EU4 a masterpiece, there are several issues with it. First, I can't talk about the game without mentioning Paradox's shitty DLC policy (Even though I am a hypocrite cause I keep buying them). But in terms of game play there are some major frustrations. The A.I is often incompetent, and it can make certain strategies that rely on them impossible (Try using allies when there in 10K in debt). And the UI is truly magical in how much it sucks, it is impossible to find buttons if your new to the game. Combine that with the classic strategy of explaining nothing, and you have an experience that will bounce half of all new players right off your game. The learning curve of EU4 is a sheer wall of ice that you have to climb up with kitchen utensils. But once you are past the wall, it is the most fun you will have in a game, with a gameplay loop more addicting than fentanyl.
