My review is based upon playing  sandbox games with smaller nations such as the duchies "Brittany" and some of the northern Germanic principalities. Although i am aware that the bigger countries are an easier experience, I have little interest in selecting one; for in agreement with others, i  enjoy starting small and expanding. 

From the perspective of playing as duchies the game is very slow. Aggressive expansion is a negative modifier that restricts your ability to expand, This maybe a useful mechanic for the bigger countries, in order to prevent you snow balling and thus quickly ending the game.  As it relates to the smaller countries though it drastically frustrates ones ability to play the game. I managed to take two provinces with Brittany by the reformation and by that point England and France had three times the troops i had. Their was little i could do but wait and hope for a opportunity to present itself in order to grow. Perhaps they should modify Aggresive Expansion so smaller duchies dont get so heavily effected by it. 

As such my game basically became a waiting one, whereby i increased the diplomatic reputation with England to protect me from a hungry looking France who wanted my lands. Sitting with the speed on full, until i could do something became very boring. 

When an opportunity did present itself to do something, for France had been at war so its army was reduced, unfortunately England hadn't yet gained 10 trust from me so i couldn't bring them into a potential war. So with nothing else to be done, more waiting ensued. Whilst i waited i was bombarded with decisions that never seemed to have any positive effect, always a lesser of two evils sort of choice. So after a long time waiting, and a constant stressful set of choices, do i reduce stability or loose prestige?, i found myself dazed from boredom and somewhat stressed.

Then when a war did start, the games entered supersonic mode,  the A.I with such speed headed straight for my units after presumably already calculating it would win, before i had a chance to react i was dead. I saved scummed as it is commonly refereed to,. raised my force maintenance and this time got crushed because i rolled 3 0's from dice rolls. So re loaded again. and again and actually it took me 5 loads to just win one battle. Meanwhile England sort of marched around my battles not often engaging in them. So i re loaded until the did... More and more stress. Eventually when i won, and got one province, i felt no enjoyment or satisfaction. Just very stressed. 

In peace time you can mess about with policies trying to stack the same buff to give you a slightly different play style from the last sandbox game, taking into consideration your countries unique ideas. I like this concept allot actually, and after completing two idea groups you unlock a special politicise only available to countries that unlocked thous two particular idea groups. synergistic. Non the less though, the game is ultimately allying with strong countries, waiting to take 1 or 2 provinces, waiting then for your peace to run out so you can attack again. Whilst stress fully trying to pick the least awful decision that pops up.  Just surviving should feel like an achievement, but really it doesnt and i didnt get much enjoyment out of the game.

Is it expensive if you buy the game today at full price for everything? Yes. Buy DLC on sale and check which DLC's are worth it, alternatively play with a friend that has the DLC's as that's one feature that is amazing about Paradox's DLC policy, if the host has it you can play with it. Paradox's DLC's do seem expensive but it has kept the game still going and fresh after being released a decade ago with new features some free and paid that have changed how the game is played and keeps it fun.

Short example, just look at the changes over the past decade to the Catholic, Protestant and Reformed faith, changed so much from the initial release of the game from just being single stat benefits to dynamic faiths that reward each nation in different ways.

Europa Universalis IV offers countless hours of captivating gameplay, immersing players in the intricacies of world history and diplomacy. The depth of strategy and historical accuracy is commendable, making it a must-play for grand strategy enthusiasts.

However, a significant drawback is the overwhelming number of DLCs. Many essential features that should be part of the base game are locked behind paywalls, which can leave players feeling frustrated. Unfortunately, this is a common practice in Paradox Interactive games. Despite this drawback, Europa Universalis IV remains a captivating grand strategy experience for those willing to navigate the DLC maze.

Edit: I feel like I'm finaly grasping the basic concepts of the game. Play at your own risk. This game *WILL* suck life out of you and leave your mind scarred with the images of the Ottoman empire declaring war on you, the Byzantium, in November 1445. 

Anyway 9/10 would get my life sucked out of me again.

Edit 2: I'm now approaching 1500h in game. After every run (I always finish my games, so one campaign takes me about 40h to finish), I think to myself - hmm, this game is becoming a little repetitive. But then I fire it up again, and again and again. and in every single game, my thought of becoming a dominant force in the world gets fulfilled in another new way, even when playing countries I already played before. 

It's a masterpiece, a testament of labour of love (but also cash-grabbing). The brilliance of this game WILL survive the test of time and it will be forever a game that changed my entire view of the gaming industry.

An excellent exploration of historical ideas and time periods that has too steep a learning curve for new players and many teething issues that annoy long time players. Updates frequently add completely game breaking mechanics that then spend months being nerfed back down to reason. The game has changed so much since release it is almost unrecognisable. While this demonstrates the dev's commitment to the game, it also shows their lack of vision for the game's core mechanics. 

Something also has to be said regarding the game's euro-centric worldview. Why do all trade routes flow inexorably to either Genoa, Venice, or the English Channel? The devs have spent so much time making non-European nations unique to play as, and allowing interesting alt-history, why doesn't this extend to the realm of trade? Considering there were many mechanics like this upon release (technology groups, static province tax base, lack of new world nations, etc) that have since been amended, I'm forced to conclude that this is simply because they either haven't got around to trade yet, or the trade system is too complicated to fix while retaining the feel of the system. Furthermore, why is the printing press guaranteed to spawn in northern Germany? Why can't a Chinese, Indian, or American province develop it? While I understand part of this derives from an attempt to simulate "real world" history, it's at odds with the rest of the player-controlled alt history design philosophy the game has going. It also comes off as kind of racist. I'm not accusing anyone, but when an outsider looks in at the game's mechanics it's not a good look. 

Ideally what this game needs is a sequel EU5 with a stronger foundations rather than the current endless dlc model, but that doesn't appear to be in the pipeline any time soon

[DLW RATED 6.9 of 10 (7=passing)] LOL! While I'm sure this game is a dream come true for less than 1% of all gamers, this highly subjective review speaks to the nightmare. Set in the 1400's, E.U.IV is a Turn Based Conquest game, where nearly every potential form of global control or diplomacy come into play. In short, the world is divided, not into 25 or 100 territories, but more like 2000 and, moreover, this game will set users straight on what Micromanagement truly... truly... means. I have played my share of micro management games, and this curve is too involved to be fun to the vast majority of humans. Given the complexity (there's the word!) a tutorial where two Very Small countries go at it, would have been nice, with firm but gentle hand-holding. The beginning choices make this game akin to setting up a company as it's owner, then going to work as an employee, everyday, and not having a clue as to the consequences until God knows when. Or is it more like going to work, as an accountant, with no experience, for no pay? My guess is a he perfect YouTube vid for beginners would be best for getting one in the groove. UPSIDE: The game is colorful and artistically compelling. If you love intricate control and micromanagement beyond reason, look no further.  DOWNSIDE: Due to the complexity and work put in needed to "play", one must wonder if using "Game" to describe E.U.IV is an appropriate use of the word. --- THAT SAID: True, 81,000 have given their approval, but that's over a 10-year (2013) period. That reminded, I am still compelled by my first thought, it's a game appealing only to 1% of humanity. I'm sure they enjoy it, but an overall review must be geared to the many and not the one. Being intelligent or a well-rounded gamer isn't enough to enjoy this; more like patience, tolerance, and appreciation of pure scientific method (not to mention work ethic) are the characteristics needed for this game, so it's hard to recommend. I can't. I trust this review explains why I arrived at 6.9, as a rating.

Title: A Grand Strategy Masterpiece - Europa Universalis IV

Rating: ★★★★ (4/5)

Europa Universalis IV (EU4) is a testament to the grandeur of strategic gaming, offering an unparalleled experience in the realm of historical simulation. Paradox Development Studio has crafted a masterpiece that seamlessly blends meticulous attention to detail with accessible gameplay, providing a captivating journey through the annals of human history.

One of EU4's most impressive feats is its historical accuracy. From the sprawling map, encompassing every corner of the globe, to the intricately designed nations, cultures, and religions, every facet of the game oozes authenticity. This meticulous world-building allows players to delve into various epochs, experiencing the rise and fall of empires, the Age of Exploration, and the tumultuous events that shaped the modern world.

The depth of gameplay mechanics is staggering, offering layers of complexity that cater to both newcomers and seasoned strategists. The diplomatic system, for instance, allows for intricate alliances, royal marriages, and delicate balancing acts of power. Economic management is equally engrossing, requiring astute decisions on trade, taxation, and infrastructure development. The military aspect, while daunting at first, rewards careful planning and tactical prowess, with battles that feel like true tests of strategy.

EU4 also excels in providing a sense of agency. Players can choose any nation, big or small, and guide its destiny through the centuries. Whether it's steering the Ottoman Empire to world dominance, nurturing a fledgling colonial power, or attempting to unify fractured states in Europe, the possibilities are as vast as the historical canvas itself. The open-ended nature of the game encourages creativity and fosters a deep connection between the player and their chosen nation.

The game's dynamic events and missions further enrich the experience, providing historical context and objectives that help guide players through the centuries. These events add an element of unpredictability, ensuring that no two playthroughs are ever quite the same.

Moreover, EU4 boasts a dedicated modding community that has produced an array of user-generated content, extending the game's lifespan indefinitely. From total conversion mods to subtle tweaks, the sheer breadth of available content ensures that players can continually find new challenges and experiences.

While the learning curve may appear steep, the game's well-crafted tutorials and an active online community provide ample support for those willing to invest the time. Furthermore, the UI, though initially overwhelming, becomes intuitive with familiarity, allowing players to focus on the grand strategic decisions at hand.

In conclusion, Europa Universalis IV stands as a titan in the grand strategy genre, offering an immersive, educational, and endlessly replayable experience. Its attention to detail, historical accuracy, and deep gameplay mechanics make it a must-play for anyone with an interest in history or strategy games. For those willing to embark on this grand journey, the rewards are boundless

"The game is fun" and "I would recommend this game to others" are two separate sentiments that [i]almost[/i] always overlap.

I started playing back in April of 2015 (yikes), and there is no game that I (as of writing, but I doubt it'll ever change) have more hours in than EU4.  I still have fun, but the experience is so mired in complexity that I wouldn't recommend most try it out.

Coaching another person on how to play this game in summer 2022 gave me some perspective.  He had significant experience in other Paradox grand strategies.  Yet, in trying to teach the game, I realized just how horrifically confusing it is to newcomers.  If somebody who already had experience with HOI 4 and Stellaris had a hard time grasping the gameplay, who wouldn't?

Unless you're incredibly driven, and willing to watch guides and tutorials, only to play ~100 hours where you're awful, followed by another ~100 hours where you're mediocre, then don't bother.  I have over 1k hours, and I barely understand how trade works.  If I have to consult a third party to understand how a core mechanic in a game functions after 45 real-life days spent playing, something's up.

...but the game [i]is[/i] fun, so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Greatest grand strategy I have ever played. It is unique in a sense that it somehow keeps things interesting throughout a 100 hour game, played with the same faction on the same map. Alliances form and dissolve, crises come and go, and you lead your country through its own path towards the victory through the hundreds of years.
For grand strategy with in depth long games this is definitely the way to go.

Great game for map painting and 4X fun. The gameplay goes very deep and I feel like every few hours I realise that I could have done something better as I get a better handle on all the systems. But you don't have to go extreme on your gameplay, micromanaging the hell out of your empire is not required to play the game, to have fun or to even be particularly good at it.

Definitely start with the base game and play a good few hours of it before you touch any DLC. The DLC adds a lot of more of the same, so it won't fix the game or make it enjoyable if you don't like it already.

10/10

Did this game take me five years to start to enjoy? Yes, but i probably only played 40 hours in those five years.
Does this game have a DLC approach that makes it difficult to get into and closer to subscription-based? Also yes.

But i come back to it over anything else, because there are plentiful goals, differing challenge levels, and most importantly, skill expression and mastery -- While my first four games struggled to make the powerhouse of Spain live up to its historical borders, subsequent runs had no problem converting that power into a world conquest, until eventually the systems mastery allowed me to (using the standard exploits) complete a world conquest as the tiny island of Ryukyu.  

Even now when I feel comfortable accomplishing any goal (with no meta-progression beyond my own aptitude) , the number of factors to consider en route to that goal makes me want to come back and solve the puzzle of how to accomplish a set of achievements quickly.  I have nearly 20000 hours in this game over the last ten years.  that's 22% of the maximum possible 87000.  (much of this time i left the game on idle, in honesty -- because i didn't see a point in shutting down and restarting the PC)

Not perfect by any stretch of imagination, but better than every other option i'm aware of.

10/10 Flaws and all

This game has offered me countless hours of fun. Wether Im doing a relaxed modded play through or a iron man-achievement run.  This game has near endless replayability with the different styles of play to every run. Mods only help expand this.  While the game can be expensive for new players, it is without a doubt a must buy if you enjoy strategy. 
It only gets better when you play with a group of friends, adding some personality to how a nation acts, allowing to use their dlc, and overall just more interesting plays.  

This is not to say the game is without flaws. Plenty of problems that shouldve been fixed week 1, such as the game crashes when exiting the SP screen or being unable to join a MP session from the start screen. Or things like Random new world saves being compressed every time you save, forcing you to play longer or save less often as the save will get janky  later on. Not to mention some weird plays by the AI.

An incredibly rich, complex and intricate game that is still evolving after a decade on the market. I've done practically everything you can do in EU IV twice at this point and I still find ways to entertain myself in single-player or with friends. Certainly my favorite game ever in spite of Paradox's infamous DLC policy, because of all the memories I've made across the years with friends. I hope that whenever EU V begins development, Paradox takes care to recognize this game's place as the undeniable flagship of the Paradox ecosystem, because of its venerability, quality and devoted playerbase. Happy late 10th birthday to Europa Universalis IV :)

The game is not in a good spot right now and there is not a lot of hope of PDX turning it around. What started out as a historical simulation about colonialism, the Protestant Reformation, and the French Revolution over the years has slowly creeped into something that feels like an overly-complicated game of Risk. 

Every country feels basically the same to play, and the only difference is the starting situation. Once you've gotten past the first hour of play you're unbeatable. It feels tedious. 

If that sounds appealing to you, then go ahead and buy it, but it doesn't feel like a grand-strategy game anymore.

I want to love this game. I really do. But the minutia is deep, deep, deep, and things don't work as I think they should. For some odd reason, though I have troops stationed inside coastal towns and ships outside those towns, pirates appear to be able to raid them at will, and apparently no one in this town has ever heard of water or a hammer, because they don't set out to stop the town from burning on their own, nor does there appear to be a mechanic that allows you to just say, "Put out the fires".

It's cool; the map is killer, and the whole idea is beyond cool, but with so little of it explained, it's just not for anyone who isn't married to it.

Huge learning curve for this game, but once you have the more basic functions down, it can be pretty fun. Unfortunately, a lot of the best content (ex. creating Custom Nations) is locked behind a pay wall, but the base game does provide enough content to have a multitude of different gameplay experiences. If you enjoy looking at spreadsheets for hours on end, this game is for you.

If you're a glutton for punishment and enjoy diving headfirst into the abyss of unnecessarily complex grand strategy games, then this might be your cup of bitter tea.

First, let's talk about the tutorials. Or should I say lack thereof? Who needs a clear, concise introduction when you can just decipher hieroglyphics and learn through the magic of trial, error, and wishing upon a star? I mean, who doesn't want to dedicate hours to deciphering tooltips that sound like they're written in an alien language?

And don't even get me started on the user interface. It's like the designers thought, "Hey, you know what would be fun? Let's throw all the information we can think of onto the screen and see how many players go cross-eyed trying to make sense of it." Trying to navigate through menus feels like attempting to solve a Rubik's Cube blindfolded – while juggling.

Sure, you could argue that historical accuracy is important, but who needs history when you can spend your days meticulously managing your economy like a virtual accountant and wondering why your neighbors are plotting against you in a language only they and the AI can understand?

Want to wage war? Well, prepare for a delightful dance of diplomatic entanglements that even Shakespeare would find convoluted. Forming alliances feels like asking for a favor in a corporate bureaucracy, and deciphering the AI's logic for declaring war involves a degree in advanced alien psychology.

But hey, if you're into games that require the same level of dedication and time as a full-time job without the financial benefits, then EU4 might be your calling. Just remember, when your friends ask where you've been for weeks, you can proudly tell them, "Oh, just trying to figure out how to maintain a positive stability rating while juggling the intricacies of religious conversion and trade power."

In summary, if you enjoy games that offer a steep learning curve, a UI designed by a madman, and the satisfaction of never quite grasping what's going on, EU4 is the masterpiece you've been waiting for.

It's a genuinely good game, but the price tag is a lie.
If you were to buy the game and all of its functional-content DLC at full price, that would cost about $300. 50% off sales are common, however the most essential DLC tend to be the most expensive, and when I call these DLC essential, I'm not kidding.
Playable natives? Conquest of Paradise.
Getting money from trade without being coastal? Wealth of nations. (Not so fun fact: when this DLC released, the transfer trade peace treaty option would break your game if you didn't have this DLC)
Make money as a merchant republic? Res Publica.
Declare war for your subject's land? Art of War. (Not so fun fact: This DLC used to be required to be able to give land to others)
Custom nations and functional New World? El Dorado.
Give your vassal land? Common sense.
Functional hordes? Cossacks.
Great power mechanics? Rights of Man.
Functional China, and automated diplomats? Mandate of Heaven.
Functional Islam, all of the professionalism mechanics, and half of the development mechanic? Cradle of Civilization.
Functional India, and 1/4 of all the bonuses you can get? Dharma.
Viable HRE and more convenient rebels? Emperor.
Favors system, Monuments, and army automization? Leviathan.
Hotel? Trivago.

All of the above do more than stated, and are likely undersold. They are the 13 particularly essential ones other than Mare Nostrum, which mostly just makes your life worse, other than taking advantage of Condottieri in Multiplayer. They're about $230 together. Also, the subscription service, is an obvious money grab looking to take advantage of people who aren't financially savvy, or otherwise can't afford the DLC.

Don't get me wrong, this game can definitely be fun in certain scenarios, but that's the issue, CERTAIN scenarios.

The easiest way to sum up EU4 is "When you're doing good, it's great! When you're doing bad, ughhhhh.."
This game has a steep learning curve, and the fact you are pretty much forced into buying the starter pack if you want mechanics that really should be in the base game already, makes the game frankly unenjoyable alot of the time. This issue is of course prevelant in all paradox games, but MAN it really shines trough in EU4! You get access to, what, 60% of mechanics trough DLC? You wanna play as a scandinavian state? Oh, well first you have to wait for a sale, and then cough up STILL 10 bucks for access to the content. I'll say that at least most of the DLC's in this game have content that justify the pricing (during sales), but it's still an idiotic, yet insanely profitable, way to sell a game.

I really want to enjoy this game, but even when I watch guides on how to play nations and copy their actions 1:1, I tend to simply lose because the guy making the guide had 10 more DLC's than me, so he has access to a bunch of mechanics I don't. I'm sure if I buy more DLC for this game I'll enjoy it more, but it's really a problem that you NEED to buy optional and extra content to enjoy the game at all.

Can be extremely fun, and addictive, but totally ruined by the RNG element. I do not recommend this game, the RNG element makes it totally nonredeemable, certainly without mods.

I have experience in other Paradox games, such as Hoi4 and so far "only" 15 hours in EU4. However, despite only having 15 hours, I consider that I have finally properly learned the game, with all its little intricacies and details you need to constantly pay attention to, and be able to have nice and enjoyable play throughs.

The role-playing element is fantastic, and so is the historical element. Overall, I find the game to deliver a really good and well made administration-simulation package which is very fun and addictive to play. However, as I said the rng ruins it. How can I be thrown in a game with one of the steepest learning curves of all big titles, and be punished for doing everything right?:

You can ensure that your kingdom is stable, everyone is loyal and happy, you have a good economy, and no war exhaustion, and all of a sudden, some randomly generated events trigger, a usurper shows up, and there are 4 separate armies ranging from 10-25k men all over your territory when you are low on manpower and have a standing army of 10k men. You fight them, go into so much debt that your country is sinking, so you start a new game: all of a sudden your neighbors have a completely different opinion of you, everyone has a different alliance and agreements, and you have a bunch of completely different rng events happening in the very same country you played with earlier.... 

Certain games, like Dark Souls, or Eldenring have very steep learning curves. But everything in the game pushes you to play in a better way, and constently rewards you for it. You are only ever punished for making mistakes. THAT is a GOOD game development. Throwing the player against a very long and steep learning curve, with a very inadequate tutorial, only for them to finally get a grip of the game after at least 10 hours only to punish them despite doing everything right is BAD game development.

Game itself is really fun, just a great RTS game for both single-player and multiplayer.  [b] But let us separate the art from the artist real quick. [/b]

The whole DLC situation is ludicrous. The fact that you have to pay hundreds of dollars just to get core mechanics that could have 100% just been included in the base game is insane. Even on sale the DLCs are not really that worth it. While I understand the devs might have put in a lot of time to create, test, and debug these mechanics. There's nothing anyone can say to justify paying the hundreds of dollars ($300-500 depending on sale) for some of these mechanics.

Sure you can try to say that maybe they just didn't think of these mechanics during the original development. However, it has been a full decade since release, and they could have easily spent all these DLC dev time making EU5 and add these "new" mechanics to it. You can do a lot in 10 years, such as making a new engine that doesn't force you to restart the game  every time you have go back to the starting menu. But oh no that means they can only charge a one time $60 dollar fee when they can otherwise charge you $450. Oh no the poor executives at Paradox. Shucks.

In the end, it's about money. Creative Assembly does it with Total War. Paradox does it consistently with most of their newer RTS games. [b] YES [/b] the game itself is amazing but also [b] YES [/b] Paradox really wants you to spend $15-20 so you can press a cool new button in the army tab. There's not much we as individuals can do about it. Voting with your wallet only really works if everyone comes to a consensus.

What I would recommend is checking Humble Bundle occasionally to see if they bring back the EU4 bundle. Not only do you help charities but you also don't have to waste hundreds of dollars on products that really aren't worth that. Unfortunately. it is highly likely that these are only possible through partnerships with Paradox so it might or might not come back.

The alleged Linux support for this game is a farce. It crashes if you try to use true full screen. It crashes if you run windowed. -look at my hours played

-you have to learn 10 years of content at once, so expect a crazy learning curve
-you'll eventually spend hundreds on DLC (absolutely worth it for over 1000 hours of gameplay though)
-you may lose 2,000+ hours of your life over the next 10 years

There is something about this game. You make your own goals and aims. Losing is part of the fun. It may seem complex and difficult at first. but there is no shame in using console commands on your first few playthoughs to get what you want and understand the game better, rather than watching hours of youtube tutorials. In fact I would argue against understanding every mechanic of the game as it really removes a dimension of spontaneity from proceedings when you do. I somehow sunk another 78 hours into this game on this account after all these years and will continue to do so, peak comfy. Learn about geography and history through osmosis, hate and love different cultures you've never heard of before that don't exist anymore. Destroy Naples for ticking you off with a trade embargo. Its truly an experience.

It happens that you landed on some minor country. At first, everything is difficult: enemies are everywhere, they want to capture you. But you, like Midas, are pursuing a competent domestic policy, and then, like Alexander the Great, you are pursuing an excellent foreign policy. And here you have an Empire that stretches what is called A mari usque ad mare, that is, from sea to sea. You become the dominant link in trade, your capital is one of the largest cities in the world, the capital of world trade, the birthplace of industry, printing presses, the Renaissance and more. It seemed that nothing could threaten you anymore ... But then a message comes from the Ottoman Empire: WAR !!! And now you have already been fucked to the point by 12543 Ottoman regiments (in 1470) in which your level 10 fortress falls in 1 month, and you were sent to fuck by all your allies, when their army is in no way inferior to the Ottoman one, but sometimes it exceeds it, but they don't give a fuck, because the fuckers will give a damn. Thus, you take 13523 debts to wipe at least one osman squad, as a result, one dick gets through the ass, and you fall into bankruptcy. Ultimately, you return along the borders of the country to the initial years. In a word, historical.

[h1]Gaming experience without DLCs[/h1]
The game by itself isn’t inherently bad without DLCs, there just isn’t any depth to the game however for example event chains or trees, and some mechanics are missing like that of moving troops across a ocean with a single click and ultimately I wouldn’t say there is anything wrong with that.

[h1]Gaming with DLCs[/h1]
When DLCs are added into the game, it feels like a good whole new game, but just a single DLC wouldn’t do much for especially for me. But when having a collective DLC of the [u]Essentials[/u] then it truly do feel like a different game, the the experience is outstanding, being able to role play as England, the Papal States, and so much more.

[h1]Downsides?[/h1]
Honestly, it’s too expensive. Having let’s say the most essential DLC to me [u]Art of War[/u] if there isn’t any discount it cost [b]19.99 USD[/b] which basically means that you can buy another game which has a more different experience. I myself can’t understand the reasoning for such high pricing but let me do some math for you.

Let’s say you want to have the essential DLCs right now, in my point of view (Full Price without collection):

[table]
[tr]
[th]DLC name[/th]
[th]Price[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Art of War[/td]
[td]19.99 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Common Sense[/td]
[td]14.99 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Dharma[/td]
[td]19.99 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Emperor[/td]
[td]19.99 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Rights of Man[/td]
[td]19.99 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Total[/td]
[td]94.95 USD[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

That basically you can buy a 2 Triple A games, but if you really want to buy those DLCs please buy it during discounts and buy collections such as Europe Universalis IV: Ultimate Bundle, or Starter Pack.

It is a beautiful game and the most wonderful way to visit "history."

I would almost recommend it as a visual resource for history teachers, but don't know if that violates copyrights or educational principles.  Personally, I have spent many hours between EU-IV maps and Wikipedia entries as I absorbed more of our planet's noisiest primates' dramatic history.

The mod community also adds richness and depth, particularly for earlier centuries.
Many of these mods serve as "pro-bono history dioramas" made possible by the delicious Clausewitz Engine.
 
But the DLC-milking is frankly egregious. Up to shameful proportions - better to charge more in less iterations.  We love the game and appreciate the development, but....

Other Paradox games are more reasonable in the way they fund continued development, Stellaris being a shining example, and if they get to be more like this 
(the Civ 6 model of "buy every different idea in the deck as a 9.99 Pak") 
then the entire franchise may die, but hopefully the Engine will remain.
It's just such a transparent "nickel-and-dime"-ing of intelligent fans that it feels almost insulting.

That being said,

Thank you for the lovely game and the delicious engine.

Keep it up and we will be here to support you.

Europa Universalis IV (EU4) is a grand strategy game that immerses players into the intricate world of global politics, conquest, and diplomacy spanning from the late Middle Ages to the early modern period. Developed by Paradox Interactive, EU4 offers a deep and engaging experience for history enthusiasts and strategy aficionados alike. Here's a comprehensive review of the game:

Gameplay and Mechanics:
EU4's gameplay revolves around managing a nation's economy, military, diplomacy, and internal affairs. The level of detail and complexity in these mechanics is staggering, offering a realistic and dynamic representation of the era. Players can choose from a vast selection of historical countries, each with its unique strengths, challenges, and historical events. The gameplay's depth allows for diverse playstyles, from aggressive conquerors to peaceful trade empires.

Diplomacy and Warfare:
The diplomatic aspect is a highlight of EU4. Players must navigate a web of alliances, rivalries, trade agreements, and royal marriages to secure their nation's interests. Diplomacy often proves crucial for expansion without resorting to constant warfare. When war is inevitable, the military mechanics offer diverse strategies, with aspects like terrain, unit types, and generals playing significant roles.

Historical Accuracy and Events:
EU4 captures the essence of the historical era remarkably well. The game's events, decisions, and missions are based on historical occurrences, enabling players to relive significant moments. The "National Ideas" system allows nations to develop unique strengths and weaknesses based on their historical context, adding to the authenticity.

Learning Curve:
The game's complexity can be both a blessing and a challenge. While it offers an enriching experience, the learning curve can be steep for newcomers to the grand strategy genre. The game's interface and mechanics require dedication to fully understand, but the reward is an immersive and intellectually stimulating experience.

Modding and Community:
EU4 boasts an active modding community that creates an array of content, from alternate history scenarios to graphical enhancements. This extends the game's lifespan significantly, ensuring players can explore fresh experiences even after mastering the base game.

Graphics and Sound:
While the graphics are functional, they might not meet the standards of some modern games. However, the game's focus is on depth rather than graphical prowess. The sound design, including the music and ambient sounds, contributes to the immersive atmosphere.

Verdict:
Europa Universalis IV is a masterclass in grand strategy gaming, offering an unparalleled blend of historical accuracy, deep gameplay mechanics, and diplomatic intricacies. Its complexity might deter some newcomers, but those who invest time and effort will find an incredibly rewarding experience that can educate and entertain in equal measure. Whether you're a history buff or a strategy enthusiast, EU4 is a journey worth embarking on.

In the vast and illustrious pantheon of gaming, Europa Universalis IV stands as a reviled testament to sheer incompetence and design malaise. This purported strategy masterpiece is a convoluted morass of befuddling mechanics and anachronistic gameplay that evokes naught but exasperation and a persistent yearning for respite.

From its onset, Europa Universalis IV inundates players with an overwhelming cascade of information, thrusting them into a baptism of confusion that leaves one gasping for a lifeline amidst a sea of inscrutable UI elements and indecipherable tooltips. The alleged "strategy" at the core of this wretched abomination becomes a futile endeavor, buried under layers of obfuscation that defy comprehension.

The purported scope and depth of the gameplay is a deceitful façade, for beneath the surface lies an unsettling lack of substance and variety. The laborious process of shaping a nation's destiny degenerates into a tedious cycle of repetitive actions bereft of any nuance or agency. Mundane decisions become mere arithmetic exercises, bereaving players of the semblance of meaningful impact on the world they purportedly rule.

Combat mechanics, ostensibly the cornerstone of any strategy game, are an exercise in frustration and tedium. Battles devolve into a farcical display of units mindlessly flailing at one another, bereft of any tactical depth or strategic acumen. This banal charade leaves the player as a hapless spectator to their own grand tragedy, devoid of any satisfaction that should arise from a well-fought victory.

The insidious design choices of Europa Universalis IV continue to afflict even the most basic interactions. Diplomacy, intended to be a realm of cunning negotiation and diplomatic prowess, devolves into a ceaseless parade of unconvincing demands and simplistic AI responses, rendering any attempt at meaningful statecraft a pitiable farce.

Moreover, the game's abhorrent AI only adds to the prevailing sentiment of exasperation. It oscillates between infuriating incompetence and blatant cheating, effortlessly swaying the balance of power with its inscrutable and irrational decisions. This unwavering inconsistency erodes any semblance of strategic challenge, leaving players to grapple with a farce of an opposition that negates the satisfaction of hard-earned victories.

The purported historical depth of Europa Universalis IV is a piteous farce, as the game turns a blind eye to the intricacies of the past, peddling a shameless revisionist history that betrays the essence of its purported premise. The depiction of cultures and civilizations is a regrettable caricature, rendering a disservice to the richness and complexity of human history.

In summation, Europa Universalis IV is an unmitigated disaster of epic proportions, suffused with an assemblage of misguided design choices and a paucity of meaningful gameplay. Its labyrinthine mechanics and disconcerting lack of coherence leave players grappling with a maelstrom of confusion and disappointment. Within its hapless embrace lies naught but the gnawing realization that one's time would be far better spent elsewhere. A shameful testament to the worst aspects of game design, Europa Universalis IV is a blight upon the annals of gaming history, evoking naught but contempt and dismay from those unfortunate enough to have borne witness to its lamentable existence.

My first review of my second Paradox Interactive's games. One of the most prestigious games in their arsenal and definitely one of mine most favourites if you consider my play time (it's actually longer than what it says here).

Now let's get with the review shall we? I'll avoid putting 20+ pros and cons as it's all arbitrary to any player both good and bad at playing at this game, so I'll just mention a couple of things both good and bad. 

I'll say, that the game is quite immersive and fun. It lets you take a look how was a world evolving after the period of Renaissance and during the Colonial era. What Paradox really took into a consideration was the sheer amount of provinces and made so clean looking borders that other strategy games can only wish to replicate. Nitpicking or giving attention to details to this map game? Up to you to decide. I am just happy being able to see almost perfectly accurate empire borders of the time. 
Map asside, talking about mechanics. Paradox did a great job at keeping an army composition fairly "easy" to put. Don't ask me how many infantry to artillery battalions have to be in that particular part of the game as I have no clue. But the ability to just spam 30+ infantry cannon fodde...I mean, conscripts is a nice simplified way to wage wars in the game. Wars are one of main focal points of the game so if you plan to build a prosperous and stable empire you would have to here and there invade a country or two. 

Some more mechanics that need to be considered as pros of this game are aggressive expansion and vassal strength. AE is a nice way to stop a country from becoming too powerful and big in a short spam of time and no matter how strong you think you are when you are invaded by the whole Europe is quite scary regardless of your status in the great powers list. Vassal strength is one of the, in my opinion overlooked mechanics of the game that Paradox really implemented it well. Just like in the actual history when a certain great power wanted to assert it's dominance over a certain region they did it best by dissolving and creating new nations of the existing people that settled the area *cough cough* Balkans.
The similar was done in EU4. Instead of having one big Great Britain as your puppet, why not disintegrate it into England, Scotland, Wales and why not Cornwall. Sure, you might be over your diplomatic limit but you will be able to easily control the new puppets now that they are weaker. Divide et impera, am I right? 

There are definitely some more things that could be addressed as the positives of this game but I am neither too skilled to name them all as I myself as still learning, however, we cannot dismiss the "downsides" of this game or the very least negatives.

Number one is the price. For a game that is going to be nearly 10 years old in I believe August of this year of writing this review, spending a full price of 40 euros, or dollars is a bit too much for a base games. I won't talk about how many in the community are talking about Paradox giving us a skeleton of the game and then having to make us pay for DLCs in order to have fun. Still for a base game 40 euros is too much. If some of the DLCs were included in the base game then I could see that being a logical decision, but I do agree that a lot of quality of life mechanics and some other features that you don't even know are actually a part of a DLC. I mean for having to do to a barrage while the province is under a siege you have to have Mandate of heaven DLC and if you wanted to do a naval barrage you have to have Golden century DLC, I believe. Two very simple stuff that could have been a free update are locked behind a paywall.

Secondly we have to address the manpower mechanic that I believe was badly implemented. The ability to recruit units means they need to be pulled out from somewhere, so that means fewer peasants, fewer artisans and so on and so on and the game in my opinion doesn't really represent that. You can suddenly recruit 100K troop in Spain without Madrid losing even one of the manpower development. Recruitment also doesn't affect production so those were some of the stuff that the game hasn't taken into a consideration fully or they just didn't want to bother us with it. 

Overall, to all of you who sticked to the end of this review, I can only say that this game is definitely fun and worth playing. The game is called Europa Universalis after all, so the main focus was done on Europe and especially great powers of the period, something that was definitely confirmed with the latest Domination DLC. That doesn't mean that you can't have fun playing outside of Europe, but if you ask me if you were to give me a cent for every nation outside of Europe I started my campaign as, well, you wouldn't need to worry about paying me, that's all I am going to say. I will avoid talking about some historical inaccuracies and they are some of them, both regarding existence of some cultures/nations at the starting date as well as the statuses of certain countries.

Definitely a must buy if you are a fan of Paradox games and therefore strategy games. I would always tell people to buy any game on a discount no matter the price and the same goes for this game. DLC wise buy some that you believe would make your playing more enjoyable, but having a base game won't make you any worse player than me...yeah the game is quite something to comprehend. This is an (expensive) strategy game with fairly dated graphics that will appeal to your inner history buff.

This game has taught me an enormous amount of geography (and some history to boot) which I have used in my life.

You play as a nation state starting in any year from November 1444 to January of 1821 and play to the latter year, deciding policy, sending diplomats, declaring wars, trading, and what-have-you. Yes, you can continue to play past 1821 if you want to. You do not have to worry about your playthrough being limited to a couple hundred years. But all the historical events (such as institutions) and technologies stop advancing after 1821. You keep going with 1821 technology, institutions, and "era" forever. A huge part of the game's main mechanics are thus eliminated or trivialized after 1821.

This game can be extremely easy or extremely challenging depending on how you play, who you play, and what your objectives are. Playing as the ottomans with the goal of conquering Wien in Austria for instance might be relatively easy but trying to simply survive until 1600 as Byzantium may be almost impossible.

This is one of the best and most compelling strategy games I have ever played.

Make sure to find out which DLC you actually need to get the experience you want.

If you play to buy this game, look on the workshop and get Extended Timeline as it is easily the best mod for this game.

Wild Wasteland is also pretty good.

I'm also a fan of the "Uber Custom Nations" cheat mod which lets you make overpowered nations.

THE CHRISTIAN PERSPECTIVE:
Guiding principles:
1. It's not a sin unless it actually violates a biblical rule or principle that is relevant under the New Testament.
2. Anything can be a sin if you do it instead of what you're supposed to be doing.
With those guidelines set...

There are unavoidable dialog popups to which you can only reply "Damn!". You can wait and it will click itself or you can click to get rid of it. So there is unavoidable cursing, which I do not like. I wouldn't say "Damn".

However, as far as I know, there is no blasphemy in this game. 

You can play as pagan, muslim, hindu, catholic, hussite, coptic or what-have-you nations (with all the major religions having mechanics unique to them such as the coptic blessings) and convert provinces you conquer to that religion. Whatever religion you play as is called the "One true faith" in the in-game dialog and menus. You can also "convert culture" on provinces, which I'm pretty sure is a shady way to say "systemic genocide".

So the game lets you roleplay something which is evil. This is little different than Fallout for instance where you can play a character that murders everyone and steals everything without remorse or regret. 

Is such a christian thing to do? If it compels you to behave that way in real life or view that behavior as "good" then no. But if it's merely part of a fictional story or setting, then it's not a sin.

EU4 is a terribly optimized, visually unappealing and over-complicated game which hides many important game-mechanics behind a quite frankly ludicrous number of (very expensive) DLC. But despite it's flaws, I cannot help but love this game which I have sunk an embarrassingly large proportion of my life into. 

At first, I found the game to be quite overwhelming, owing to its sheer complexity and the insane number game mechanics to grapple with, but once I jumped that first hurdle and gained a basic understanding for the game (aided by large amounts of YouTube content) - I was hooked. 

The core gameplay loop of building alliances, fighting wars, conquering new lands and developing your nation etc. is brilliant, (although it does get stale by the late-game when you usually find yourself far ahead of the AI). But in my mind, what makes EU4 such an incredible game is the sheer variety of content it offers. Depending on what nation you choose to start as your gameplay experience can differ enormously. Owing to differing regional mechanics and power-dynamics, along side a large number of unique and powerful mission trees; there is no end to the number of ways you can experience the game, giving it near infinite replayability. This means that the game still somehow manages to feel fresh almost 2500 hours in. 

If you have a large amount of time in your life (alongside quite a bit of money to shell out for overpriced DLC), which you are willing dedicate towards this heavily flawed but nevertheless endlessly captivating and highly addictive game, then I highly recommend that you play it. If you however feel that you have better, more important things to be doing than commanding virtual troops on a 2D map, then please stay away.

Tip: Paradox usually hosts a deal for EU4 and most of it's DLC on humblebundle for a fraction of it's usual price every year. If you are uncomfortable paying such a high price for the game and it's DLC, keep watch and see if you can grab it there

I don't know how to start this review, so I think I'm gonna go for a pros/cons review.

Pros:
-IMO the mot fun RTS game on the market
-A plethora of achievements and DLC to keep you occupied for 20x the amount of playtime I have on this game
-In-depth economy, government and army mechanics
-Fun and thrilling wars
-Not too easy, not too hard. The adjustable difficulty is a plus too
-Probably the biggest reason for why I know assloads of geography and historical borders/flags
-You can convert to Orthodox Christianity as the USA, become Italian culture, and colonize Australia, which is just an example of the absurd shit you can do in this game

Cons:
-ABSURDLY expensive, you have to buy the DLC on Instant Gaming or wait for one of those crazy bundles on HumbleBundle or else you're screwed, and the DLC is pretty much necessary too
-Probably the most complicated Paradox RTS, although it's not annoying to learn like CK3 or HOI4
-The enemy AI is like if you were spectating a chess match and they were Gary Kasparov and your allies' AI is an autistic toddler. The enemy AI also asks for as much as they can get in a peace deal the second they get 10% war score for some reason


If you don't mind a long-ish learning curve and quite a bit of money put into Instant Gaming then I highly recommend you get this, just trust me, it's worth it

EU 4 is the epitome of grand strategy games, delivering an unparalleled experience of shaping nations and rewriting history. Its intricate mechanics, vast scope, and attention to detail create an immersive and addictive gameplay experience. From diplomacy and warfare to trade and exploration, every decision you make has far-reaching consequences. The depth of historical accuracy and the freedom to forge your own path make EU 4 a captivating journey through time. With its robust modding community and regular updates, the game continues to evolve, ensuring endless hours of strategic bliss. Without a doubt, EU 4 is a masterpiece in the grand strategy genre.

As a fan of history and strategy games, EU 4 holds a special place in my gaming library. Its depth and complexity are unmatched, and the ability to reshape history according to my own vision is an absolute delight. Whether you're a seasoned strategist or new to the genre, EU 4 is a must-play title that guarantees countless hours of strategic enjoyment.

Europa Universalis IV, is my personal favorite Paradox Game and the one that I decided to devote the most time to. Despite the fact that at the time of writing this review I have 550 hours on the game. I'd still be considered by many players to be somewhat of a newbie, and with good reason. The game has a tremendous amount of replay value and content. So much so that the game may even be just straight up overwhelming. 

[h1] Positive Aspects [/h1]
What do I think the game does well? Well, as previously said, the [u][b]massive amount of replay value and content to go through[/b][/u]. Furthermore however, the mechanics of the game are rather [u][b]well made and are fun to use[/b][/u]. The game has [u][b]in-depth and complex mechanics[/b][/u] regarding everything from: war, economy, religion, terrain and much more that I simply do not have enough time to write about. All of which give you the ability to take a nation into your hands and form its history in the early modern period in whichever way you envision. All in all [u][b]mechanics wise, and gameplay wise this game is incredibly good[/b][/u]. However.

[h1] Criticisms/Disclaimers [/h1]
As to criticisms of the game that I have. First of all you may have already seen it. [u][b]The atrocious amount of DLCs[/b][/u]. Now thankfully these DLCs are mainly just quality-of-life improvements, though not all unfortunately. It is not nearly as annoying as in Crusader Kings where entire sections of the game are unplayable without DLC. But it's still fairly annoying. 

Furthermore like I said at the beginning of the review. The game is [u][b]incredibly complex and requires a lot of time in order to play properly[/b][/u]. Let alone to master which takes an exorbitant amount of time to do. If you don't have the patience or time to learn an entire genre from scratch (which I could not blame you for), then this might not be the game for you.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
All in all though, despite its flaws. I still really love this game and would recommend it to people who enjoy playing strategy games and don't mind sinking time into one specific game to learn and master it. However, this game is not for everyone so I would highly suggest, especially considering how much this game costs. That if you are considering buying this game to [u][b]watch a couple of lengthier videos about the game and learn some of its mechanics beforehand, only then should you make an informed decision on whether or not you would like to purchase the game.[/b][/u]

This is actually a fantastic game. As a new comer to this genre, you'll be overwhelmed by the interface and the sheer amount of information to digest. Lot's of things that you can do, but basically it will make you feel like a director who sits in front of a monitor trying to analyze corporate data in massive detail. Yes, that's how you would feel like if you have more than a decade experience as middle or top management in any company. Not much animation. Tons of buttons and tooltips. Just pawns on a giant map. Something like a sophisticated Excel with attractive numbers and icons. More like a corporate dashboard which gives you global information in the beginning, but then you can drill down to more detail information and make various decisions from those information.

But the game does not manage a company. It manage a country or a collection of region in kingdom era.

So if you love math, data analysis, or computation, then you'll love this type of game.

Unfortunately, I already have a headache doing all these stuff at work. So playing a game which resemble work, is not my cup of tea.

Voted down because I have a love/hate relationship with this game.

So it is a history simulator for the World like the Civilization series only much more realistic, without all the cheesiness. You can start in the mid 15th Century and try to make it take a turn. What if the Dutch tried to race the other European nations to the new world first? What if Ethiopia was more militant? That is where the fun in this game lies. Change history and see how things might react, or just try to recreate history.

It has a lot of Cons though. This game is not intuitive or user friendly. It has a lot of DLC, some of which seem almost essential and most of which seem to be rubbish. It partially depends on what region of the world you want to play. 

Europe, Asia and parts of Africa seem fairly well done. The Americas are essentially just there to be conquered and the game really fails to recognize the dififerent civilizations of the Americas and their historical power. The Aztec empire didn't fall because of a massive Spanish army but because of conflicts between tribes. North American civilizations weren't destroyed by colonialists so much as being utterly ravaged by disease and inter-tribal conflict.  But hey, I"m American so maybe if I was from Europe, Africa or Asia I'd have more criticism.

EU4 will always be one of my favorite games. It's my most played steam game for a reason. While at its simplest it's a map painting simulator, almost nothing beats the satisfaction of completing whatever goal you set for your campaigns. I've had so many fun moments playing this game and have also met one of my closest friends due to our shared interest in the game.

Although I may have periods where I don't play the game at all, like TF2, I always eventually come back to it and play it for weeks, hunting random achievements or playing whatever Alt-history mod is popular on the workshop at that point.

It's a fun game, although the amount of DLC brings it down a bit since you're paying way more than what you thought you'd initially pay for the full experience with the game. There is the subscription for those who are starting out and don't have any of the DLC and want to experience them all without paying $200+ right out the gate.

If you're able to look past that, it's a really fun game, and one you'll be playing for a long while.

The business model Paradox (the developer) has adopted for this game’s DLC is problematic in my opinion. 

Over the nearly 10 years since this game was released, the developers have released A LOT of additional content; some of which is absolutely essential to enjoying the game in it’s current state. This is because, unlike many other games/developers, Paradox has adopted a policy of free updates for everyone—alongside “optional” DLC. In theory this is good: it means players gets free patches and features, while payers get that extra depth and expanded gameplay...but in practice it doesn't always work this way. Many CRUCIAL gameplay features have been pay-walled behind DLC, and the accompanying free patches simply don’t always account for the lack of these features. This leads to a lot of gameplay balancing problems, and half-hearted implementations of features that either fall short or in some cases straight up break or make the game unplayable.

So, all of that being said, should you still buy EU4? If all you plan to buy is the base game, it’s a hard no. As an experienced player, the game simply isn’t worth playing without some of those fundamental DLCs. If, however, you plan to also pickup some of the DLC—which is a hard sell if you don’t already know you’re going to enjoy this type of game, I know—then yes, in my opinion it’s absolutely worth it.

At the end of the day, there’s simply nothing else out there like EU4: it has become an incredibly deep and satisfying grand strategy game, that’s brought hundreds if not thousands of hours of enjoyment to its fans. But...it’s bogged down by an unfocused DLC model, which hodgepodges features in often nonsensical packages and expects players to continue paying for said content, even when Paradox themselves admit to not meeting their own quality standards.

PDX has certainly lost a lot of goodwill and trust in the community over the last few years. Communication isn’t where it needs to be, valid criticisms of the DLC model hasn’t resulted in any change to the way they make or release content, and quality control has just seemed to slip farther and farther from what anyone would consider acceptable… It’s sad to see a game I love go this way, but there isn’t much I can do beyond telling you that in it’s current state, the base game EU4, is not worth buying. And the developers have a long way to go towards rebuilding their reputation and the trust they’ve lost as a result of taking community goodwill for granted. Actions speak louder than words, you can apologize again and again, but if you don’t back it up with action, have you really learnt anything at all?

The ai's bias against the player is one of the stupidest f u c k i n g thing I've ever seen in my life, and has gotten so incredibly terrible since Cradle of Civilization. (experienced on normal)

-Blocks of alliances around the player while just out your sphere every other nation gets to expand freely. Block doesn't exist if you play outside the region and look in during other games. 
-No matter who you are in a war, the ai will attack you. Forget the rest of the alliance members you brought in, forget other wars happening to their country, just throw as many men at the player as possible.
-The ai's manpower never seems to end and they spam out 1k stacks like they're candy. The ai has infinite money.
-Sieging happens faster than the player's with less siege pips, less artillery, etc. you have to do multiple save resets before the "dice rolls" come close to your favour.
-THE AMOUNT OF NEGATIVE EVENTS THAT HAPPEN TO THE PLAYER COUNTRY THAT THE AI GETS TO SKIP IS UTTERLY GAME BREAKING. Random rng should not give me -3 stability, +20 autonomy, -300 ducats, etc and I had literally no control over it, ESPECIALLY when every other entity in the game gets to just avoid it.

it just keeps going. No wonder they keep shelling out dlcs for this game. They can't get anyone new to buy it. I've wasted so much of my life on a game that just sucks.

The bugs, feature creep, overpriced garbage DLCs, terrible balancing, and greedy Publisher, have turned a masterpiece of a game you can waste thousands of hours on, into a mess of buttons, glitchy mechanics with absolutely zero play-testing whatsoever. 

I used to love this game and had a positive review for it. You can get thousands of hours replaying it over and over as different countries paving your own path and story exploring the game's rich strategic gameplay and mechanics. The base game however is missing lots of features, many of which are quality of life features that they instead sell back to you as DLCs. Paradox intentionally made the game unfinished so you can spend literal hundreds of dollars of DLC so you have easier access to things like the 'alliance button'. I am not shitting you it's THAT bad.

 The DLCs themselves are terrible, just all of them. They all cost way too much and boil down to cramming a few extra buttons into your already cluttered menus. Some of these buttons are absolutely integral to the core gameplay that you would otherwise miss out on, others are completely useless. The DLCs ALWAYS launch with a heaping pile of new bugs that rarely get fixed. Over time the bugs accumulate to such degrees, that the game is barely playable anymore.

Deep under the layers of garbage injected into the game is a fantastic game with a passionate community that, again, I once loved.

At this point however I can't stand by my positive review any more.

TLDR: Was good now it's bad, Overpriced DLCs, Paradox is Greedy

Another game from Paradox Interactive. It has a lot more of what was in Crusader Kings 2 or the previous Europa Universalis 3. Here you can play as a Zaporozhian Cossack, who freed himself from the Turkish and Polish rule, and as an Indian civilization, where you will resist the colonization of America. Personally, I've had England and Spain combined twice from the Americas playing for the Amazon Valley Native Tribe. And I will say that in the end I was defeated, but the game itself showed that with proper government, where you sometimes take unnecessary risks or big investments, you get the same new experience and enjoyment of the challenge.

I highly recommend it to everyone!

Ещё одна игра от Paradox Interactive. В ней гораздо больше всего, что было в Crusader Kings 2 или в предыдущей Europa Universalis 3. Здесь ты можешь поиграть как за Запорожского казака, освободившегося от турецкого и польского владычества, так и за цивилизации индейцев, где будешь сопротивляться колонизации Америки. I give this game a solid 9/10
Pros
- Good mechanics, balanced trade and economic systems. 
-A peaceful "tall" run is possible as is a somewhat Rapid expansion across the globe (some paradox games lack this, they nailed it with EU4)
-Achievements, both Steam and personal, to keep you going until 1821
-Infinite replay-ability. Need difficulty? Play as an OPM in Asia or the New World. Had a good game and are nostalgic about it? Do it again.
Cons
-Game can be railroaded at times, but that's part of the difficulty to break the tracks, and keeps things somewhat historical (I don't know what to do when the PLC explodes and France looses the HYW, so that part is covered by the historical leans)
-AI is either braindead or 900 IQ, also it is allowed to break certain rules like Naval attrition and Zone Of Control, just as the player breaks rules with PUing and Inheritance
-DLC policy is atrocious, getting better. This is a theme with all Paradox games

Unfortunately there is something wrong with it, some line of command that when you log in to play will suddenly disrupt your alliances and create coalitions (simultaneously) out of the blue (over 50 years peace no coalitions against you when you logged off) that will attack you at once, no matter how well you have been doing if you were in peace for over 50 years, not married to heirs of the top dogs to ensure they don't try to rule you, you log in and even if you decide to just forfeit the three coalitions the game will just keep throwing all neighbouring countries that will then proceed to attack you regardless. 

Tried many things, different ways, even following what big players teach by the book - but you log in and the software has a bad day and bye bye to your iron man game you played for a day building up and harmonizing. Happened more than thirty times so I just can't play this anymore. These situations are impossible in real life - impossible. 

No issues, overcame even the religious wars in Europe, all country my religion only, in good will with the neighbors, my allies are strong yet not married. Suddenly log in economy over 10 bushels + strong starts dwindling no reason given - then you know the three coalitions bug is inevitable. 

Because of that I could only finish the game a few times (over 2000 hours played). Usually at sixth to eight place so it's not because I want to be number one, it's because the game is really bugged.

because it must be a bug, unless in order for the AI to compensate the fact it is losing just throws even the kitchen sink at you to stop it, what would be really lame mechanics, as the game ceases to be fun if the software has to cheat to win.

Its a decent game, but as someone that played it and pre-ordered when it was released, its changed in ways I'm not happy about. I can't think of one reason why I would want to play this game ever again.

I'm happy with the game when there were 5 major expansions to the game, after this the changes to the base game gotten to a point where I had to relearn everything once again after knowing how to play before the last expansion.

I can understand learning new mechanics can be fun but when the mechanics change to a large of a degree over the years, this makes it not only overwhelming to the player, its just not fun to relearn everything 5 different times to just see how to lower your AE as an example.

Someone out there in like 2-10 years from now, if you see this review, let me say this. Since this game has all the dlc released you now can play a complete game which to you would probably be a steal if this were on sale.

Though it might be a lot of fun to you and I'm glad I put my fair share into it. Still at that point, I would not buy all the dlc if it was greatly reduced because of the practices that Paradox has today. Hopefully they learn that yes it is okay to release dlc if we continue to pay for it, but what most people want is content that is ADDED onto the base game. NOT TAKING AWAY mechanics that made the game fun to play.

Either or have a good day/night hope someday I can make a future recommend on a Paradox game but this is not one of them.

This game is... so many things both good and bad.

This games core pieces are amazing, and something that will be played 20 years from now. However:

The more I play EU4 the more I remember why I didn't play the game without it being heavily modded. The minor functions of the game can pile up to be migraine inducing. It's like the devs put too many things to do in the game, and due to this some things don't get the attention they need. My latest rant:

Small nations are way too strong, fort pathing and radius effects are still buggy as hell, colonial nations are annoying, ideas have yet to get a major rework, and dice rolls are still 0-9!!! (sorry paradox, battle is not that random.) The problems list goes on!

If you are a fan of history, medieval Europe, watching numbers go up, or painting large areas with a single color, you'll love Europa Universalis 4.

The game offers thousands of playstyles, nations, mods, and tons of flavor. You can conquer Europe as the mighty Ottoman Empire, amass great wealth as Venice or England, or colonize the world as Spain. What ever you want to do and however you want to play, you can most likely do it. Not a fan of vanilla? Well the countless mods such as Europa Expanded, Extended Timeline, or (one of my favorites) Ante Bellum will introduce new flavor and nations to give a break from the base game. 

Now, the game has a steep learning curve and you will need some time to get decent at it, but the community has your back. Dozens of YouTubers, guides, and forums will answer any question you have. You will always learn new tricks and tips even after hundreds of hours. 

I highly recommend the game for strategy game fans.

I've been playing this game for a few years now, and I'm just tired of pretending this game is good.
The concept itself is great, however the vanilla EU4 experience is dogwater even when you have all the DLCs.
Like most of the paradox games, the expansion packs for the base game itself are overpriced and bring nothing to the table, as most of the mods for EU4 offer more variety and flavor than any EU4 DLCs.

I've wasted quite a lot of time playing this game and from my experience, unless you are playing a very overpowered nation, the beginning of the game is almost 99% rng. You want to play Spain? Oh, you can't because France took 3 provinces in Catalonia, which prevents you from progressing your mission tree as Castille, and additionally you have two disasters, that can (with bad rng) game ruin you. The Mamluks at the start are one of the top 5 great powers, too bad they don't have any flavor. Ottomans sounds fun, too bad the game blocks you from expanding after 2–3 wars because of AE. 

When it comes to historical accuracy of EU4, it is no better. The game seems to be the least railroaded out of all the other paradox games, which definitely offers more variety and has more replayability value for the player. but at this point just make an alt history game set in the late medieval to early modern era's. To me, it makes the game worse and more frustrating, as the player has to deal with the most retarded AI ever created for a game. The AI is not coded to do what certain nations did historically and will often do random stuff, usually resulting in abominations like "Danish Russia" or "French Brazil" popping out. In short, EU4 is a sandbox game disguising itself as a historical game.

The war and combat part of EU4 sucks. If you want to make a historical game at least do the combat mechanics some justice. The total war genre did it quite well, where they have actual meaningful battles, where a skilled player can win by having a strategical advantage, despite being outnumbered and outgunned. In EU4, battles are pure maths and statistics, with no regard for realism and historical accuracy. For instance, during the Hundred Years War, in the famous battle of Crecy, an outnumbered but better trained English army, defeated the much larger French army, which comprised at the time of the best cavalry in Europe. Try replicating that in EU4.

Now, the map of EU4. The map is just not good. There are numerous historical inaccuracies, which I presume were done for balance or gameplay reasons. I understand, that making a historically accurate rendition of the HRE in 1444 will make anyone's PC burn, however there are plenty of mods for the game, for example Veritas et Fortitudo or Victorum Universalis, both of which had found a fine balance between historical accuracy and game stability. The EU4 vanilla map is simply too self limiting.

The mods are what saves the base game from being completely worthless. Whatever vanilla version of the mod does wrong, there is a mod that fixes it. It just shows how lazy PDX are with their games. All their games revolve around the same strategy of making a half finished product, releasing it and afterwards they proceed to create a billion DLC's for the game, and having the audacity of charging criminal prices for what should have been in the base game at launch.

TL;DR Base game sucks, historically inaccurate, stupid features, no flavor, overpriced dlc's, literally a mod for the game is better than vanilla.

So let me start off by saying I am in the USD pricing zone for Paradox games, and as such my prices have not increased as many other countries have, and considering I own almost all the DLCs (mins Mare Noestrum, by far the worst) this price increase does not affect me. That being said, I absolutely can not recommend this game to anyone based on this exploitive price increase, in combination with the ludicrous DLC policy. When GOTY Witcher 3 costs less than Vanilla EUIV in some countries such as Brazil or Russia, you know consumer manipulation has gone too far.

The game itself is fun, combining all Paradox games I have 2k+ hours in the short few years I've used steam, but I can't support a company that would outright exploit countries where purchasing power has decreased or stagnated. Nor can I support a company where their DLC policy is to publish DLCs with essential features for a price comparable to the base game itself. Mare Noestrum is a great example of this, in which you get very mediocre features and "should be free" GUI buffs for $20. The Mandate of Heaven also has a noticable teaser with the Ages banner at the top, and providing negative buffs like Devastation free but positive buffs like Prosperity that only come in the DLC, putting players with a smaller wallet at a significant disadvantage.

Until Paradox changes course and commits to changing course, don't buy this game unless it is on sale, and if you're really committed to pro-consumer advocacy I advise not buying paradox games period.

Wait for Europa Universlis 5. 

This game is great. One of the best Paradox has ever released and the best in recent memory. If EU5 maintains this game's DNA it'll be well worth playing. This is not. 

Paradox's strategy is pretty obvious at this point. Release a *mostly* complete game and then release expansion pack priced DLC that provides the solutions to the problems they create in "Free Updates". No game should have "DLC required to have fun" and this game does. They've attempted to mitigate this late in the game's life by releasing a subscription service. If you're the type that doesn't mind paying a subscription, especially for a game with multiplayer this poorly implemented, then by all means go ahead. Otherwise you're stuck paying hundreds for the DLC or trying to play the game with only a couple and slowly getting them. I was the latter and it made the experience very poor, I decided to try a month of the subscription and it's obvious they're paywalling enjoyment of the game. 

I'll be honest. I'm tried of paying $20-30 for something nobody wanted to solve problems they created. All the aesthetic changes would previously had been bolstered by mods but you're left hoping they update the mod after the update breaks it, and even then it might just not be compatible. Games like Rome: Total War had expansions priced similarly and they were nearly full new games. 


Ultimately, it's a great game with insane player freedom, and some of the best (and only) grand strategy out there but mirred by poor executive decisions.
