This game is cool and that's about it.  Get ready for bullshit RNG and thousands of popups that block your screen, all the while having everyone else somehow having better tech and army damage and morale than you.

First some of the pros, I do sometimes enjoy EU4, even if it's situational.  Being able to play as different empires and rp your way to greatness is really cool, and the game is difficult, which means every victory feels incredibly satisfying.  You feel like the reincarnate of Caesar when you do well in this game.  The world is interesting and varied, with fleshed out nations in Asia, Europe, Africa and even the Americas (with DLCs).  Nations can form others, meaning you can create your favorite historical empires and kingdoms.  The combat in this game is not for everyone, and you move individual units to seige forts and kill other stacks of units, it's an interesting combat system but it can be jarring if you've only played games like HOI with a frontline system.  Economic systems in the game are pretty in depth with some good customization, however don't expect vic2 levels of economy depth.

EU4 is a cool, and potentially fun game, and while I do have fun expanding, it is quickly taken away.  Firstly, This game is very RNG dependent, and whether you get a good start or not is entirely random.  For proof you can just about go to any nation guide, and they always start off with "If... then restart."  That's not good game design, its not fun, its just tedious and monotonous, but that's the absolute best of it.  Mid to late game is when RNG really kicks your ass.  Random massive nations allying each other, your best generals dying at the worst possible moments, random events that spawn tens of thousands of "pretender" rebels when  you have no unrest, with absolutely no warning, not even letting you accept their demands.  I  can not count how many times I have wasted hours of my life and lost a game because a general randomly died or the nation I was at war with allied the most powerful country in the world.  And that's the absolute worse part of it, it's not bad enough that you have to restart and can't fix your dying nation, but it takes hours, potentially days to get to that point, and if you mess up once you can destroy all of that.

While it is better the more you play, and I am not incredibly experienced with 300 hours (which is ridiculous that that's "inexperienced"}  Learning this game for the first time can be complete and utter garbage.  The game tutorial is useless, and your only guides are youtubers.  However, if you actually want to play the game you bought without combing through literal hours of youtube tutorials, you are violated by multiple UIs, buttons, and hidden features that you may not even learn until thousands of hours later.  Combat is simple enough, but different nations have ideas that either give them completely OP buffs to their armies, or none at all, making playng some nations out of the questions, same as attacking others.  It almost takes strategy out of the equation, where actually building up your country to a position you are powerful in is completely negated by the fact another nation could have an arbitrary +20% morale boost to their troops.  Combat can be unforgiving and relentless, and you can easily lose stacks of your army in a single battle, deleting tens of thousands of troops, making you have to scramble to re-recruit more.  The economy in this game is incredibly tough to crack, and can be a constant source of stress and pressure in the game, with you usually having to take out a ton of loans to stay afloat until late game.  Even then, to have a competent military with the other powers in the game you are going to need to use loans and experience a degrading economy.  Trade can be incredibly hard to learn for beginners as the interface is complicated and intimidating, Interest from loans can quickly pile up, putting you in a debt trap where your only option is to go bankrupt, potentially ruining your game and making your armies useless.  In all, the game can be brutal for beginners and can continue to be so later on, with little to no breathing room or possibility for experimentation as doing so could cost you time, money and even your whole run.

Lastly, the ai can be frsutrating to work with, and a lot of the time, you'll need to rely on it.  The ai in the game is.. inconsistent at best, with your allies sometimes wiping the enemy completely, or failing to win a single battle against them. 
 It always feels as if the enemy ai and their allies are always better than the ai of your allies.  I have had allies with three times the troop count and power as enemies completely fail to do anything useful, throwing the game and ruining it.  The enemy ai always deathstacks their troops and targets yours, and if your ai allies aren't nearby to help, they will wipe your army and split into dozens of tiny stacks to flood your land, preventing you from making more troops.  The ai in the game can be both incredibly infuriating to go against and work with, making you feel as if you're really the only one doing anything at all in the majority of your rounds.

As cool and potentially fun as EU4 is, there is so much room for disaster that could make your playtime not enjoyable, and cause you to waste hours of your life on a run that you didn't accomplish anything on.  The RNG, AI, and steep learning curve can make the game an infuriating mess.

It's a really interesting game, however, you ought to spend a lot of time playing it, for it to pay off. I've been away for several months, and it's like I need to learn it anew. The tutorials online are helpful, though, although I need to spend a lot of time just updating and reminding myself. That said, it's really rewarding and a lot of fun once you get a hang of it.

I genuinely enjoy some aspects of this game, but when all of my progress will inevitably be wiped out by having cowardly allies who cannot recognize situations where the only possible way to win is to group up, I cannot say i would recommend it. Also side note the business strategy here with the dlc is actually atrocious. It is simply not worth that much.

They added a "favor" system to diplomacy that makes absolutely no sense and makes alliances essentially useless thereby ruining the game for me.

Used to be fun, not ruined. Do not buy.


Long Story: You used to rely on countries opinions of you which were determined by who you were allied to - allied to a countries rival? they'll not like you. You could cut off that alliance to change that, and if you improved your relations with the first country you could become their ally and they would likely help you in a war, depending on their finances and other varying circumstances - all of which made sense. 

Now you need "10 favors" to ask a country to come help you in a war.
All that other stuff is still there but now on top of that you need to have "10 favors" to ask anyone to come help you in a war, unless you want to make promises of giving them territory - which makes no sense and makes the point of the war essentially pointless. You aren't fighting to expand another country, you are fighting to expand your own.

How do you get favors? you wait, i presume. It was never explained. I lost interest with the game before i got to that point because i honestly cant be bothered to learn redundant game mechanics for games that prior to their addition, had no issues with said game mechanics...

It's like addind a new wood gathering mechanic to RUST where you'd be picking up individual pieces of wood off the ground. It might sound good on paper, but during the actual gameplay, it would be a redundant and useless mechanic that offered nothing but an annoying obstacle to what you were trying to accomplish prior to its addition. You can still technically do it, but it's going to take much longer.

That's what the problem with this addition is. I could TECHNICALLY still start an empire where the netherlands exists, during the HRE, but it would take me phenomenally longer and likewise be phenomenally less enjoyable.



Maybe try listening to the consumer and ask them what they want because no where in any forum, discussion board, reddit post or anything ever, have i ever seen anyone who plays EU4 say "Hey, you know what would be cool? If we added this thing were instead of just agreeing to help allies as has been done since the dawn of history.. how about now - you can only get allies to help you in wars if you suck off... i mean if you get enough "favors"... yeah -- we should have this whole "favor" system that would essentially slow down every bit of the game progression and keep people festering in unhealthy alliances or just not conquering anything, essentially forcing people to watch the game advance on the fastest speed without being able to logically do anything... that would be so cool"


As a gamer, you're probably reading this and having that same thought all of us are having where we say, "who even thinks of this shit?" no one wants this, no one asked for it. It helps nothing. It's so weird because all of us have these amazing ideas, none of which are usually shit ideas because we genuinely talk to other gamers during our brain storming sessions, typically. And we know that an idea like this would be purely unfun at a root level, and outright stupid at a base level... yet here we are in 2023 where games that are coming out are trash and the updates to the games we used to like basically break the fucking game.

Paradox though, amirite?

Live service games are a cancer, and Paradox has truly lost their way. Or perhaps they found it after all...

I WAS an ardent Civ 5 player before I found this game (and its cousin Crusader Kings 2). Note the emphasis on the WAS. EU4 is, no doubt, an epic, the beowulf of video games (or any other gargantuan classic you'd like to name). Relatively easy to pick up, but (and I'm sure I'll test this) a lifetime to master. From Agincourt to Napoleonic France, this game covers the end of the middle ages, the age of exploration, and the beginnings of industrialisation in grand detail. Conquer, colonise and connive your way to the top, and fight to stay there - or explicitly choose not to.
Only major downside is the price - and the fact that it overlaps with others in the Paradox catalogue - which, while demonstrating the studio's commitment to their product, adds substantially to the cost of purchase. Buy the base game, certainly, and then, if you become as enthralled as I have, shell out for the DLC's and connected games.

The game is incredible. The depth and the complexity of the game mechanics means that you will still be 'learning' the game hundreds of hours in - and you will likely never master it. Every nation feels unique in some way, and there are tons of unique interactions to discover while playing each of them. The AI has also gotten considerably better at playing the game, which means that there is a lot of challenge early on. However, like most GSGs, the difficulty falls off a cliff in the late-game once you've established yourself.

The game has become a bit of a meme over time due to the massive amount of DLC. Two points on this:
(1) You don't get 10+ years of active development and support on a game without some sort of ongoing income, in this case DLC. The DLC are the price you pay for Paradox to continue developing the game, and with this perspective its less egregious than it appears at first glance. 
(2) A lot of the DLC are no longer necessary due to Paradox removing features from the DLCs and putting them in the base game. There are still a few that are basically 100% required for the game to play correctly - Art of War, mainly - but for the most part the DLC features are additive. I would recommend locating a DLC tier list before buying any, and only buy them on sale or from 3rd party sellers.

That being said, you will not find a better GSG. EUIV is considered to be the king for a reason.

One of the best (and probably the best) strategy game ever. Though it might be a little difficult to understand all the mechanics at first, you're in for hours of play.

You'll have to manage your income (through trade, taxes and more), your warfare (manpower, armies, generals,...), your diplomacy (who are your allies and ennemies ? Your vassals ?) and your territory through roughly 400 years. You'll choose your difficulty (ie your beginning country) according to your liking and this game'll range from "very easy" to "really challenging".

Best of all, this game is entire in itself but the developper make new dlc twice to three times a year. You don't have to buy them to enjoy a full game, but even if you don't they always release free content at the same time of each new dlc. Just be aware that you'll have to wait for (roughly) a month or two before every bug is corrected each time they get a new DLC out.

Best parts of this game :
- a real diplomacy compared to most of strategy games
- a new game almost each time you play a new country
- up to 10's of hours of playing for each new starting country
- good in every mechanic
- regular free content

Europa Universalis 4 (EU4) has given me nearly 4000 hrs of challenge, education, frustration and joy. I recommend it as a learning tool to people who are either fascinated by geography and world history, or who have been completely bored by it in a classroom lecture setting. I also consider it to be a fun mental exercise up there with the best Total War and Civilisation titles, though EU4 is its own experience is certainly not for everyone.

I have been hesitant to make a proper review because the game is frequently changing, and may continue to change for some time. While I think the model of continuous growth can be compelling for dedicated players, it makes it very difficult for new players to find solid ground. This is on top of the paid expansion model, which I will discuss further on. All to say that I often feel a kind of incompleteness to EU4, neither fully good or bad, that is just part of the experience.

I have played in bursts over the past 5 years, and while I have felt finished at times, I still find myself coming back for one more nation's story, one more crack at taking the world. You get to know the big dogs in your corner of the world, and how to use them to jump from a minor local power into a looming superstate. If you ever get bored of that corner, start a new game somewhere else. Some of the achievements are downright painful, but the good ones offer a good hook to give you new ideas.

I should warn that there is a general instability to the game, with fixed bugs being replaced with new ones -- occasionally game-breaking ones -- each update. Still, the community is active and the devs listen, so a crash usually just means it's time to report and take a break for a few weeks and come back even stronger.

As for the paid expansions, I would recommend new players to mostly ignore them. I consider EU4 to be a hobbyist's game, like Warhammer tabletop or model railroading; you can watch guides to get exposure to some expansion material, and ideally play with others to feel out which expansions you might like. In the past, there have been some expansions that seemed "necessary" for play, but the devs have been good about transitioning those most valued mechanics into free updates for all. What remains are mainly flavour packs for certain regions or nations, which add richness if you really crave it. In any case, I neither approve nor oppose the paid expansion model, but would strongly encourage to wait for sales and bundles on expansions.

This game, along with other Paradox strategy titles, ignited a passion for understanding peoples of the world that I never knew I wanted. I recommend Europa Universalis 4 in the hope it will do the same for you.

Pope willing, we'll all meet again in EU5: The Search for More Content.

Europa Universalis 4 is hands down one of the best grand strategy games out there, and I say this as someone who's spent countless hours playing it (let's just say I have a lot of experience with it). If you're a history buff or just enjoy complex, in-depth games with a ton of replayability, then this is definitely worth checking out.

One of the best things about EU4 is the sheer amount of content it offers, including a wide range of nations to choose from, a variety of different start dates and scenarios, and complex gameplay mechanics that cover diplomacy, warfare, trade, and colonization. The game never gets stale because there's always a new challenge to take on, and it's incredibly rewarding to see your nation grow and thrive.

That being said, Europa Universalis 4 does have a lot of DLC, and it can add up in price. While some of the DLC is cosmetic, there are several expansions that add significant gameplay mechanics, such as new religions, governments, and regions. If you want to experience the game in its entirety, you'll need to invest in some of these expansions, which can be a bit pricey.

Despite the cost, I do think that the DLC is worth it if you're a serious fan of the game. The expansions add a lot of depth and variety to the gameplay, and they're generally well-done and add value to the base game. Plus, the developers continue to release new DLC regularly, which keeps the game fresh and exciting.

Overall, I can't recommend Europa Universalis 4 enough. It's a truly fantastic game that offers countless hours of entertainment and replayability. While the DLC can be a bit of a barrier to entry for new players, I think it's worth it if you're planning on sinking a lot of time into the game. And if you're not sure which DLC to get, there are plenty of guides and reviews out there that can help you make an informed decision.

I love this game, it's a great game, and I've obviously sunk a lot of hours into it, but I can not recommend this game. The DLC posture that Paradox takes feels predatory. Buying EU4 and all of it's DLC costs hundreds of dollars. This is not unique to EU4, Paradox DLCs the hell out of all of their games.

I have less than 1444 hours so I havent finished the tutorial but I can say pretty confidently this is a good game. It's probably the "gamiest" of the paradox games, not much in the way of roleplay it definitely feel more like learning a bunch of systems and then using your knowledge of how things work under the hood to game the system and pull off incredible plays. Nothing else quite like it out there, recommend with an asterix. The dlc is expensive af, theres so much and a lot of it feels pretty essential, I obviously dont recommend buying it all at once unless you're a millionaire. They have a monthly subscription where you get all the dlc for a smaller monthly fee and if this was literally any other videogame on earth I'd think that was a horrific, scummy practice but for this game and this game alone it isnt the worst. If that turns you off of this game then theres nothing I can do to convince you, you're not wrong, its a bit unreasonable to pay a subscription for a game like this and its more unreasonable to pay hundreds of dollars up front for almost 10 years of dlc. The only reason the dlc doesnt bug me specifically is I've played this since launch, I'm buying one dlc every 6 or 8  months, its a bit different than dropping 300 bucks on a game in one lump sum.

Either way, be prepared for a lot of hours of losing, as there are a lot of different mechanics that you are not taught about beyond experiencing the consequences of getting it wrong.

Detailed map painting simulator with high learning curve and intense micromanagement. It is a very rewarding experience.

The only real major game changing mechanics from EU3 is the change of the trade system. Several game aspects, such as navy, army supply, and governance are underdeveloped and for the majority unchanged this same decade. Sometimes I prefer EU3 over EU4. EU3 is a finished product where all aspects come into its own. EU4 feels like a broken product where new mechanics are perpetually added to justify "fixing" the game.

- Learning curve and excessive micromanagement is caused by the excessive feature creep. 
- Feature creep exists, because of the excessive amounts of DLCs. Some DLCs are mandatory to make the game playable. More recent DLC's focus on missions which add "flavour" which is also obtainable through the use of mods. That these DLCs see daylight is because they are what the consumer wants and on top of that low-risk, low-effort and high pay-off.
- Quality of DLCs and their associated patches are dubious of quality. This has led to a decrease in stability and performance. And while the former was fixed, the latter persists.
- Very slow game pace, especially mid-game when you have to fight the same war over and over again, because absolutism/ admin efficiency have not kicked in and the AI developed every province into infinity. 
- AI is in a terrible state while it has seen some improvements over time. In 1.35 the AI finally seems to realize it is a good idea to attack a stronger, but weakened rival. For years the AI was seen too stupid so their troops would not suffer from attrition. Currently, the AI is exempt from rules that do count for the player, but not for them, such as forming alliances while at war. 
- Diplomacy is broken and attempting to use it as intended is just frustrating. The AI's diplomatic decision making criteria are laughable, for example, when they ditch your alliance, when they join your wars, if they want an alliance with you or if they join a coalition against you. This is inherently related to the stupidity of the AI which is all too easily abused to do your dirty work. The state of diplomacy and AI is best described by the meme "AE is just a number".

My European genes have begun colonizing

This game is my favorite grand strategy game from Paradox Interactive and perhaps my favorite strategy game of all time. You can choose literally any country in the world from 1444-1820 and play that nation and see it rise or fall. The game mechanics are simple enough to where a new player can have fun, but are deep enough to where you are always learning and adapting your strategies. The frequent updates keep the game fresh with new mechanics and aesthetics to learn and add to the depth of the game. Every time I play something new happens: no playthrough is the same.

However, this positive review is completely conditional on DLC. If you do not have the over $400 worth of DLC, this game is very shallow and lacks many quality of life additions, not to mention countless game mechanics. It is essentially an entirely different game without DLC. If you are able to pick up the DLC on sale, or subscribe to the expansion subscription to unlock them, then this game is completely different.

However, with or without DLC, the game is definitely showing its age at the time of writing. Certain mechanics and features you can definitely tell are from 10 years ago. Each new update seems to break as much as it adds, and it feels like the game is made up completely of spaghetti code at this point. You can also clearly tell that Paradox doesn't play test their new updates and some of their decisions are baffling (buffing the already overpowered Ottomans?). I wouldn't be surprised if an EU5 is announced soon to replace this game. 

But, you can still spend hours on a single campaign, and besides the fact that completely different events happen in each playthrough, your options and play styles are completely different depending on the country. I have nearly 1,000 hours at time of writing on this game, and I still have barely managed to scratch the surface, and that's with me primarily only playing in Europe and the Middle East.

I've been playing this game for close to 10 years at this point.  Got it on launch, stuck with it through the rough patches, and is by far and away my most played game of my entire life.  Recently it has been getting significantly worse.  First with the Leviathan patch and now with the 1.33 France patch it finally stopped being fun to play.  The change to the military battle calculations just stripped a number of play styles out and replaced it with a single dominant style that any deviation from turns any run radically sub optimal.  

I'll be the first to admit that these changes probably won't be noticed by new players, but over time as you play and master the game they add up to ruin the previously near endlessly diverse ways to play.  It's not a game with infinite repalyability anymore.  It's paint by numbers where you either follow the MP meta in SP and stomp the AI or you don't and your expansion slows to a crawl.  In short whatever they were trying to balance ruined the fun of the game and I've uninstalled it for the first time in over 8 years across 3 computers.




It took them a year but they fixed the problem.  The game is playable again.

France is trying step by step on the road to unification. He ended the Hundred Years War with England. The Pope always said that Ottoman was weak and we should continue to form crusades to defeat him. However, Ottoman has been challenging Europe after defeating the Eastern Roman Empire. The Age of Discovery came, and Spain and Portugal were the pioneers, exploring and plundering the world. The Spanish Armada was even more frightening at the time, and then the rest of the Western European countries followed the pace of the times. Tsarist Russia and Poland in Eastern Europe are also rising and expanding. The Ming Dynasty in the east, as the strongest country in the world, was entrenched in the east, and many countries wanted to be his tributary state at that time. Later, pioneers appeared in Germany and religious reforms were carried out. This is a great thing and we have to admire it. Then, within a few hundred years, wars of all sizes occurred in Europe and even the world. France, Tsarist Russia was gradually becoming stronger, Britain was making great strides, and Manchuria in the east was trying to defeat the once glorious Ming Dynasty, but he succeeded in the end. It is true that God favored Europe, where pioneers of thought appeared, and then there was a great revolution in France that affected the world. A legend saw this opportunity. In the French coup, he was Napoleon Bonaparte, the emperor of the First French Empire. He led the French Revolution Going to the climax, his revolutionary sword is changing Europe, the ideas spread by the revolution are simply too terrifying, so that some countries in Europe have begun to form anti-French alliances, and have fought against him for more than 20 years. Maybe God doesn’t want this A legend won, and eventually the Battle of Waterloo ended him. He should never be forgotten in the long river of history, the ideas, tactics, and others he spread, some even affect today. Almost all wars in the American Revolutionary War and the world after the Great Revolution were related to independence, especially the impact of the Great Revolution. Napoleon is a legend and should not be forgotten. The United Kingdom started the first industrial revolution, and it is advancing at high speed. The North American and Russian plains are the British cornfields, Canada and the Baltic Sea are the British forest areas, Australia is the British pastures, Peru is the British silver mines, South Africa and Australia are the British Gold mines, India and China are British tea plantations, the East Indies are British sugar cane, coffee, and spice plantations, the southern United States is British cotton plantations, and Britain is gradually reaching its peak. Eu4 is a great game for the kind of people that will play it. But if you are looking at it and going "oh idk if I will really enjoy this game" then you won't enjoy it. The problem with Eu4 is the same thing that makes it great and extremely fun. And that is it's mechanics and expanse. The game is great with literally infinite content and tons to do, but that is the problem, there is no hand-holding. There is no tutorial, and even at my hours some people will watch me play and feel dumbfounded, either by how much I know, or by how little. The barrier to entry is enormous, and the barrier to mastery is infinite. If you go into this game wanting to play a grandstrategy with other maybe more simpler ones under your belt like ck3 or hoi4 you might love it, that's how I found it, but if you go in first time grand strategy because maybe a friend recommended it or you saw it somewhere and thought it looked interesting I wouldnt recommend it. EU4 is not for everyone, just like chess is not for everyone. If you enjoy 4x strategy games like civilizations, you may want to consider one of the paradox series. EU4 is the most in-depth, accurate historical simulator on the market. I've learned more about history from this game than probably a masters degree in world history. That said, the sheer complexity of this game is daunting. It'll probably take you at least 50 hours to learn the basics of the game. Once you do though, you'll open up a rich and strategically complex game that'll keep you entertained for... well, 4289 hours at least.

If you are afraid of diving into a game of this complexity, try out Stellaris or watch a letsplay before you buy. The other criticism I have of this game is that paradox really milks you for all your money with its many many many many DLCs that are kind of essential to get the most out of the game.

5) If all else fails, remember ALT QQ

What I liked or disliked about this product

First off, this is not a casual game. I remember sitting for hours and looking thrugh the different menus and options thinking about what on earth I was supposed to do.

After 3.7k  hours I still don't know a lot of things. But you don't need to know everything to play the game. If you're willing to spend a day or two learning there is fun to be had. You start by picking one of the existing nations in the world. I haven't counted but I imagine there are hundreds of them. Then you manage your nation with the goal to be better than the others. Usually by making sure there are none left to compare with. There are several start dates but the earliest and I assume most common is 1444.

You will build armies and navies, manage the economy, make allies to make sure stronger nations don't eat you, use diplomacy to hopefully make your alliance eat parts of other alliances, discover and settle the new world, try to please the different groups of your nation (like the Nobility, Clergy and so on), manage new lands and core them so they become yours, try to figure out how to optimize trade, manage religions, I could go on but mostly you will be looking at numbers that describe your country and improve them through different actions and choices.

I mostly play as my own nation, Sweden. In 1444 you start by fighting an independence war against your overlord Denmark. Preferably with an ally or two, Every game has some randomness regarding who will like who so games are always a little different. You get a warscore depending on what the wargoal was and if you achieved that, battles fought, and lands taken among several other factors. Depending on how well you did in the war you can demand lands, money, diplomatic concessions and more. In this case independance and hopefully a few provinces if the war went well.

Then you will probably need some time to cool down. Especially if you took a lot of land. Your population absolutely HATES you taking land and will rebel if you grab too much of it. And your aggressive expansion score will eventually make other nations make coallitions against you if you go too fast. Also you are probably short of manpower for the forseable future.

But soon enough you will look elsewhere for more land. Usually some Novgorod provinces. Then you look for opportunities, does Livonia have strong allies or can we overcome them? Maybe my alliance is strong enough to attack Muscovy?Eventually the truce is up and you will go round #2 with Denmark. Soon you have teched up a bit and will have to choose what to focus on, stronger armies, better economy or perhaps settle the new world?

Your nation grows. You get stronger allies and more dangerous enemies. The diplomatic situation grows more complicated. The longer the game goes on the further away nations can trade and handle diplomacy. Suddenly if you attack a small nearby nation they might have strong allies across the world. Now to take just a small piece of land you might have to spend years getting your troops halfway across the globe. Is it even worth it? This is where the most fun part of the game ends and the more tedious part starts. You are strong enough to win against anyone head to head but if you don't pace yourself everyone in the world will team up against you. Problem is that you only have so much time. The game ends in 1821. So you either play non-ironman mode so you can continue past that date or learn to juggle coalitions against you and learn how to deal with one million rebels roaming your country complaining about how that new province in sibiria is making lives impossible for people in Paris. Because you know... reasons.

I do have all the expansions. While expensive, if you divide the cost by hours played I believe it has been more than worth it. I do recommend the game, with 3.7k hours it would be strange if I didn't.

This game, like all Paradox games, has a deep and complex system for diplomacy, economics, development and more.  Much more.  But where this game falls down is where most Paradox games fail.  The combat mechanics are simply terrible.  
    
Defeated enemy troops run from combat seemingly any direction, often can't be touched until they rally, and then start taking over provinces.  1k troops can control a 50 mile province AND THEN MOVE ON TO OTHERS.  1k troops would be hard pressed to hold a city of any size in that province let alone an entire province.  Your own defeated troops have to march a hundred miles to rally. Enemy nations might attack your invading forces, but more often than not, they don't defend at all and instead march for hundreds of miles to attack non-defended areas.  Not realistic at all.  
   
It's really a shame because combat really doesn't feel epic or realistic, and feels more like a chore.  There's few to little decisive battles and most of the time is spent herding those rabbit forces, moving towards your undefended areas while you are taking over their entire country without opposition.  

It's just damn strange that Paradox hasn't addressed this in any of their games.  I guess they are making too much money on the macro level DLCs to address this very core issue.   It's why I've stopped buying their games or DLCs.

Runs natively on Linux. A good grand strategy game set in the early modern era. The player commands the expansion, development, and centralization of an early modern state along historical lines towards the nation-states and empires of the modern era. This game will interest history buffs and those who generally want to learn more about the world and the histories of the different peoples and nations within it.

Europa Universalis IV is a grand strategy game that covers a huge time period from the beginning of the Renaissance to around the downfall of Napoleon (1444-1821). Like other Paradox historical grand strategy games, you control a country as you try to change history and guide your country through multiple different eras of history. One of the main appealing things of this game is how you can choose any country on the map. You can either play as the great powers, horde nations, Native American tribes, HRE princes, whatever you really want! The best part is that different nations in different parts of the world have unique mechanics to them, allowing for more replayability. The diversity in countries and the longer time period is why I prefer this game over Hearts of Iron IV.

One thing to account for, as always with Paradox games, is the DLC. EUIV has A LOT of DLC. Even if you only count the DLC that add major game mechanics to the game, they still cost more than the base game itself by quite a margin. I was lucky enough to get almost all of the DLC via the Humble Bundle a year ago for $20. However, all of the DLC right now is $400+. Also keep in mind when you see videos of this game, it will probably have most/all of the DLC. There is an option to buy a $5 monthly subscription for the DLC, which would probably be the best option if you have none of the DLC.

If you can look past the DLC issues, this game is amazing for anyone that is interested in history, especially during this time.

To go all over the content is to much for a review here, but in a nutshell: You pick a nation you want, choose whatever is available on the map and play it. Control, manage and conquer land/provinces. Have diplomacy with other nations. Manage your economy. Advance in technology as time goes on. Deal with events and make decisions which always pop-up in a message box.

Note: I usually don't do mods, but for me, the governing capacity and the crown colonies are a game killer, so I do play with this combination: unlimited governing capacity mod + MAX_CROWN_COLONIES set to 500 (instead of 4) which you can find in folder: /EU4/common/defines.lua and edit with notepad. Please note that certain update may reset it back to 4.

EU4 is my favorite paradox game and here is why: it works as both a freestyle strategy game and as a single player campaign.  If you want to play freestyle, you can assume control of any nation on earth in 1444 and go in any direction you want to try. However, I have issues with that type of game - I start feeling overwhelmed by all the possible choices and I struggle to choose. I usually don't feel engaged in that type of game because while I can crush my neighbors and paint the map my color, I start to feel like why should I? Just to see my numbers go up? EU4 offers something for me that other paradox games are sorely lacking: Missions. Paradox has added excellent mission trees to all of the most popular countries in the game. These missions fall into two categories: 1. Things that would be good for any country to do, like increasing your army size, your treasury, your ally relationships, or unifying all of the territory around you or 2. Completing goals that that country either historically DID do or that they WANTED to do. And if you complete the mission, you get some sort of reward to your country, be it more claims on more territory around you, buffs to income, buffs to public order etc. It creates challenges in the game that are fun to try and overcome. For example, starting as Muscovy you have stuff you need to take before you can form Russia. Once that is done you get claims on large swathes of land in Poland/Lithuania. Poland/Lithuania is formidable, so it is a challenge to build yourself up to a point where you can accomplish these goals. It's really far more engaging than other paradox games. I also really appreciate how the game is broken into early/mid/late game by world events. You start out in the age of discovery, when nations are going through the renaissance and nations like portugal and spain are discovering the new world and vying for colonies. Not everyone is in a position to colonize though, so there is a variety of experiences you can have in the early game. Then the age of reformation begins and suddenly there are protestant nations appearing all over europe, which will eventually pull a ton of europe into the religious league war. After that comes the age of absolutism, which sets the stage for the final age of the game, the age of revolutions: nations with super high absolutism may see the revolution appear in them and then the wave of the revolution can spread like fire across europe. All of these things will impact how you play. No two playthroughs of Eu4 are ever the same because of the huge amount of variables being modeled. I really can't praise this game enough. CK3 bores me because yes, I can kidnap and eat the pope, but why? It's funny once and then I just don't see the appeal. There's so few events and historical flavor in that game it really signaled the beginning of this new, seemingly bad era for paradox. Victoria 3 is shaping up to be the same. They claim it is an economic simulator, but really the economic simulation is extremely simple once you figure out how it works. I'm glad I still have Eu4 to come back to since they keep adding valuable content to it. I'm not optimistic for whatever Eu5 will be because surely the new leadership at paradox will make them strip all fun out of the game in order to maximize their profit.

Firstly, let me mention that this is coming from a mainly singleplayer experience. I've done a bit of multiplayer, and the experience is vastly different. This review is up to 1.34 with all current DLC. I believe the EU4 experience can be broken into 3 separate stages.Stage 1 is learning the basics. EU4 is a difficult game to get into. There are many unexplained mechanics, the UI can be difficult at times, and there seems to be too much to keep track of. While this makes the game difficult to get into, it makes the mastery of those mechanics much more rewarding. There are plenty of guides online if you want to learn that way rather than trial and error.Stage 2 is learning how to plan out your moves. After you learn the mechanics, you'll start to learn strategies and goals. As Poland you'll want to form the Commonwealth, as Muscovy you'll form Russia, as England you'll form Great Britain and dominate north america. You'll learn what idea sets go best with those nations, how to efficiently use your resources to win against your rivals, and how to use and format your armies properly. The vast majority of players stop the learning here and then eventually start to lose interest, as nothing seems "new" anymore and all the playthroughs seem the same.The 3rd and final stage is to optimize your gameplay. Learning the small quirks of mechanics and how they may effect your country, and how to utilize them effectively. Throwing on ironman mode and achievement hunting. Doing Byzantium on ironman is probably the best example of this, as it's relatively easy compared to other hard starts but still provides a good challenge. Another good example is razing the world to the ground as a horde when you learn to do efficient conquests and balance truces to nullify aggressive expansion.If you think that taking your time and learning the mechanics of a game to challenge yourself is fun, you'll most likely get your money's worth from this game. I know I have. The game is flawed, don't get me wrong. There are areas of the game that are criminally underdeveloped, Persia being the best example. Other areas are just so poorly made that I can't bring myself to play any nation there, the Americas being the main culprit.TLDR: Git Gud, and game is Gud

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started EU4 and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, did the tutorial but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

As a seasoned player and enthusiast of the grand strategy genre, Europa Universalis IV (EU4) is hands down my favorite game. It offers a depth and complexity that is unparalleled in the strategy game market and allows me to experience history in a way that no other game can.

One of the things that I love about EU4 is the sheer scale of the game. The game spans from the late Middle Ages to the early modern period, and allows you to play as any of the nearly 500 different nations in the game. Each nation has its own unique attributes and challenges, making each playthrough a completely different experience.

Another standout feature of EU4 is its focus on historical accuracy. The game models everything from the political alliances of the time to the technological advancements of each nation, giving players a sense of immersion that is hard to match in any other game. I love how the game allows me to explore different historical what-if scenarios, such as what would happen if the Ottoman Empire conquered Europe or if France was never defeated in the Hundred Years' War.

The game also has a steep learning curve, which I see as a positive. It takes time and effort to master the intricacies of the game, but once you do, the sense of satisfaction is unparalleled. The game also has a robust multiplayer component, which allows me to play with friends or other players from around the world, making each playthrough a new and exciting experience.

Of course, like any game, EU4 has its flaws. The game's AI can sometimes be unpredictable, leading to frustrating situations where the player's best-laid plans fall apart due to unexpected actions from the AI. Additionally, the game's interface can be overwhelming for new players, and the sheer amount of information presented on the screen can be intimidating at first.

Overall, EU4 is a game that has captured my heart and mind like no other. Its depth and historical accuracy, combined with its challenging gameplay and multiplayer component, make it a must-play for anyone who loves strategy games and is interested in exploring the intricacies of history.

Clocked in >1000 hours since 2014. Easily my favourite strategy game. To the developers over the years, thank you for the wonderful (but frequently infuriating) journey. To those starting, you're in for a treat.

Get this game if;
1) You're a raging strategy nerd who's dabbled in and largely completed more mainstream games (Civ, Total War, etc)
2) You have good friends who are raging strategy nerds, so you can spend countless hours strategy-sharing for future conquests, troubleshooting current conquests, and glorifying previous conquests
3) Are completely okay spending the first 20-50 hours finding new and inventive ways of spectacularly over-indexing in one area, and subsequently finding other nations mercilessly punishing you back into obscurity for it
4) Adore cultural diversity (increasingly represented in-game) but are willing to suspend such in the name of imperialism
5) Want a uniquely immersive way of developing an expansive knowledge of world geography and history, especially the obscure bits
6) Ideally, have better self-discipline than myself, or have better excuses than myself as to why you sometimes attend late for work/appointments/catch-ups.
7) Crave mastery and the intrinsic reward of refinement

EDITED TO NOT RECOMMENDED

Please do note that I have played the game up until version 1.34 with all DLCs on multiplayer, and up until version 1.30 with AoW, CS, RoM, MoH, ED, and RP on singleplayer. Also do note that, despite the voluminous size of this review, I am in no way trained or experienced in video game critique, and am simply putting forward and exploring my personal experiences with the game.

There used to be a paragraph here about how I struggled with whether to mark this review as positive or negative, ultimately landing on positive. I have since returned to EU4 after a break, and my experience was.... underwhelming. Now, to address all the people who say rating a game not recommended with 1000 hours in is hypocritical. Many points can be made against that argument, but I will say the following. That I have played a game for a long time does not mean it has to be a good game. It does not even have to mean I personally liked it on the merits of its design or gameplay. Maybe it just makes a convenient tool for killing time. Maybe it has a special place for a group of friends. That does not mean the hours drowned in it are thanks to the game's intrinsic qualities, and it all the more does not mean I am going to RECOMMEND it to other people. I think my original points still hold though, so the following review is unedited.

On account of its mechanical complexity, EU4 is well-known for having a high entry threshold. You might at some point find yourself 1500 hours in and still not knowing exactly how combat works. However, this example also speaks to the fact that you do not have to know all the mechanics meticulously to actually play the game meaningfully. You will still need a lot, mind you, and knowing more typically allows you to strategize more skilfully, but you do not *have* to know quite so much to play decently. This, however, is a double-edged sword. It means that a lot of the game's mechanics can feel somewhat redundant to the regular player, and thus not having their true potential utilized. This, in itself, is still not neccesarily a big problem for the usual player's experience, but it segways into a rather more noticeable problem with EU4's mechanical complexity.

A lot of the mechanics do not have a very real impact on the gameplay - they are not utilized to their full potential. There is a joke in the EU4 community that the game is pretty much just a map colouring simulator - and this comment is not unfounded. Despite the plethora of mechanics at the player's disposal, by far most EU4 games will follow the very same pattern, at least until mid to late game - build a spy network to justify war, declare war, take land gains, integrate conquered land into your country, crush rebels who do not like it, rinse and repeat. Of course, your game will be somewhat different whether you play a merchant republic or a feudal monarchy, whether you play an island nation or a landlocked one, etc. But some patterns are painfully repetitive. The game has virtually no support for "tall" play - developing a small, well-developed state, and protecting oneself using diplomacy, rather than preventive war and vast swaths of territory. Such a playstyle makes for both a boring experience and a vastly more difficult time being a power that actually matters than just expanding ceaselessly. Even as a merchant republic, which should by all accounts bloom as a small nation surrounded by trade partners, you will probably end up expanding to support your nation's development and protect yourself from invasion either way. This can make replayability and diversity of player experiences not that amazing, surprisingly, considering the theoretical scope and diversity of the game.

Another problem with making the experiences feel diversified is the way EU4 handles flavour, or rather the way it is diminished by other factors. The game clearly has a lot of work put into establishing flavour - from unique country ideas, to a plethora of localized events, to even individual unit types featuring in-depth descriptions of their historical background, that most players have probably never noticed. However, that last part is the problem - all the flavour will probably be hard for most players to notice and appreciate. I feel like that stems not from issues with the flavour itself, but the way the game handles UI. EU4 embraces a philosophy of laying all the modifiers and consequences of the player's actions out clearly right in front of them. This might be good for letting the player know what they are doing, allowing them to plan out their actions and predict the consequences in a system as mechanically complex as EU4's. However, you will quickly notice that all those modifiers seriously distract from flavour. Personally, even though I think I would genuinely appreciate flavour as one of the most important aspects of the game otherwise, I never read the actual content of events that pop up. I only found out about the meticulous unit descriptions when I started modding units. Because of all the modifiers you can see laid out in front of you, EU4 becomes almost solely a game of optimizing the numbers. When an event about a conspiracy pops up, you do not bother to appreciate that there is a story going on in the shadow of your throne - you start worrying about the number of admin power points it is going to take to prop your country's stability level back up. When a rebellion erupts in one of your provinces, you do not think about the societal factors behind the growing unrest - you mechanically send in an army to quash it. Even though the flavour technically provides a lot of opportunities for political roleplay - will your ruler flee the capital which is experiencing an epidemy of plague to preserve their life, or will they stay to inspire the inhabitants - when they actually come up, you worry more about whether you can handle the loss of a ruler or a growing unrest modifier in the capital better. Instead of varied political roleplay, of telling an interesting story spanning centuries of history, the game becomes strict realpolitik. And you do this absent-mindedly, even if you would rather roleplay a sociopolitical story than mundanely optimize your empire.

There is, admittedly, a certain silver lining to all of this. Some aspects of the game are big and flavourful enough decisions that they do not suffer from this problem, and I have always had the most fun with EU4 when those things are allowed to shine. There is simply nothing more entertaining than, say, converting Kamchatka to Hussitism as a federal empire you built from a city-state in the HRE. When you play around with such things as nations, cultures, religions, government types, or bizarre borders to create unholy alternate historical scenarios, the potential of the game's flavour really shines - typically in very hilarious ways. Although this also makes it somewhat more clear what all the small-scale flavour could have been had it been given the chance to stand out.

No review of a Paradox game can go without mentioning the heinous DLC policy. As with most Paradox games, base EU4 can be gotten at a reasonable price on sale, but without DLCs, the game is incredibly basic and underdeveloped - meaning you are effectively forced to spend really large amounts of money on a heap of DLCs if you want anything more than that. There is, however, a caveat. The game only requires the host to have a given DLC in multiplayer, so if you have friends who are willing to play, you only need one set of DLCs between you. I think multiplayer also really enhances the best parts of the game mentioned above.

The game is also incredibly easy to mod, as long as you are not looking into changing fundamental mechanics. The code built on top of the engine itself is easy to edit and (mostly) very clear, even to someone with zero coding experience (like me), meaning after a few short and easily available tutorials

It's a grand strategy game from Paradox, so, as for ALL their games, huge pros and huge cons:

Pros: 
Lots of stuff to do, lots of CRAZY achievements, from hardcore to easy peazy. You can create whatever monstrosity you have in mind, or re-enact history with (or without) your friends. Or something in between. Or both of them at the same time. It looks hard, it's actually easy once you do a campaign and reach 1650. Past 1650, just be sure to have a fast CPU and lots of RAM (Fast Universalis is your friend).

Cons:
After 1650 you can pretty much blob everything or explode. Or become revolutionary, which helps you blob at a faster rate...or explode at a faster rate. Or explode people, at a faster rate. Right, France? Lol.
LOTS of DLCs, but this is also a pro. Lots of content. But the thing is, they changed the game too much too many times, after a while it's hard to follow.

In short, 10/10 would reccomend to anyone interested in grand strategy.

I really really want to love this game, or even like it.  It represents a style of game I really want, grand overarching strategy on a world scale.  But I just can't.

The interface and mechanics can be quite arcane.  And when I read about the mechanics online, it just becomes a task of optimizing the game's mechanics, which completely drops the illusion of some kind of world scale strategy, it just becomes a system optimization activity.

Then I read that in order to enjoy the game I just need to get one more DLC to fix some odd broken mechanic, or to make a particular nation fun to play.  Just one more DLC and it will be great.  I promise you'll have fun if you get that DLC!  But it doesn't.  Its just more spending for a game that doesn't feel "fun" in any way.  Oh well.  I guess it works for many, but the investment in learning curve and DLC is very high if you are first approaching the game.

Unfortunately, Steam doesn't have any ratings other than "recommend, don't recommend." 

The game appears interesting, and it is very well rated, but I am simply stunned by the lack of thought given to the GUI. It's bad... no... it's horrible. Little tiny buttons hidden behind other tabs, or with icons that are not clear or are too small to make sense, including some of the most imporant ones. As a result, things take 4-5 times longer than they should. It isn't even really a question of getting used to the layout; some of the locations simply do not and cannot make sense. Things like telling a ship to move and to where should be simple left click/right click, They're not. 

The game clearly has depth, and it is visually satisfactory, and I can see why so many players are enthusiastic for playing it. I want to like it, but with the GUI as it is now, I just can't bring myself to commit. Why should it be any harder to play than a Civ game? 

There's one other thing that annoys me, and that's the DLC. Rather than work on the next version for the franchise, they have posted up a bunch of content for sale. Most of it should probably have been included in the game itself. Seriously, there's more that $300 worth of DLC there. Talk about developers behaving badly...

I've uninstalled my copy, and while I did not ask for a refund, if I had it to do over again, I wouldn't have bought it. The same thing goes for every game by this developer. Sometimes in the future, I may give it another chance... lol... no TBH, that isn't going to happen.

03/07/2023 Update: Installed to see if I had changed my mind. Nope, the GUI is still horrible. Click on army. Find little tiny box to use ship, click on tiny box to unload army. Click on other box to land. Click, search. Click.... search.... Click.... search. Still silly.

Do not get this if you're expecting a finished game for $40. The base game isn't worth $40. The additional DLC aren't worth the several hundreds of dollars. This isn't an MMO - you shouldn't have to pay a subscription to enjoy it.

Many features will feel incomplete, or just not function, without any DLC, or without the right DLC. Because PDX seems to think it's totally fine to cut them in half in major updates.

Take, for example, army templates. It's a system built so you can have standardized army built with a single click. Supposedly, if you have an existing army you want to adjust to a new template, you can do that too, detaching excess manpower (say, too many calvarymen) and training up what the army lacks, as long as you have the money and reserve manpower to do so.

Some of the buttons to use this exist at all time, but don't function AT ALL without the Art of War DLC (+$20). But if you do have the DLC, it still won't work completely. Training up a completely new army works. Shaving off that excess works. But new regiments won't train for an existing army that lacks part of a template you're wanting it to conform to. You can have infinite gold, infinite manpower, all technology, and it just won't. This problem exists for navy fleets as well.

EU4 is rife with these sorts of things. There echos of DLC features all over the place, and sometimes the buttons to use them will be there outright, and you may even be able to click them (to no effect). If you're too poor to spend hundreds of dollars on a game, you have the exclusive privilege of investigating how much of the game actually functions, and if you DO pay the money, it might still not work right.

There are other problems, of course - there's a shocking lack of content for anything outside of Europe (unless there actually is, and I just haven't bought the DLC for that), and the content in Europe feels clunky and artificial (again, probably fixed by $100 of DLC). In a lot of other PDX games, they're trying to accommodate people not fortunate enough for the privilege of having the DLC, but here they seem to expect everyone to be a Saudi Prince with no ability to discern quality. If you're not, you just need to give up and shut up, poor.

It took me sometime to review this game, maybe because the learning curve is greater than the expansion of the universe, but anyways... an amazing game when you understand what you are supposed to do.

So this was initially a negative review. I liked the game, but was extremely frustrated by game-breaking updates. Since a play through of this game often spans months or realtime, and since the game is still being updated/maintained, you NEED to turn off automatic updates if you want to not get angry with this game.


This game covers the time of early colonialism, and it can be frustratingly difficult to play a European power that wants to halt colonies from forming and destroying the native nations of the Americas. If you just take the foreign colonies over, your holdings will eventually become semi independent powers, and will wreak havoc across the Americas.  You have to actively try to sell holdings to the natives surrounding you to keep your holdings in america to become an autonomous power of its own. it is frustrating. 

The game IS a lot of fun, though there is definitely a steep learning curve for figuring out ideal army size/breakdown and timing for reinforcing battles to be able to stand up somewhat to the computer AI. Spend time reading the various wiki pages for aspects of the game, and hope you don't get too confused by the different ways that various DLC affects gameplay.

EU4 takes a while to learn, for me it took about 200 hours before I was any good at the game. At first, you're driven by your desire to create alternate history scenarios, seeing if you can do it better than rulers did in our timeline or save a country from its doom. Once you're good enough to not only save Byzantium, but lead them to be resurgent and form the Roman Empire, you'll basically reach the peak of saving said dead historical nations. At its core, EU4 is a game about stacking modifier after modifier on top of one another to do things that are absolutely absurd. It's still really fun, but different. As for the DLC, don't buy them off the steam store. They're essentially necessary to play the game, so you'll need them, but don't encourage Paradox to hide game mechanics behind DLC by giving them your cold hard cash.
It's okay, I guess.

Imagine simular a história, 4 séculos do passado humano de 11 de Novembro 1444 até 3 de Janeiro de 1821. Como representar a dinâmica dos diversos povos que moldaram o mundo. 

O equilíbrio que sustenta diferentes partidos, favores e garantias entre as classes internas do seu governo, a fidelidade dos seus aliados e subjugados, tudo que é tão caro a prosperidade; Administramos ao mesmo tempo da chegada de inovações, ideais e tecnológicas, o inicio das grandes navegações, o planejamento e descobrimento do novo mundo, os primeiros passos do comercio global, a chegada da prensa de Gutemberg, a formação de republicas, impérios, califados, coalizões, reinos, mandatos guiados por deus, entre outras interpretações de organização da sociedade, temos o controle de possíveis destinos para diversas representações de povos. Considero representativo a lógica expressa na frase "Por meios diversos chega-se ao mesmo fim" de Montaigne (1533 - 1592), ensaísta francês que analisou instituições, opiniões, costumes e dogmas do pensamento na época em que viveu.

O que a interatividade deste sistema permite é simular dentro do possível os atos e consequências de diversos fatores, a maioria das vezes não se correlacionando fielmente com o mundo e a evolução como conhecemos; Um grande "e se" do que poderia ser o ciclo de poder e expansão do controle exercido por diferentes comunidades que se uniram ou foram subjugadas em volta de uma identidade nacional que tentou sobreviver no tempo. Espalhadas pela extensão da terra com milhares de províncias virtuais organizadas eurocentricamente, como o Novo Mundo aguardando seu fatídico colonialismo, este mapa representa a maior parte do mundo habitado durante as época demarcadas. Diversas famílias de povos, culturas, religiões e tribos que praticam diplomacia, alianças, comercio e guerra, decisões e eventos propõem quase um infinito de diálogos possíveis. 

O tipo de jogo que parece complicado, começa complicado, tu falha miseravelmente, mas depois compreende que não é impossível e recompensa. Observar e absorver, talvez ler informações extras, para aprender o que fazer exatamente e tirar proveito de cada situação é o caminho certo. Assim que perceber estará sobrevivendo, e no tardar, restaurando um reino da decadência e levando a glória, ou algo entre essas linhas. 

Dito a parte séria, tirando a desculpa de guiar o desenvolvimento de uma nação, você  basicamente ficará alucinando frente a tela digital de um mapa, clicando sempre que aparecer uma das caixas de dialogo, botões que podem parecer aleatórios, como um primata cobaia escrevendo uma narrativa a esmo; temos na junção de tudo isso a chance de criar uma historia alternativa do seu sonho febril de império universal.

Europa Universalis IV is a grand strategy game that takes players on a journey through centuries of history, allowing them to build and expand their own empires. Set in a beautifully crafted world that simulates the rise and fall of nations, the game is packed with intricate mechanics and a vast array of modifiers that can affect everything from trade to warfare.

A major downside is the cost of the DLCs. With a total cost of over 400 euros without discounts, it's a steep price to pay for the full experience. While some of the DLCs are worth the investment, others are less essential and can be skipped. It's up to the player to decide how much they're willing to invest in the game.

One of the best things about Europa Universalis IV is the ongoing effort to improve and develop the game. The developers are constantly releasing new DLCs that add new content and mechanics, as well as fixing bugs and improving the overall gameplay experience. This level of support and dedication is impressive and keeps the game fresh and exciting.

Another standout feature of the game is its music. The soundtrack, composed by Andreas Waldetoft, captures the grandeur and drama of the historical period in which the game is set. From epic orchestral pieces to hauntingly beautiful solo performances, the music enhances the game's atmosphere and adds to the immersion.

Despite the high cost, Europa Universalis IV remains a top-tier grand strategy game that rewards players who take the time to learn its complex systems. From managing trade routes to engaging in diplomacy, there's always something new to discover and master. And with a vast array of starting nations to choose from, players can experience different paths to success and explore alternate histories.

I have pretty much nothing bad to say about EU4 - it is the greatest game I have ever played. I can get nitpicky about certain things if I wanted to I suppose but the fact of the matter is:

- This is the definition of grand strategy.
- The depth of play is intense and well worth the steep learning curve.
- The constant updates and expansions continue to give you a new experience (for good or bad).
- The modding community is fantastic.
- The achievements span from unbelievably easy to impossible.
- No game has ever provided me with more satisfying (and frustrating) replayability.
- This game is hardcore.

Every dollar spent was well worth it when you look at a time/dollar point of view.

I have found that finding quality historical strategy games seems to be getting harder and harder, if not impossible. I prefer games with much, much more historical depth and realism than other games, (such as the well known Civilization). 

Many games are released, but a precious few have any depth under the hood to make the game truly enjoyable.

As someone who has been playing strategy games pretty much since the PC became a thing, (and as someone who has played each version of Europa Universalis as well as countless other games of the genre), I feel confident in my opinion that Europa Universalis IV is arguably one of the best strategic games ever made.

There is a learning curve to this game, -it is complex-but it is a "learn as you go" experience, - which makes even learning it enjoyable.

If I had to nit-pick, I would like the ability to customize our nations in a much more in depth way in terms of religion, builds, infrastructure and government.  I would also like to see a much greater depth of military strategy for combat (tactics, fortifications, terrain etc.). Lastly, I do wish that each nation had more features and complexity that made them feel-and play as unique nations. 

But overall, this game is extremely solid. It has an exceptionally high level of replayability-each game will be different and each game will last for weeks if not months of gameplay. Almost all of the additional content for the game is worth the purchase price and while the total cost of the game-(with all content is high), for me it is well worth it (as my number of hours played shows)

If you love history and in depth strategy games, I highly recommend this game.

One of the few games on Steam that I have amassed enough hours on to feel I can adequately write a review. 

This game is a masterpiece. If you love grand strategy and using your brain to achieve goals in games, then this is the game for you. Although daunting when you first start, I promise you once you get your baring's you'll be in love. I own a ton of games on steam and none of them have the replay value that this game has. Coupled with the fact that you can get ALL the DLC content for this game (there's a lot) for 5 bucks a month, makes this game even better.

I play a lot of grand strategy games, but this one is THE BEST "map painting" game on steam, and of all time. EU4 is definitely not a game for everyone. Its very strategic and methodical. You take control of a country of your choice and play from 1444 to 1820 (if your country doesnt get wiped out by then).
The majority of the game is you looking at a map and making governmental decisions, like going to war, making allies, or developing your nation.
There are hundreds of unique ways to play, since almost every country plays differently. I havent even begun to explore all of the possibilities.

My biggest problem with this game is that the total cost of all the DLC is upwards of $350 and will only continue to increase as more DLC gets added. Paradox is notorious for this.
Even though I dont have any DLC, I still really enjoy the game. Though some aspects of the game feel like they are necessary, but are locked behind a DLC paywall.
However, there is a way to get around it. If a friend of yours has EU4 and all/some of the DLC, and sets up a multiplayer lobby, you then have access to the DLC that they own for that campaign.

I do think, at its core, its a very well made game, supported by the fact that its still getting content, albeit in DLC. I do recommend it, but really only if its on sale, which is somewhat often, as I feel the base game is no longer worth $40. I picked it up for $10 and have more than gotten my moneys worth.

They promised better performance, yet again that was a lie. The game is marginally faster on speed five and starts to chug and drag horridly post 1600. They promised better AI and that was a half truth, which is another way to say a lie. The AI is more aggressive but only compared to more recent patches where combat is basically broken. It spends most its time walking from theater to theater melting away under attrition, and with the changes to manpower that makes every nation but the player perpetually low on manpower. Coalitions are a joke. Strong nations are a joke, allies are a joke. Naval landings are better but only because the AI unapologetically breaks the rules in terms of attrition, both on troops and boats. What is punishing for the player is done on a whim by the AI.

The only thing, and I mean the only thing PDX got right here is AI finally building buildings, and building the right ones. However this has always been possible, and was more of a tactic to limit the player's gains by not giving them provinces that are already complete. They are not to be applauded for doing what several mods over the years have implemented, this was always possible and easy.

It's just more crap, more bugs more busted features. Lions w/o Worth is disgustingly overpriced and honestly should have been free, I'm only grateful that it is so completely without value so I don't feel any compulsion whatsoever to pick it up. 

Some good new companies are coming up, should put some pressure to PDX to stop this dramatic slide in quality, but it probably wont. They have their whales and nothing will change that

I have played many hours on this game. Now the game has better stability and the launcher works again. The endless stream of content keeps the game fresh but will eat up your money if you don't pay for their content pass. The game is worthwhile either way  just be careful with the add-ons. They add up quickly.

This game every since its release has captivated my attention. The game while not the prettiest to look at it and can be seen as boring to others, has this level of depth I have yet to find in another game. This is the game I have the second most amount of time on 1600 hours as right now. 

Complexity in this game really makes you feel like you are playing a ruler and having to make tough decisions everyday. For instance diplomacy in this game is very tricky. Most things you do like declare war, make allies with someone who doesnt like them, or even just bordering someone can make the game more dynamic. I find the diplomacy section the most enjoyable for myself. Whether its creating giant webs of alliances to make my country almost impossible to declare on. Or creating giant vassals and destroying my enemies without having to lift a finger. it feels good because the game will let you do that.

Biggest con I will give this game is its complexity. I will say it took my about 100 hours to grasp the concept of this game and actually start having fun. I believe this game should award you a college degree after about 400 hours because of how much complexity there is.

Overall this game has been a blast. This review isnt very good. But I will say this game is amazing once you put in the time to understand it.

[h1] EU4 is gamer-friendly - it is just selective on who its friends are[/h1]

EU4 is a game with lots of complex mechanics and a complicated DLC setup that aims for well off people. If you want to start out, wait for a sale.

[h1] DLCs [/h1]
If you read the Reviews for the game and DLC´s the pricing is questionable and hardly anybody recommends to buy at full price. The next caveat is that the developers chose to include base functions in their DLC's.
[list]
[*] want to upgrade your provice -> DLC
[*] want to build Tradecompanies -> DLC
[*] want to upgrade a trade hub -> DLC
[/list]

Next they topic is that Quality of life improvements are behind a DLC e.g.
[list]
[*] Upgrading your navy -> DLC (land troops are fine)
[*] Recruit to army -> DLC (else you have to recruit by province and then give a move command)
[/list]
As the game is built around playing hundreds of hours, you will get nudged into buying the QoL improvement, as it saves you time and brainpower you can invest on something else.

Most functionality is spread around many DLCs. So there is no "War" DLC with all War options, Diplomacy DLC etc -- compared to e.g. Civ series where an expansion will have one focus on a theme. You can find yourself in the area where you research if you have access to a certain feature or how to unlock it.

[h1] the UI is a mess [/h1]
The game has lots of information and it hides the information in many tabs, submenues or changing tabs if you click an icon or text. So if you start out you have (F1)  country view -> (0) Stability. As a beginner I had a hard time finding cores, hidden under "Manage", that changes the lower pane of the selection. In Government the crown takes you to a new screen.

If you try to find out where your opponent has his colonies, it is a mess - if you mouse of a country you get a red outline - but if it is spread out and the country small the outline is hard to notice. You can use the Goods location screen in the ledger, but cannot limit the information to a certain country.

A clear design choice bevore release with a concept about how the UI will evolve in the future could help a lot.

[h1] Achievements locked behind ironman - Ironman only allows visual mods[/h1]
I do play singleplayer and I detest a developeer telling me how I like my game to play. I did actually base my buying decision on the mod support on steam  - only to relize later that mod support is restricted - and achievements locked behind Ironman - in other games at least the developers let you disable this using a mod. Not here.

[h1] for a 90 € or 280 € price tag the game has an abysmal tutorial[/h1]
It has an introduction like - recruit a unit, move unit - a basic list of steps, but it won´t allow you to test yourself and master each of these conecpts.

E.g. for combat a modern game would start out similar with - recruit a unit, move a unit, explain field of vission, terrain type and then continue to give a goal where you need to apply the skills - e.g. conquer an enemy nation.

Now EU4 is a millitary game, but it calls itself grand-strategy. So you need to know about other types, like espionage, choosing the right casus belli, actaully how to gain certain casus belli - how Aggressive Expansion works, Personal Unions, Gonvernment types, Terrain for combat and provice improvement, ...

(and other games also bring an in-game documentation about their concepts like civiliopedia in Civilisation).

This lack of polish on the developers side has lead to a pletora of online ressources - reddit, youtube tutorials explaining what the game fails to.

Once you took most of the challenges the game is ok.
Just epic !
