Master of Orion II was a really great game. When they tried to top their accomplishment, they made Master of Orion 3, which has a million details that you can control. MoO3 was terrible. This is how I feel about EU4; a game that could have been great if the developers just dialed it down a bit. Of course, Paradox has made Crusader Kings, which is kind of like a dialed down EU4, but in the case of CK they dialed down too far and there are too many important things that are just out of control for the player. 

Paradox studios have some great ideas in their portfolio, but in my opinion they are all rather poorly executed. On top of that, they have this really bad business model of DLC's, which I guess they think is better for their own wallets but very bad for the players.

EDIT: I'm changing my original review to Yes, with a caveat. If you are looking to buy this game, do one of two things:

1. Play multiplayer with someone hosting who has all the DLC already, since you can then play that game with all the DLC too.

2. Use the subscription pass. $5 for all the DLC is worth it, even if you just want to try it out for a bit. If you find you don't like it, it will only be $5 spent instead of $200+.

OLD:

This is a hard review to give.

I love this game, I really do.  One of my top 10 games I've ever played.  It scratches an itch that most other games just can't scratch.  And even after all the hours I've spent playing the game, there are still thousands of hours of content left that I haven't delved into.

Having said all of that, I just cannot recommend it to someone who is looking to get this game for the first time.  The double-edged sword of constant updating by developers has led to the game being constantly refined at the expense of a massive amount of content being locked off by DLC.  Without exaggeration, a new user would have to spend hundreds of dollars to simply upgrade the base game without dlc to the fully-fledged game I play today.  That's not an expense I would recommend to anyone who lives on a somewhat normal income.

Until Paradox changes it's DLC policy to package many of the older DLC into a much cheaper deal for possible new or returning players, I cannot recommend this game.  You should not have to pay the price of multiple Triple-A titles for a single game.

Admittedly I've spent more time watching people play this than I have actually playing it, and that's because the game does nothing to help you.  The tutorials and hints are worse than useless.
The game itself is fine, but it's incredibly dull, and requires a lot of imagination and projection.   There's nothing to look at beyond a lifeless map, data, and a few other things.  Football Manager is a spreadsheet game, but even it manages to be much more visually stimulating, and waaaaay more intuitive than this jumbled mess.
There's tabs, sub menus and all kinds of nonsense hidden all over the screen.  Your fort menu blends in at the side of another menu so it can be easily missed.
Doing anything requires money, and money isn't easy to come by. 
To play this mind numbing map painter you essentially need to know the history, research the area and then set about putting a few things in motion.  After that it's a matter of managing how fast the game plays. 
Honestly, it's the least intuitive game I've ever played.  The DLC model is utterly laughable and honestly I pity anyone foolish enough to throw hundreds of pounds at such blatantly corrupt devs.  The DLC's don't add to the game like all of the map packs in ETS or ATS, instead they complete the game.  The subscription fee is also hilarious.

Honestly, if I had the choice I'd pick up Crusader Kings 3.   It's much more intuitive, it's visually stimulating, you're playing as people instead of a land mass, and it looks like it's a much more complete experience.  Even with the DLC's the price seems fair.  Then again, seeing what I've seen I have absolutely zero trust in PI.

If you like spending a lot of time planning and putting things in motion without really having anything to look at or do, then this is for you if you can afford to ship between £80-£250 on a very bland game that does a million things poorly.

Europa is honestly THE best paradox game to date, the only game that could even think about touching it in terms of fun is CK3 but EU4s grand scale blows CK3 out of the water. In EU4 you have every culture in every corner of the Earth as an option to play. Want to play Sweden and form a massive Scandinavian empire? you can do that. Want to play as a Japanese Daimyo and unify Japan under one flag? you can do that. There's even native american tribes where you can push out the evil colonizers and modernize your tribe. Speaking of which, colonization is really fun in this game. To send your settlers out and conquer new land is a really fun system and i absolutely love how colonies develop into semi-autonomous states instead of you having direct control. This game is simply amazing, if you love grand strategy please please play this. BUT BE WARNED... This is a Paradox game so if you want a full experience you're gonna have to shill out some cash. The game is playable without them but as with all Paradox games the DLC add so much content that frankly should be part of the base game. Regardless, a very good game.

I was a fan of previous EU games. This new one change a lot of things, and a lot of mechanics are now far more better and deeper. I'm already a fan of EU3, and I love EU4 for different reasons. But I think that the basic appeal of both games is the same: play with history having all the time you want to think about every decision you make and have the chance of see the results of your action in a long period forward.
You will like this game if you like history (first of all) and then if you like games where you have to mange complex systems. But you need patience to build up your projects and see them accomplished. It's not a game for arcade fan or fast-play devoted. You will pass a lot of time in pause, evaluating cost/benefits of every action.

Buy the game and a dlc bundle on sale. Far to much additional content is needed to play the game competently. If you get the game and dlc for good price and enjoy grand strategy: there really isn't a better option. Play from the mid 1400's to 1800's. Pick from literally hundreds of nations, duchies, vassals, tribes and more and play from their historic start or pick a year and watch the map transform to match the time period. 

 The game is both difficult to learn and master and lets you change or role play history with an extensive number of systems and mechanics that simulate an expanding empire and all its minutia. The welcoming and helpful community, the deep game play systems, and the astonishing historical backdrop can easily draw you into this unique, historical, grand strategy experience. The game also includes interesting history and gives you the basic historical backdrop and context for any nation or power you choose and give you missions to follow to complete historical milestones. Nothing is required however and you may make any decision you so choose. Will your nation flourish or crumble? It's fun to find out!

There are three types of games. First there are those that are quick and easy to pick up, like card games. Secondly those that require a set-up, like Colonists of Catan or Monopoly. And lastly there are games that require hours of preparation and strategizing. Europa Universalis IV is part of the latter.

The game is based on a real world board game. That real life version uses a variety of chips, cards and pieces. This translates perfectly into a game version. But that also means that the game can become way more complicated as it is possible to code and track multiple features in the background. This is no turn based game. A day passes every couple of seconds and you can adjust the speed. The game uses different forms of currency or mana, like ducats, 'monarch power', manpower, sailors etc. These get updated every month, according to how you build your state.

[i]Setting[/i]
In Europa Universalis 4 (Eu4) you choose a nation in the year 1444. It is possible to select an exact date between 1444 and 1821, but it is advised to start in 1444. In this time frame the world changed drastically and you have to guide your country in becoming a prosperous and strong state. The game uses a historical time frame, but after unpausing the game for the first time, the game is completely ahistoric. It is up to the player to decide what to do.

[i]Gameplay[/i]
A core mechanic in Eu4 is strategically using your 'mana'. Everything has a cost. Integrating vasals, coring new land, recruiting generals, developing your land etc. uses monarch power. (administrative, diplomatic and militairy) The amount of monarch power you gain depends mainly on your ruler's stats (0-0-0 to 6-6-6), your advisors and some other factors. There are more pools of mana like ducats and manpower. The gameplay loop is acquiring and using these pools. Becoming a good player means knowing how to balance your mana usage and how to get even more mana.

[i]DLC's[/i]
Eu4 has a lot of 'DLC's'. Some give flavour to a region or play style. Others add core mechanics and there are also skins and sound tracks available. As a new player it's difficult to grasp this insane list of add-ons. Eu4 gets an update every half-year to a year. There is a free part of the update and a DLC part. This is how Eu4 is monetized.
I advise that you [b]ONLY[/b] buy Eu4 on sale and try it out. Learn the core mechanics. Try a big country around Europe, like France, the Ottomans, England, Spain or Poland. Watch video's on YouTube, read stuff on the wiki and look at achievements and formeable nations. You will find an obstacle in the form of a missing DLC. Decide if it's worth to buy necessary DLC's (and wait for big sales, like on Instant Gaming). This requires a lot of strategizing, in game and when buying DLC's. At least if you want to think economically. Remember, Eu4 is the acquivalent of a Warhammer board game. You need to buy trinkets and extra's to play the game. 
--> Read the wiki for more information on DLC's, but here is a quick summary:

[i]DLC help[/i]
[i]Conquest of Paradise:[/i] If you want to play in the New World
[i]Wealth of Nations:[/i] Core mechanics for trade
[i]Res Publica:[/i] Core mechanics for republics and mana
[i]Art of War:[/i] Core mechanics for diplomacy like vassals (+ religion wars and Napoleonic wars)
[i]El Dorado:[/i] Better Conquest of Paradise, cool custom nation designer.
[i]Common Sense:[/i] Core mechanic for government, flavour for parliaments and some religions
[i]The Cossacks:[/i] Core mechanics for Hordes and cool features
[i]Mare Nostrum:[/i] Extra cool features, should be in base game
[i]Rights of Man:[/i] Lots of quality of life improvements
[i]Mandate of Heaven:[/i] Flavour for Eastern Asia (China, Japan) Quality of life + Cool extra's like Historical Ages
[i]Cradle of Civilization:[/i] Flavour for Middle East + Core mechanics that should be in base game
[i]Dharma:[/i] Flavour for India + Core mechanics that should be in base game (trade company, government reforms)
[i]Emperor:[/i] Flavour for Europe + extra's for late game
[i]Leviathan:[/i] Flavour for South-Eastern Asia and Oceania + Monuments (I bought this game only for the monuments)
[i]Third Rome:[/i] Flavour for Eastern Europe and mostly Russia
[i]Rule Britannia:[/i] Flavour for the English isles + core mechanics for the navy, innovation and Industrial Revolution
[i]Golden Century:[/i] Flavour for Iberian Peninsula and Northwest Africa + more naval stuff
[i]Origins:[/i] Flavour for Africa
[i]Lions of the North:[/i] Flavour for Northern Europe (New style of DLC with way a different approach to 'flavour')

[i]DLC controversy[/i]
Eu4 is monetized with DLC's. But a quick glance on the summary I gave shows the general disgust. Flavour for certain regions is nice, but a single or a couple of core mechanics are put behind a paywall. Sometimes you even need an older DLC to experience a newer DLC. Lions of the North adds more monuments. But you need Leviathan to unlock the monuments mechanic!
[i]Leviathan debacle[/i]
In 2020 1.30 Emperor was released. It was a buggy mess but the devs fixed it within a month. A year later 1.31 Leviathan released. This DLC and update broke the game and netted the worst reviewed DLC of all time on Steam. Lots of players quit or refused to play 1.31. I myself stayed on 1.30 untill 2022. After that a new team took over Eu4. They released 1.32 Origins. Which is a good flavour DLC without significant paywall mechanics. There was a very good free update 1.33 that made the AI actually competent and late 2022 they released the well received 1.34 Lions of the North, again without big core mechanics behind paywalls. Hopefully the trend continues. Eu4 is in a healthy position and can still offer a lot of fun. But there is a lot of potential in the form of mods. The Fantasy Total Conversion Mod: Anbennar might even be considered its own title as it's a complete different experience.


[i]TL;DR[/i]
[b]Style:[/b] Map painter, has cool models and flavour. Bit outdated compared to newer games, but is not a hinder to gameplay. 
[b]Gametime:[/b] Infinite (especially with mods, try Anbennar!)
[b]Difficulty:[/b] Easy to pick up, difficult to grasp
[b]Learning curve:[/b] Under 1000 hours is beginner level. After 2000 hours you can still learn a lot
[b]Multiplayer/Singleplayer:[/b] Both are fun but completely different games. Singleplayer is a great experience. Multiplayer should be played with friends, or look for a community organised game. Multiplayer can be very glitchy with more players.
[b]Price:[/b] ONLY buy on sale.
[b]Rating:[/b] 9/10
[b]Rating/DLC-policy[/b]: 5/10: too many small core mechanics are locked behind paywalls that should only be about flavour.

Be aware that new content is seemingly always locked away in the expansions, and you are probably going to want it, because some of it adds really interesting mechanics. It can get expensive fast! This game is the literal best shit I've played. Unlike HOI4, the game takes a long time, the focuses (sorry I'm a HOI4 man I call them focuses) take ages to get to the requirements, and the chances for alternate history are tremendous. EU4 is truly the only game where the knights templar can set up colonies in the cape of good hope. Speaking of which, also unlike HOI4, the non-major countries have their own skills, like Venice has a powerful navy, the knights templar have professional soldiers, and even the natives can drive proud empires from their lands. Add that to loads of reforms, interesting events, an economic system that makes you think twice about recruiting horrendous amounts of soldiers, and dynastic actions make this my favourite game. Ever. 11/10, I got it on sale but would happily but it full price, hell, maybe but it for more than it's worth!

EU4 is a nightmare of a game.  Extremely complex mechanics plus a highly dynamic AI environment make it virtually impossible to play without pausing and reassessing every decision in depth.  Beginners will need to invest dozens of hours watching YouTube tutorials just to get started.  Torturous hours will be spent while your nation is dragged in to long wars with allies in which you benefit nothing at all.  You will not have any money to spend on development for at least the first 100 years of game play.  A few powerful nations will chew up all nearby smaller powers.  Then they will entangle themselves in endless wars of attrition.  Home country Estate interests (clergy, nobility, burghers)  and rebel armies will test your patience and skill at pleasing absolutely everyone or facing dire consequences.  Replayability is decent because starting allegiances are randomised.  Other than that, I have little positive to say.  But I will play it because my life is that boring.  Sad.

I didn't like this game because of mediocre interface and graphics, boring gameplay and greedy business practices. There can be more than 68 icons on the screen at the same time and the font used is quite hard to read. You can increase the font size in the game menu, but then it becomes blurry. Environment and units graphics aren't too good either. Regarding gameplay, most of the time you'll be looking at the map, reading text, clicking buttons and waiting; there's few interaction with other characters. Finally, there're a lot of DLC packs, but they're incredibly expensive (they cost 400 eur making a single payment or 60 eur per year paying a subscription fee; considering the basic game already costs 40 eur). If a new game is released I will pay close attention to it, because the general idea is quite good (manage production, trade, diplomacy and war with limited violence representation); but I can't recommend it in its actual state.

Incredibly frustrating game where every single war will have the AI focus entirely on you unless they literally have to go through someone else to do so. Wanna attack someone while they're already fighting another tough war? They'll pull all their armies away from that front and onto you and then a couple of months after when their other enemy starts rolling into their lands, they'll white peace to make sure you get fucked.
Sometimes the AI will completely ignore your forts, armies supposedly aren't able to move through areas with a fort and while this holds true for you, sometimes the AI will just completely ignore it and do whatever they want.
There's no way to tell your armies where to retreat to, so sometimes after losing a fight they'll just move over a single province and get completely annihilated, instead of moving past your own fort right next to it and giving you a chance to reinforce.

All of that said, I did spend more than a thousand hours in the game, so clearly there is something worth playing or I'm a masochist. Considering how frustrated this game makes me, I'm leaning towards the latter.

[b] What is this game? [/b]
A $330 game including every major expansion and immersion pack when bought full price. Yet more if you want fun skins or extra music. A game sold so piecemeal they offer a $5 subscription just to lease the DLCs. It's a very niche sort of strategy game with lots of math and relatively simple visuals. There's a high barrier to entry and you'll easily spend 100 hours just figuring out foundational concepts. I think you'll either become addicted or simply not see the appeal, no middle ground. Just look at the amount of sickos in the reviews who have over 1000 hours in this game. I became one of them. You could be next.

[b] What else is this game? [/b]
A fun and intricate strategy game with so many layers and choices to make, rich in history and dripping with charm. A modding community which have personally easily added 300 hours to this game alone with the interesting and inventive creations on the workshop. Consistent updates that make the game better on a regular basis. Paradox is strange, but it does seem like they listen and acknowledge mistakes (Leviathan release, Emperor release, old estates). Multiplayer is alive and well, and lobbies exist for casuals and veterans alike. DLC policy also only applies to the host so only one person needs to experience financial ruin. Or, save the $5 you'd spend on a DLC subscription every month and you'll have everything major in 5.5 years. Diverse systems and unique viability of all playstyles mean you can play one country five ways and it feels different each time. Great for achievement hunting or alt history RP. Infinite replayability. Overall, my favorite game of all time.
Quite a beautiful experience. You have the ability to create any world you desire and do anything you really want in this game. You also have the ability to genocide which is always nice ;).

It'll probably be a bit before the sequel, so I recommend buying the DLCs piecemeal or on sale. Overall still an Outstanding game.
ottoman empire is stinky i dont like them

It may say I have played for 81 hours, but I actually have 594 hours total (+ my Epic Games account before I migrated to Steam). I would say I have a love-hate relationship with this game right here. I love it because it is one of the best strategy games out there (with a mix of politics and military). I hate it because of other reasons + how addicting it is.

Good sides:

Love the soundtrack, beautiful and I can hear it in my head. In terms of difficulty, I might say it is not complex yet challenging (for me). I am actually not that big of a fan of challenging games because I find solving problems a nuisance and my inner soul would kill me for solving problems outside of reality than IN reality. The modding community is impeccable and in my time around the community I've met and seen some very talented souls, the game is very moddable and some mods do spice things up.

Bad side is, it can run pretty bad when it reaches near the end game, and as for me, an Extended Timeline Player, It gets buggy and laggy if you play for long periods of time, i.e 500-1000 years. The DLCs are way too expensive and it just kills me that I have to pay upwards of hundreds of dollars just to get the full experience. I resorted to paying for the subscription anyway but I still think it is too expensive for a beginner and it's almost like you're collecting DLCs rather than getting them to enhance your experience.

All in all, I recommend this game for anyone that loves politics and strategy. Pay for the subscription and get the full experience and download mods for the best experience. 8/10 for me.

My favorite map painter, and probably my favorite Grand Strategy.

EUIV differs from other Paradox titles like HOI or Victoria in that it doesn't focus the experience to war or economy, but rather provides you with a host of simpler but still in-depth mechanics that touch most aspects of "nation-building".  It's the gamiest of the Paradox titles, and the emergent storytelling isn't of the level of CK, HOI, Victoria, but the gameplay itself - balancing war, economy, unrest, diplomacy - is snappy, satisfying, and paced very well.  If you know what you're doing, it's hard to ever find yourself in a CK2 style "Well I own all of Iberia, guess I just need to chill and rule at speed 5 for 20 years" situation - There is always more dirt to acquire, more small countries to absorb peacefully, more crises to avert.  It holds my attention through the full campaign in a way no other Grand Strategy game does.

The UI is pretty outdated, and in order to play the game the way it was meant to be played you'll probably have to watch some youtube. Or a lot of youtube.  If you are willing to put the time in to learn, this game will give back many many hours of super engaging nation building.

I don't really think some of the latest stuff to EUIV such as the monuments is really fitting for EUIV and feels like the kind of flare that's more suited to CKII and CKIII. I get they wanted to give a use to the stuff from the CK series' monuments for mega campaigns, but they just feel like a waste and are better as a modifier, personally. Otherwise, the combat system is mostly fair, even if RNG can screw you hard. We all have experienced rolling a 0 several times in a row when we should have the stats to win.

I think cavalry could use a soft rework to improve their use, as currently they're awful in combat. They should be great as an early game shock unit that is expensive but is worth the cost. As it stands right now, only hordes (And some non-horde states) benefit from cavalry in any functioning capacity. Naval combat is definitely better than what it was when the game first came out, and the fort system is a significant improvement on EUIII's system.
Surviving as Byzantium should be a litmus test we do to people.

We don't even know what war is." 

"Sounds like WOKE NONSENSE to me!" guffawed Columbus, his very presence introducing microplastics into the ecosystem as he cracked a Miller High Life. "This is MAGA country now, boy" he proclaimed before shooting the chief with an unregistered AR-15. The other natives scattered in terror, sheltering their nonbinary tribe members from the bullets and slurs that now ripped through the treeline. "Kek" said Columbus, loading another 30-round assault clip. "This is based. Wait until 4chan hears about this."

As a Grand Strategy Game this game succeeds at creating a fun experience for people looking to scratch that itch. People who don't like Grand Strategy as a genre tell me they dislike micromanagement. If that describes you, I wouldn't recommend this game for you. Those looking to try one for the firs time, I think it's accessible and tutorial resources are online. My advice to navigating to learning all the mechanics quickly is to just play your first few games through even if you lose. Going down in flames instructs well in this regard. 

Many updates to the tools at the disposal of all countries are spread out amongst several DLC expansion. Typically they are bundled with immersion packs for a geographic region. Missions trees, historically accurate skins for the region being emphasised, regional idea groups, religious mechanics, trade mechanics to name some of the paired features you can expect. The ability to "build tall" mechanics were added in Leviathan but were bundled with immersion packs for a particular geographic region/s A. If you want to build tall in geographic region/s B, C and D, you would need to buy the other DLC that has the culturally relevant immersion packs. 

This isn't to say you aren't getting a fair deal on the DLC, the expansions deliver on the features they look to introduce and the cultural immersion packs are focused on a thematically appropriate region. I would say many expansions are not cheap but the value an individual places on the features and cosmetics is their judgement to make. This is what you can expect for the microtransaction system of this game generally but you could easily get hundreds of hours out of the base game which in my opinion is a lot of fun. 

Combat is prevalent but not a spectacle for those who enjoy some more fleshed out combat visuals. The depth of this game is in the logistics of managing your state and not the complexity of it's war system. It would be more accurate to say that all the elements of supporting an army are what is emphasised. The military take over of your neighbour was assured by your superior command of trade, politics, economics, industry, religion etc. 

If this sounds like a good time to you, I think it's a good buy.

EU4 fills me with a rage so hard to define that I doubt it has a definition. But it also fills me with joy that fits the exact same picture. Depending on whether your feeling lucky or not, you'll get 7% sieges, lose 92% sieges, get 20, 0 rolls to 20, 9 rolls. Prussia and Russia are objectively the most OP nations in EU4, one being able to kill stacks in 3 in-day games, and the other being able to drag battles out for the entirety of the Napoleonic wars. EU4 will give you the happiest AND the worst day of your life in 1 session while also proving that Paradox's AI will always go AGAINST you, and never truly help you. 0/10 still can't stop.

As someone who used to have that time back in high school, I get why I used to play and enjoy this game. But I don't have that time anymore, and that's fine. It's not necessarily a huge issue with the game itself or its quality, but it is what stopped me.

An accurate representation of my first time playing: Huh? What is this? What's that? What am I doing? What does that do? Why am I at war?

Steep learning curve but quite entertaining.  I recommend new players roll back to a very early release to see the game before many of the additional mechanics were introduced to get a handle on the core mechanics.  Otherwise it's almost exactly like expecting a 21st century gamer to try to take over as a great minister of state in the renaissance (and lets face it, none of us are actually Axel Oxenstierna).

The hours I have listed are just the hours I play while online, most of the time I play offline alone for peace and quiet. Man, this game as seen me through a lot, it is my coping mechanism. Need a break? I start up EU4. I've played through family tragedy and even a global pandemic. When I am old and grey I will look back and think of this game as something that was there when nothing else was. 

I am a huge history buff, while the game is somewhat historical, it is mostly ahistorical, a history simulator if you will. You can start at England in 1444 for example, and do absolutely nothing the real England did for 600 years. You can do this with any nation. Want to make Austria a republic? Go for it. Want to conquer the world as Ulm? Go for it. Want to colonize the entire world as Brittany? Do it. Want to be a failed state like Italy? Do it again.

It's a nice game, though I do hope they make a follow up game to it, with POPs as the population is an important part of a grand strategy game for this era. And the game is getting bloated through it's many updates.

I have spent a lot of time playing this game, and I had a blast. The game is awesome, there is no denying that.

Then why the negative review?

Because behind this heavenly game lies the devil: Paradox Games. They used to be  a small studio which made games for its own little fanbase. Today, they have a rather anti-consumer DLC policy. They have released unnecessary amounts of unnecessary DLCs, mostly for EU4. Mare Nostrum, Common Sense and the Cossacks are just a few of them. What is worse is that fundamental game mechanics are sold with these shallow DLCs. For example, if you don't own the Common Sense DLC, you cannot improve your provinces; thus the base tax, manpower and the amount of buildings you can build in a province stays the same for the entire 400 years you play in the game.

Like I said at the start, this game is incredible, but understand that it is a significant investment with all the DLCs. If you plan on playing it for a couple of months, you should consider the DLC subscription thingie they released.

EUIV is one of my favorite games. The ability to guide a historic nation through these fascinating time periods makes for a wonderful sandbox with infinite replaybility. That's why so many people have thousands of hours in this game.

Want to play a traditional militiarist Prussia, form Germany, and unite all Germanic peoples? Go for it. Or be protestant Naples and found an anti-Catholic Italy. Or unite Japan under your authoritarian clan. Or play as Mexico and drive the United States into the sea. It's all possible.

I also learn a lot. Every time a history-inspired event pops up, I go to Wikipedia. Every campaign, I learn some history I never would have known. 

The DLC is great, although the price sucks. Older DLC should just be folded into the game. Buy them on sale, if you play this game long term, you easily get your money back.

Like a more complex game of risk this historical strategy ticks lots of boxes for fans of the genre. It is very complex and hard to understand at first but once the main concepts are understood it becomes a very satisfying long play.

1.30 patch somehow achieved excellence in both making Europe beautiful and disgusting at the same time. While rework of Iberia, Italy, France and so on managed, better or worse, to hold itself together, taking a look at Greece and rest of Balkans is suicide for your eyes. Seriously, you either have to go along starting borders or take half of region to make it look half-decent. To have a decent look, you take whole of it. Lusatia is another example, whichever province from a total of three you won't take, it would stick out like a sore thumb. Also, they reworked Stolp and it's still a goddamn triangle, but this time Poland's border with it is so broken, that even rustling emperor's ego with taking it just for sake of satisfying look on map won't save you from the beauty of Kolberg and this abomination that happens to emerge in place of Neumark. Now Poland by no means other than pushing germans to the other side of the Oder can have a border with them that doesn't compete with geometry of Habsburgs' chins.
For a big plus, now you start with two Frances instead of one.

This game has a steep learning curve, but once you've played your first two or three playthroughs were you got absolutely wrecked, this game is a lot of fun. It has got a lot of replayability and is always different and it is basically still in development after more than 5 years there are still constant updates which are financed by the DLCs that always add a lot to the game while leaving you to decide what you want to buy making reskins a separate DLC instead of packing it into the actual DLC that changes how you play the game and charging you extra. So this game is awesome and still getting supported by the developers with new updates and content for nearly 10 years now!
Edit Nov 2019: Sadly the last few DLC have not been full "Expansions" anymore, only what Paradox calls "Immersion Packs" with comparably less new content, but to compensate they only cost half of what the full blown "Expansions" used to cost, so I'm ok with it.

2000h in this game speak for themselves. If you get through the threshhold of the first 50-100 hours, which most need to grasp the game mechanics sufficiently, you will discover a game which keeps on giving. Even after 2000 hours, I have not tried every play style or region. The mission trees and events add so much flavor and guidance to each playthrough and I have not even begun to talk about mods or multiplayer. It is just a masterpiece of grand strategy. The only downside is the DLC-policy which becomes quite expensive, but there are guides to which are more important than others. I would not recommend the game without any DLC. Art of War or Common Sense deliver crucial game mechanics. Everyone who enjoys history, strategy or map painters will love this game.

EU4, this game in all seriousness is great, I love playing this game in the end, yes it has its moments (AI being annoying) but overall there isn't much to complain about the game. Many would complain about the DLC policy Paradox has, but it isn't that bad, every year or half a year they release a $20-$40 DLC which is cheaper than some AAA games, for 100+ hours worth of content and addition to the already infinite hours you can have on the game. I am willing to fork out that X amount to simply enjoy a game at my own pace knowing I am supporting a company who creates games to my flavour. I do think EU4 needs a sequel due to it being outdated but the DLC policy keeping it fresh will keep the community around till it drops. 10/10 would recommend to any history nerd.--

i like EU4,too bad you need to spend a lot of dosh to fully enjoy it,but it's currently on sale as i'm writing (editing it for the 2019 game awards badge) so pick up the base game,art of war and common sense,with those two DLCs you should be able to have a basic understanding of the game and you'll be able to tell if it's for you or not. Even if you suck at it you can always pull a Drew Durnil and just spectate while you're doing something more productive than staring at a map for 5 hours like the wet blanket you are. There are also over 200 achievements for you to torture yourself with so if you're willing to make the investment it's worth every penny, note: having autism is preferable if you want to get into paradox games :^)

One of the best grand strategy games on the market. Paradox have done a great job with this game by making it continually fun and interesting to play. The game has no shortage of interesting playthrough options, achievements to unlock, and features you have never found even after hundreds of hours. The only downside is the absurd amount of DLC which locks a lot of features that improve the game however the game is still good without them. As well as a very fun singleplayer mode it also has a multiplayer mode and workshop support to allow you to sink even more hours into this game. Overall, this game is definitely worth it and I would highly recommend that those interested in grand strategy games get this game.
